While our name is novel, this sorority maintains the strong sisterhood of Sigma chapter that has been at the University for over one hundred years. In its founding, the members of Delta Sigma have shown devotion to our values and each other, and have created an organization that embraces change. The compassion and drive of Delta Sigmas extends far beyond our home at 2311 Prospect Street. Delta Sigmas are leaders on campus and in the UC Berkeley Greek community.
From Cal’s cheerleading team, to Berkeley’s Society of Women Engineers, to the Berkeley Business Society, to Cal’s Campus Ambassador program, you can find our members in leadership positions in over 100 campus organizations. As a chapter, we’ve achieved one of the highest G.P.A. ranks, exceeding the all-campus average, all-women average, and the all-PHC-Greek average. In addition to supporting our sisters in their diverse extracurricular involvements, we love going out together for football games and pep rallies, hosting philanthropy fundraisers, and attending formal social events in San Francisco! You can spot us having Friday morning brunch on our deck enjoying the beautiful place we call home!
Check out our website, Facebook page, Instagram, and Tumblr in the links provided on this Callink page.

Aion interest group is an officially recognized interest group for an Asian Interest Sorority at the University of California, Berkeley. We are striving to bring this Asian-Interest sorority to campus. We want our group to foster long-lasting relationships and build our community through breast cancer and mental health awareness, leadership, scholarship, and Asian awareness. 
Our pillars are:
Leadership
Scholarship
Community
Philanthropy (Breast Cancer Awareness, Mental Health Awareness)
Asian Awareness

Gamma Phi Beta is an International Sorority dedicated to helping women realize their full potential. Of course, you will make lifelong friends here – and in the future after college. But it’s here you will have the opportunity for individual growth through academic excellence, leadership development, social enrichment and philanthropic involvement that will take you wherever you want to go with your life. 

We believe that the result of contribution to community, developing moral and ethical integrity in all aspects of life, and striving for excellence in all levels of your endeavors are elements that one learns as a part of sorority life. Being part of a social organization is also an important "fun" aspect of college life. 

Becoming self-reliant, looking inward toward sisterhood for support and celebrating your individualism are benefits not found in many other organizations.

Every member is selected to life membership. This choice of membership does not relate simply to one college campus or community, for every member belongs to the International Sorority and enjoys a member’s rights, privileges and responsibilities wherever she may live, study, work or travel. As a member, you have the opportunity to be a part of a sisterhood that has blossomed from Four Founders to over 140,000 members with 114 collegiate chapters and 156 alumnae chapters.

Kappa Alpha Theta, the first Greek letter fraternity among women, was founded in 1870 by Bettie Locke Hamilton, Alice Allen Brant, Bettie Tipton Lindsey, and Hannah Finch Shaw. Theta has over 170 chapters with houses throughout the United States and Canada. More than 250,000 women have been initiated into Kappa Alpha Theta, forming strong friendships in chapters from all over, holding the sisterhood strong. The Omega Chapter was founded at University of California, Berkeley in 1890. Our Chapter occupied the first women's chapter house built by Omega sister Julia Morgan, the first woman to study architecture at the Ecole de Beaux Arts in Paris. 
  Kappa Alpha Theta is proud to be national supporters of Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA). CASA is an organization that provides mentors for abused, abandoned and neglected children. These mentors establish close bonds with the children as they interact one-on-one and serve as a voice for the children during the judicial process.
The Omega chapter of Kappa AlphaTheta supports CASA in a number of ways including donations from our annual philanthropic fundraising events, Theta Dodgeball and Cafe Casa (our famous Theta Brunch held at our beautiful Theta home, open to the Berkeley community).
  For any questions regarding Recruitment or Letters of Reference, please contact our Vice President of Membership at omegathetacro@gmail.com.

Children in care are often transferred to different schools, and disruptions like these make it harder to do well in academic settings. Foster youth high school dropout rates are 3 times higher than other low-income children.
  Our goal is to change those statistics, to give them educational support others were born with. To do so, our long-term tutors meet regularly with foster kids around the Bay, remotely and in-person. We plan on hosting workshops and work as advocates and help raise funds to support these children on their path to a bright future.
  Email our officers: officers@abetterway.berkeley.edu or join our facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/abetterwayatberkeley or follow our Instagram: @abwberkeley
  We are accepting applications on a rolling basis for Fall 2022. Feel free to fill out the application form in the meantime: https://forms.gle/1rrPMuyqAgWiV6PPA

Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Incorporated founded on January 13th, 1913 on the campus of Howard University, is a public service organization based on the principles of sisterhood, scholarship, and service; committed to the constructive development of its members and to service of the Black community.
Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc., Kappa Chapter was chartered on the campus of the University of California, Berkeley on February 21, 1921. It is the first historically Black Greek Letter Organization at the University of California, Berkeley, and the first historically Black sorority chartered west of the Rocky Mountains. For more than 100 years, this public service organization has served this campus, the Bay Area, and the state of California.

The vision behind A.N.T.I. is much broader than just providing a performance space to promote inclusivity. We stand to create an atypical platform for performances, allowing for students to create more devised or individual pieces, politically-charged or focused performances, and non-traditional classic theatre productions. From breaking gender roles in casting, to pushing away racial stereotypes, to even developing minority-based perspectives, A.N.T.I. strives to promote what a theatre company for actionable social change to the existing problems within the theatre industry can look like. While our goal for supporting inclusivity is related to many departments and clubs on campus, A.N.T.I. is different because our primary goal is to be inclusive and to create a theatre company on campus that specifically and primarily focuses on promoting the recognition of an individual's artistry, whether it be identity-based, politically-focused, or just artistic expression.

The furry fandom is a subculture interested in anthropomorphic animals. Its origins date back to at least the 1980s in science fiction and comic conventions. Due to the diversity within the fandom, as well as fictional portrayals of the fandom based heavily on stereotypes, a certain amount of stigma and controversy is unfortunately associated with the fandom. The Anthropomorphic Animal Appreciation Association hopes to serve and portray the furry population on campus positively, as well as foster community collaboration between furries at Berkeley with other interest-based or academic groups.

The Gamma Alpha Chapter of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Incorporated was chartered October 23, 1947, which now spans the campuses of the University of California, Berkeley, San Francisco State University, and the University of San Francisco.

Founded in 1975, Berkeley ABA is a consulting organization with 5 teams: Business Development, Finance, Marketing, Non-Profit Organization, and Strategy. Our founders set out to provide a bridge between the professional world and the students of the UC Berkeley campus. Over the course of 45+ years of history, ABA has expanded its mission and now represents many diverse majors and cultures:
ABA’s mission as a business organization is to develop well-rounded business leaders who put our skills to work and never compromise our humility, integrity, or passion for each other and the work that we do. As such, we provide our members with opportunities to gain hands on professional experience through various industry-focused projects.
ABA has become a well-respected organization among the campus, the business community, and the business world. With over 500 Alumni, it is the undergraduate business organization on campus with the largest alumni network.

University of California, Berkeley chapter of Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc.

On Friday evening, November 17, 1911, three Howard University undergraduate students, with the assistance of their faculty adviser, gave birth to the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. This event occurred in the office of biology Professor Ernest E. Just, the faculty adviser, in the Science Hall (now known as Thirkield Hall). The three liberal arts students were Edgar A. Love, Oscar J. Cooper and Frank Coleman. From the initials of the Greek phrase meaning "Friendship is Essential to the Soul," the name Omega Psi Phi was derived. The phrase was selected as the motto. Manhood, Scholarship, Perseverance and Uplift were adopted as cardinal principles.

Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. was founded on November 12, 1922 on the campus of Butler University in Indianapolis, Indiana by seven accomplished community-driven young educators. They believed that the self-respect, knowledge and discipline gained through study would help individuals to recognize their duty and responsibility for their society. Founded on the precept of education, Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc., as a leading national service organization, continues to meet the challenges of the day, promoting and encouraging high scholastic attainment, and continues to grow through Sisterhood, Scholarship and Service.

Alpha Epsilon Omega, established at the University of California Berkeley in August 2022, holds a mission centered around uniting students dedicated to fostering cultural stimulation on campus. This dedication aims to kindle interest in the Armenian language, history, and culture, all while upholding rigorous standards of academic excellence. The fraternity's objective revolves around nurturing a community where brothers wholeheartedly embrace their culture and heritage through philanthropic, cultural, and professional events. AEΩ has established and will continue fostering a supportive network for its members, contributing significantly to academic and social success.

Unity of Strength and Knowledge | Գիտության եվ Հզորության Միություն

Acacia Fraternity was founded in 1904 at University of Michigan, Ann Arbor on May 12th. The California chapter was founded 1905, having the distinction of being one of the oldest operating chapters in the National organization.
However, "an organization is not necessarily good because it is old, but old because it is good." There are a lot of great fraternities out there, and only you can decide which one is right for you. Here are a few reasons why Acacia Fraternity should be on your short list.
Acacia Emphasizes Academic Achievement
Academic achievement should be the first and foremost priority of all university students. It is also central to the mission of Acacia Fraternity, whose chapters stress academics above all else. Moreover, the Acacia Fraternity Foundation assists deserving Acacians with cash scholarships — over $250,000 in scholarships and educational grants were awarded by the foundation during the 2007-2008 academic year alone.
Acacia Develops Leaders
Acacia Fraternity is dedicated to building leaders by providing a wealth of leadership opportunities for our members. From social issues to academic, business to philanthropy, the Acacians of today are the leaders of tomorrow. Click here to view a list of prominent Acacians.
Acacians Help Better the Communities in Which We Reside
Our motto is "Human Service," and we take it very seriously. As member of Acacia Fraternity you will have ongoing opportunities, through structured community service programs, to make a difference in the lives of those in need.
Acacians Value Fitness
Members of Acacia are encouraged to participate in intramural sports, a system in which athletes of all caliber find camaraderie and physical challenge. Whatever the sport, and whatever your skill level, as a member of Acacia you will always have a place on the team.
Acacians Know How to Have Fun
Forget the "Animal House" stereotype of reckless partying and irresponsible behavior. Acacia's policy is that each chapter maintains a fun yet responsible social policy that promotes responsible choices and the dignity of every individual as well as zero tolerance for illegal activities.

Delta Xi Phi Multicultural Sorority, Incorporated is a national multicultural sorority based upon five pillars – increasing multicultural awareness, the advancement of women through higher education, community service, friendship, and sisterhood. Our sisterhood was founded in 1994 at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, was a chartering member of the National Multicultural Greek Council, and has become one of the largest and fastest growing multicultural Greek letter organizations in the country with 23 chapters nationwide.

Welcome to the Lambda Chapter of Gamma Rho Lambda at UC Berkeley!
  Gamma Rho Lambda (ΓΡΛ) is the first national, college-based, Queer and Ally social greek organization. We aim to provide a safe space and support system for queer and allied individuals. We center and prioritize people of color, folks of marginalized identities, undocumented folks, trans and GNC individuals, low-income, and queer!
  Interested in joining Spring 2023? Please fill out this google form to receive updates about our recruitment week! 
You can also find us on ig @grlberkeley and learn more about us on our website https://grlberkeley.wordpress.com/

Established in 1992 at the University of California, Berkeley (founded nationally in 1987 at Chico State University), Gamma Zeta Alpha Fraternity, Inc. is a Latino interest fraternity dedicated to three principles: Academic Excellence, Community Service, and the maintenance of the Latino culture through Brotherhood. All brothers of this fraternity strongly abide by these values in their everyday lives and demonstrate this strength through performing a number of community building activities. Community service is perhaps one of our largest emphases, as we strive to return a small portion of what our families and upbringings have provided to us in our quest for success. The strong bond that we possess among our 23 chapters statewide makes the brotherhood experience unlike any other Greek organization on campus.

column3: Lambda Theta Alpha Latin Sorority, Inc.
column6: The purpose of Lambda Theta Alpha shall be to provide a sisterhood based on Unity, Love, & Respect. To develop strong Leaders who will then provide and practice political, social and cultural activities. To promote Latino Unity through charitable and educational programs. To maintain a high standard of learning and serve as a voice for the Universal Woman, all Latino students and disenfranchised communities. Lambda Theta Alpha is the FIRST Latina Sorority created in the Nation as well as the Largest Latina Sorority in existence.

Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. was the first Latina Sorority on the West Coast and on the UC Berkeley Campus. Established in 1986, Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. continues to provide its members with a support system based on academic excellence, community service, and sisterhood. 
The purpose of Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. is to open the doors of opportunity to the Latinas of our community. Our primary focus is academic excellence and meeting the needs of Latina women in higher education. Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. also promotes the advancement of Latinas through various campus activities and community services, and provides an environment for personal growth within a unit of sisterhood. Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc.'s priorities, however, will be placed upon academic excellence and community service.
Divine Delta Chapter | University of California, Berkeley | Est. April 6, 1991
In the Spring of 1991 three strong, brave, and intelligent Latina women, Jennifer Garcia, Maria Martinez, and Rosalinda Valdez felt the need to establish an organization that supplemented their needs as women in higher education at UC Berkeley. This need led to the formation of the Delta chapter of Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc., and the establishment of the first Latina organization at UC Berkeley. Twenty-seven years later, the Delta chapter continues it's commitment to academic excellence, community service, and sisterhood. Although we are a Latina-based sorority, we accept applicants regardless of race or color, national origin, religion, sexual orientation or handicap.
Pillars 
Academic Excellence, Community Service, Sisterhood 
Traditions
Stepping: In 1987 the sisters of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. first introduced stepping to ladies of Lambda Theta Nu sorority Inc. by inviting them to step on stage in a unity step. Our sisters at California State University, Chico added the use of machetes as a symbol of strength, a symbol with direct cultural ties.
Machetes: In 1989 Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. became the first sorority to incorporate the use of machetes in a stepping performance. The use of machetes has traditionally showcased the bravery of men. However, for Lambdas, breaking down this male-based tradition not only served as symbol of empowerment but also exemplified the determination of Latinas to integrate into every aspect of life that was not traditionally meant for Latinas. The incorporation of machetes in our performances personify our culture and our strength as women whose perseverance is multidimensional.
Strolling: Strolling, also known as party walking, is a synchronized dance used to encourage commonalities among sisters and showcase our organization and/or to compete in shows.
Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. Facts
Founded Nationally: March 11, 1986 at California State University, Chico
Founded at UC Berkeley: April 6, 1991
Colors: Burgundy, Silver, White
Nickname: Lambdas, Sexy Silver Roses
Symbol: Rose
Chapters: 44 Chapters Strong, 10 States Wide
  Add us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/berkeley.lambdas
Follow us on Instagram: lambdathetanu_berkeley

column3: Lambda Theta Phi, Latin Fraternity, Inc.
column6:
On December 1, 1975, history was made – history on a college campus, which would transcend other colleges/universities throughout the United States; history which would have a positive impact on the Latino community and our nation; history which would forever change the Greek system, more specifically, the entity known as a fraternity. On December 1, 1975, Lambda Theta Phi was founded on the campus of Kean College in Union, New Jersey.

The ideals of this brotherhood are the following: Academic Excellence; Brotherhood; Leadership; Latino Unity; Service. On a daily basis, our brothers live up to these ideals, as set forth by fourteen young Latino men decades ago. 

Since our founding, Lambda Theta Phi has established chapters in every region of the country at both the undergraduate and professional levels. Our brotherhood continues to provide the necessary skills and resources for the advancement and empowerment of our people and for the betterment of this nation. 

The University of California, Berkeley was home to the newest chapter of Lambda Theta Phi, Latin Fraternity, Inc. in the Spring semester of 2004. Ten undergraduate students came together with the idea of introducing a positive image of a Latino fraternity to the UC Berkeley campus. They wanted to embrace and take part in the unity, brotherhood, pride and respect for all cultures that Lambda Theta Phi offered.

On May 9, 2004, Luis Sanchez, Renato Manay, Renzo Manay, Arquimides Pacheco, and Rafael Hernandez created a historical landmark and established the first Latino Greek Letter Fraternity officially recognized by the National Interfraternal Council (NIC) on the UC Berkeley campus.

Now, since its establishment and through its further development and growth, Lambda Theta Phi in UC Berkeley has continued to carry through its ideals of a service/social fraternity by giving back to the community while engaging in social activities that would allow further bondages among our members and with other organizations. Such include our participation in the Annual AIDS Walk, our service in low-income Oakland Elementary schools, and advocacy of immigrant rights to day laborers within the county of Alameda. Apart from these community service events, this chapter has sought to create strong ties and mutual respect with other Latin and non-Latin organizations through social activities and collaborative efforts.

Lastly, the main goal of Lambda Theta Phi in UC Berkeley is to pursue the educational success of our fraternity brothers. At the national level, from New Jersey to California, many go on to become doctors, lawyers, engineers, among other professionals.

====Who We Are====
The Alpha Delta Phi California Chapter has been a mainstay of the University of California ever since we first received our charter in 1908. In addition to the immense social gratification Aqua Delt’s privileged brotherhood provides, there are many academic and character building advantages unique to becoming a part of the Alpha Delta Phi. Our novelty and selective chapter size offer the opportunity to cultivate immediate leadership experience and contribute to a fresh and emerging legacy.

====Notable Alumni====
-Walter Haas Jr: President and CEO of Levi Strauss & Co.
-Allan Sproul: President of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, namesake of Sproul Hall.
-David M. Solomon: Current CEO of Goldman Sachs
-Dr. Frederick Allen: Pioneer of Diabetes Research.
-2 U.S. Presidents: Franklin D. Roosevelt & Theodore Roosevelt
-Francis Julius Bellamy: original author of the Pledge of Allegiance
-7 Supreme Court Justices
====Our Mission====
We seek to develop potential new members through our national founder, Samuel Eells’ original vision statement: "a true philosophical spirit looking to the entire man, so as to develop his whole being - moral, social and intellectual."
Established with ASUC 11/9/11 SB 138 Fall 2011

On August 14, 2022, a group of 6 Latina/Chicana women established the Iota Chapter of Phi Lambda Rho at UC Berkeley. They brought forth this beautiful organization in order to uplift women of color at Cal through sisterhood, mutual support, & love. We hope that bringing Phi Lambda Rho to Berkeley will create a supportive sanctuary within this historically white-serving institution for the growing number of Latinas on campus to flourish.
Phi Lambda Rho Sorority Inc., is a multi-cultural Chicana/Latina sorority popularly known as “Rhosas” or “Rhos.” Sisters of Phi Lambda Rho organize and execute events catered to their four pillars -- Academics, Cultura, Philanthropy, and Sisterhood --throughout the year, making them an active and professional sorority in the community.

The sorority serves as a retention group for aspiring young women in college who wish to leave a positive impact in their communities by engaging in service to the community while displaying a sense of cultural pride and fostering life-long bonds.
Follow us on Instagram: @ucberkeleyrhosas
For more information, contact us at flr.iota.president@gmail.com

CAT is a group of students from various backgrounds that work with the greek councils towards a safer and more educated community with respect to alcohol.
CAT has a double mission:
- Monitor the social events of the greek community in order to ensure all safety rules are being followed.
- Educate students to a responsible way of partying and drinking alcohol.

We are the Chi Alpha chapter of Alpha Epsilon Pi at the University of California, Berkeley, founded in 1949 and re-founded in 1985. Since our founding, we have been growing constantly. Several brothers hold executive positions in many organizations on campus, including heavy involvement in the Jewish community: ASUC (UC Berkeley's Student Government), Jewish Student Union,TAMID Group, and many others. Like CalGreeks Family Feud, our philanthropic events raise over thousands of dollars for several charities per semester. Furthering our relations with other houses in the Greek system, we hold several joint social and philanthropic events on a weekly basis.

Alpha Gamma Omega (ΑΓΩ or "AGO") is a national, Christ-centered fraternity. It was founded in 1927 at UCLA, making it one of the oldest national fraternities in the United States that have retained its Christian values. ΑΓΩ at UC Berkeley was founded in 1938 and is the second oldest chapter of ΑΓΩ. There are currently eleven active chapters. ΑΓΩ maintains a close relationship with its Christian "sister" sorority Alpha Delta Chi.
  ΑΓΩ exists for the following reasons:
1. To win others to a saving knowledge of Jesus Christ
2. To promote Christian fellowship
3. To present Christian ideals in word and deed
4. To search reverently for the truth
5. To uphold the traditions and ideals of the university
6. And to deepen the spiritual lives of the members.

Alpha Sigma Phi was founded on December 6th, 1845 at Yale University, and today stands strong as one of the fastest growing fraternities in the nation. Our fraternity stands on the pillars of Silence, Charity, Purity, Honor, and Patriotism, and our brothers strive to embrace these values in order To Better The Man and become Brothers For Life. If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact us!
Sean Collins, Chapter President
Kyle Mak, Chapter Vice President

Established in 1865, Alpha Tau Omega was the first fraternity created after the Civil War. ATO was founded at the Virginia Military Institute by three cadets who sought to create a brotherhood based on eternal and immutable principles to unite men and heal the divisions caused by the war. 
ATO continues to reinforce these principles today, as embodied in the fraternity's creed:
"To bind men together in a brotherhood based upon eternal and immutable principles, with a bond as strong as right itself and as lasting as humanity; to know no North, no South, no East, no West, but to know man as man, to teach that true men the world over should stand together and contend for supremacy of good over evil; to teach, not politics, but morals; to foster, not partisanship, but the recognition of true merit wherever found; to have no narrower limits within which to work together for the elevation of man than the outlines of the world: these were the thoughts and hopes uppermost in the minds of the founders of the Alpha Tau Omega Fraternity."
The Gamma Iota Chapter of Alpha Tau Omega at UC Berkeley has received several awards ranging from academic to athletic successes. We provide an excellent way to delve into a rich life at Berkeley with socials with sororities, brotherhood retreats, philanthropy events, club nights, sporting nights, and a whole lot more. We have consistently successful intramural teams in basketball, football, soccer, softball, and volleyball.
We live in the largest fraternity house on campus, which has been recently renovated and is well taken care of. Our brothers are diverse in their backgrounds and their studies - we are open to all who are charismatic and outgoing.
Our alumni range in successes from former US Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens, the Vice President of Fox Sports, a major Hollywood talent agent, a world class anesthesiologist, a senior partner at Goldman Sachs (who was named by Haas as the Business Leader of the Year for 2014), and a former California superior court judge. 
One of ATO's most notable contributions to Cal is the original Oski. Oski was a bear cub who lived in the ATO house in 1923 until he grew too large and was moved to the Oakland Zoo.

Chi Psi Fraternity is the first social fraternity of gentlemen, established nationally in 1841. This Alpha (chapter) of Chi Psi at the University of California, Berkeley was founded in 1895, making it one of the oldest and richest traditions on campus. Our Fraternity is composed of undergraduate students from across a wide range of disciplines and backgrounds, brought together by a mutual desire and respect for brotherhood. We support and inspire one another to succeed, despite the competitive academic atmosphere at Berkeley. We maintain a prominent building (The Lodge) on Piedmont Ave, a robust social calendar, intense involvement in campus life, and a dynamic alumni base right here in the Bay Area that provides career support and guidance.
Most importantly, Chi Psi is a brotherhood of gentlemen in the pursuit of excellence. Since our inception more than 175 years ago, the only requirement for membership has always been that one displays the characteristics of a gentleman. By committing ourselves to the values associated with this pursuit, we help young men mature into responsible, compassionate, and confident members of the greater community. 
Furthermore, we are committed to maintaining a diverse, equitable, and inclusive brotherhood that welcomes all kinds of gentleman. We respect and acknowledge our brothers' diverse experiences, and are strong in our unity. 
If you're interested in rushing or learning more about our organization, please email andreasmaass@berkeley.edu.

Delta Upsilon Fraternity was founded in 1834 upon the basis of non-secrecy, meaning we hold nothing secret: all of our rituals, initiations, and principles are open to the public.  

We now stand as the oldest and largest non-secret fraternity, and have grown into an organization that focuses on providing our men with a unique college experience, one grounded in our four founding principles of the Promotion of Friendship, Development of Character, Diffusion of Liberal Culture, and the Advancement of Justice.  We accomplish this through a variety of educational programming opportunities, including our Leadership Institute, held annually in a different city across the country; the Winter Educational Conference held every January in Indianapolis; the Global Service Initiative, which sends a group of our undergraduate men to Jamaica where they spend a week doing service work; and staff- and volunteer-run Regional Leadership Seminars.

column3: Greeks Against Sexual Assault at Berkeley (GASA)
column6: Greeks Against Sexual Assault (GASA) is a peer-education based organization that works with members of the Berkeley community, especially with the CalGreeks Community and the LEAD Center. Our mission is to educate members of our community on SVSH, reform our current culture to be more inclusive and aware of issues facing SVSH, and to advocate for those who are survivors in our campus community. This education may come in the form of workshops, roundtables, meetings, or other settings. This includes but is not limited to education about: consent, consent talks, privilege, power dynamics, bystander intervention, and national and local policies. GASA is committed to advocating for survivors of sexual violence and creating a survivor-centric CalGreeks and greater campus community.

Phi Delta Theta was organized with three principle objectives: The cultivation of friendship among its members, the acquirement individually of a high degree of mental culture, and the attainment personally of a high standard of morality.
These objectives, referred to as the Cardinal Principles, have guided over 225,000 men since 1848 when the Fraternity was founded at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio.
The Fraternity teaches men that these areas of commitment, outlined in The Bond of Phi Delta Theta, are not to be viewed as separate ideals, but as areas of discipline for daily life. Developments intellectually, in leadership, and human service (to name a few) are vital to the men of Phi Delta Theta. A member will support, and in turn have the support of, his brothers as these principles are lived out.

Since its founding in 2001, Alternative Breaks has offered students opportunities to connect with the greater community through meaningful service, education, and reflection during their academic breaks. Many participants return from their experiences with greater insight on a particular social justice issue and a deeper understanding of what it means to get involved in the community. This year, Alternative Breaks offers seven trips to different locations during the spring break, covering issues such as environmental justice, health care, immigration, and housing insecurity.
These student-led trips travel to different locations in California and Puerto Rico to further their understanding of the community and to bring knowledge gained on-site back to the Berkeley community. Students not only participate in a week-long service trip, but also a spring DeCal course to explore various topics revolving around each social justice issue and engage in reflection both pre- and post-trip.
Our Spring 2024 experiences include:
Central Valley - The Unsung Heroes Harvesting Your Tomorrow: Exploitation, Migration and Resilience
San Francisco - Economic Justice | No Place Like Home: Housing Inequity 
East Bay - Environmental & Food Justice: Heal Your Planet Heal Yourself (HYPHY): Building Sustainable Legacies Rooted in the Town
Los Angeles - Striving for Health Equity in Los Angeles
Puerto Rico -Bombiando con Puerto Rico
San Diego - Immigration Isn’t a Crime: The Fight for Human Rights at the Southern Border
Apply now! Link to Spring 2024 Participant Application!
Priority deadline: Oct 23 at 11:59pm
Final deadline: Oct 26th at 11:59pm
Our mission is to create a sustained dialogue that fosters change around sustainability and environmental justice in all Greek Councils through education and community created solutions.

The Interfraternity Council (IFC) is one of four Greek councils at Cal that abide by the pillars of Friendship, Leadership, Scholarship and Service. We are the binding organization that ties all of the recognized fraternity chapters on campus. The number of fraternities is now over thrity, which amounts to approximately 1300 of the undergradute men at UC Berkeley. IFC serves chiefly as the official connection between the individual chapters and the University of California. As a council we are by and large self-governed through the efforts of representative delegates from each chapter, who work year long with the officers on IFC to strategize, plan, organize and execute short and long term goals to ensure the growth of the fraternity system at Cal.
IFC can also be thought of as the organization capable of doing things for the benefit of the entire community that no individual chapter has the resources to do on their own. We frequently engage in activities that include Greek-wide philanthropy and social events, public relations with the University and rest of the Berkeley community, risk management and safety of the entire community and Greek wide recruitment, to name a few.
Recruitment into IFC chapters is generally available at the beginning of every semester to every undergraduate male seeking to enhance their time at Cal by being a part of an organization that is truly greater than the sum of its parts. Greek members graduate with uncomparable experiences of the brotherhood, leadership opportunities and social life that is inherent in every chapter, regardless of the letters.

We, the undersigned Greek organizations have joined together to form this council known as the Multi-Cultural Greek Council at the University of California, Berkeley in order to better meet our individual needs, voice our concerns and promote the greater good of our community. Our official charter date is February 2007. We recognize that there are certain areas of action and programming that can be best carried out by the joint efforts of all such organizations. As culturally based organizations, we strive to promote and uplift our common heritages and history. As a council we shall uphold our commitment to service, scholarship and the values of sisterhood and brotherhood.
  Member Organizations: 9 Sororities, 6 Fraternities
Delta Xi Phi Multicultural Sorority

 Gamma Zeta Alpha Fraternity, Inc.
