Emily Enriquez at emilyenriquez@berkeley.edu
Additional Advisor, if applicable. Some groups benefit from having assigned advisors across units. This relationship can be informal or formal. If formal, the advisor name appears here:
Not Applicable

The vision behind A.N.T.I. is much broader than just providing a performance space to promote inclusivity. We stand to create an atypical platform for performances, allowing for students to create more devised or individual pieces, politically-charged or focused performances, and non-traditional classic theatre productions. From breaking gender roles in casting, to pushing away racial stereotypes, to even developing minority-based perspectives, A.N.T.I. strives to promote what a theatre company for actionable social change to the existing problems within the theatre industry can look like. While our goal for supporting inclusivity is related to many departments and clubs on campus, A.N.T.I. is different because our primary goal is to be inclusive and to create a theatre company on campus that specifically and primarily focuses on promoting the recognition of an individual's artistry, whether it be identity-based, politically-focused, or just artistic expression.

This group is intended to be used to demonstrate tools and modules of the CalLink org management system for registered student organizations who are ASUC-sponsored at UC Berkeley for the 2022-2023 academic year.

Our mission is to preserve, promote, and embrace the cultural heritage of Afghanistan through social events, education, mentorship, advocacy, and fundraising. We are partnered with other Afghan student organizations across the state in a collaborative effort to bring awareness to the rich culture and tradition that Afghanistan has to offer. We invite those of all cultural backgrounds to learn about Afghan culture/history and contribute to our advocacy efforts.

MISSION
  Bear Closet aims to create a platform for LGBTQ+ students to share their personal narratives with middle and high school students in the Bay Area. We encourage members and supporters of the LGBTQ+ community to serve as mentors and advocates for the equality of all identities by sharing their personal journey toward self-love and acceptance. Through class discussions and projects, we will explore LGBTQ+ experiences and learn more about the community and how we can best serve it. In addition, students will also be provided with public speaking opportunities that will help inspire Bay Area youth to take pride in their identity and fight for a stronger, more inclusive future.
WHAT WE DO
Bear Closet is a community-based organization and DeCal course offered at UC Berkeley dedicated to training and preparing students to speak at middle and high schools regarding LGBTQ life at college, through the Pacific Center’s Speaker’s Bureau program. Such services are essential to motivate LGBTQ adolescents to pursue higher education with the reassurance of a better, more inclusive future they may look forward to in college. Our organization and course are open to students of all genders and sexualities (including straight, cisgender allies), and will facilitate students’ volunteer work with LGBTQ support organizations, including the Pacific Center and Center for Educational Partnerships.

We welcome anyone interested in sharing their queer-related stories and experiences (i.e. personal, of a friend/family member, etc.) at middle and high school classrooms, in hopes of motivating out or closeted youth to pursue college education with the assurance of a better future. Rather than strictly focusing on assignments and deadlines, our two-unit DeCal prioritizes class discussion and bonding among its members, for the sake of establishing a strong base for community service.

We are a student organization dedicated to education, research, and creation in fields encompassing, and related to, the production of 3D animation. We provide a group for students who are interested in working in the 3D animation or related industries, researching in relevant fields, or simply for students who are interested in learning about the topic. To facilitate a healthy ecosystem of support, we run a DeCal class called UCBUGG: 3D Modeling & Animation (http://www.ucbugg.com). We also host guest lectures related to the topic of 3D Modeling & Animation, to help students pursue their career and self-learning goals.
  To join, just hop on our Discord (https://discord.gg/ZUFgDry) and follow us on social media. That's it. No apps, dues, etc.

Dedicated to building community among Queer & Asian students, Cal Queer & Asian welcomes all interested students to join us. Whether you’re still questioning, seeking friends, looking for activism/leadership/educational opportunities and beyond, Cal Q&A is a great group to join. You don’t even have to be queer or Asian - anyone who has a genuine interest is considered family :) 
Cal Q&A was founded in 1995 on the UC Berkeley campus as a student organization dedicated to the intersectionality of the Queer and Asian identities. Through meetings, various monthly events, and our annual conference, Cal Q&A acts as a safe space, social group, and support network for any and every student on the UC Berkeley campus. Our meetings are casual and relaxed, and we invite students to come in at anytime and bring a friend if they like.
Resources | linktr.ee/calqa | https://www.instagram.com/calqanda/

3DMC focuses on teaching and learning 3D printing and modeling skills. We hold workshops, participate in competitions, teach DeCals, and host an annual 24-hour 3D printing designathon.  We also tinker with 3D printers and 3D print cool projects!
If you are interested in learning more about 3D modeling/printing, teaching it to other students, or competing in design competitions, then swing by one of our meetings or check out our 3D Printing and Design decal!
Follow us on Facebook at "3DMC at Berkeley" or join our Slack (goo.gl/cF63vZ) to get the latest updates on our club's meetings and events.

This organization aims to represent LGBTQ+ Chinese international students at Berkeley while advancing equal access to resources on campus for everyone who identifies as part of the community, and serves as a hub for transnational LGBTQ+ grassroot organizing among this community and allies

The purpose of this organization is to engage in virtual and in-person volunteering opportunities initiated and developed by UC Berkeley students and alumni. With the impact of COVID-19 on our society, we are passionate about empowering and collaborating with fellow Cal Bears to meet the needs of our local community and the world.
  If you're interested in getting involved, check out our website and sign up at 5and2berkeley.org.

Out for Business at Berkeley is a queer, undergraduate business organization on campus that develops, inspires, and connects the next generation of LGBTQ+ business professionals at UC Berkeley. Our mission is to foster diversity, inclusiveness, and a strong sense of community for LGBTQ+ undergraduates interested in the fields of business, consulting, banking, marketing, management, and similar industries.

Amores Valientes is a community of Queer & Trans Latinx students at University of California Berkeley. The purpose of AV is to provide a safe space, to create a social environment for networking and community building for the Queer/Trans Latinx community on campus. AV does this by having programming and collaborating with other organizations on campus following the democratic principles of participation and where respect and confidentiality are fostered. Our meeting times will be on our Instagram linked below, if not @amores_valientes

column3: Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
column6:
oSTEM aims to unite the LGBTQ+ students within the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics to foster a strong professional and social network as well as to promote awareness of their presence in all communities.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
We are preparing for Spring 2024 meetings however, we currently conduct club contact through:
  Discord
Instagram
Linktree
In Person SP 24 Meetings:
*tentative* Bi-weekly Wednesdays from 5-6 PM

We hope to tackle LGBTQIA+ health disparities and social justice issues in medicine through outreach and education at the undergraduate level, as well as the social, professional, and academic development of our members. Five pillars define our mission: [Q]ommunity, Allyship, Philanthropy, Professional Development, and Academic Support. QAPPA welcomes anyone interested in sexual and gender minority topics! Our regular events throughout the semester include guest speakers, attending conferences, and an article-based journal club. Meetings for the Fall '23 semester will be announced shortly! Sign up for our listserv for more details! 
Check out our Linktree!
Sign up for our email listserv for events and meeting topics!

Children in care are often transferred to different schools, and disruptions like these make it harder to do well in academic settings. Foster youth high school dropout rates are 3 times higher than other low-income children.
  Our goal is to change those statistics, to give them educational support others were born with. To do so, our long-term tutors meet regularly with foster kids around the Bay, remotely and in-person. We plan on hosting workshops and work as advocates and help raise funds to support these children on their path to a bright future.
  Email our officers: officers@abetterway.berkeley.edu or join our facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/abetterwayatberkeley or follow our Instagram: @abwberkeley
  We are accepting applications on a rolling basis for Fall 2022. Feel free to fill out the application form in the meantime: https://forms.gle/1rrPMuyqAgWiV6PPA

The Queer Alliance and Resource Center, formerly the Queer Resource Center and Queer Alliance, was united for the first time in 2008 by a Senate Bill written by Gregory Stevens and Senator Corey Jackson and sponsored by Senator Corey Jackson. QARC is one of UC Berkeley’s oldest student organizations, established 1969 shortly after the Stonewall Riots. 
The Queer Alliance and Resource Center is a student-run organization in charge of providing social, educational, and safe sex programming for the queer and trans community on campus, and also acts as an umbrella organization for all active queer/trans communities on campus. QARC hold bi-weekly meetings, acting as a caucus for all active queer/trans organizations on campus (as well as queer-allied organizations), taking place every other week at a time set by the Board. QARC empowers and enriches the experiences of QT+ students, faculty, and staff at UC Berkeley through advocacy, service, and engagement. 
The Queer Alliance and Resource Center also maintains 2 QARC lounges in space A15 of the Hearst Field Annex; they are safe spaces and open to all students and QT student groups, with sexual wellness, wellness and academic resources.  Our current list of resources available remotely can be found here: queer.berkeley.edu.
  QARC would like to remind everyone to support the queer and trans (and queer-allied) groups on campus including: 
-Bear Closet
-Beyond the Binary
-Cal Queer & Asian (Cal Q&A)
-Cal Ace Space
-Student Athlete Gay-Straight Alliance (Cal SAGSA)
-De Colores / Queer Trans Latinx Collective
-Gamma Rho Lambda (GRL)
-GIA MAG
-Queer and Ally Pre-Health and Pre-Med Association (QAPPA)
-QJew (Queer and Jewish)
-Out for Business (O4B)
-Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (oSTEM)
-Oscar Wilde / Johnson Rivera House
-Queer Student Union (QSU)
-Queer Trans South, Southwest Asians, and North Africans at Berkeley (QTSSWANA)
-Queer Art & Fashion Show (QAFS)
-Sigma Epsilon Omega (SEO)
-T-Cal: A Transgender and Gender Non-Conforming Space at Cal
-Unity House
-Zawadi / Black QTs at Cal

We are the Arab Student Union (ASU) and our goal is to create and maintain an Arab environment for the benefit of Arab students and interested members of the community and to promote an understanding of the Arab history, culture, and heritage at the University of California, Berkeley - through education and example.

column3:
Q
Queer and Trans Geographers of Berkeley

column6: The furry fandom is a subculture interested in anthropomorphic animals. Its origins date back to at least the 1980s in science fiction and comic conventions. Due to the diversity within the fandom, as well as fictional portrayals of the fandom based heavily on stereotypes, a certain amount of stigma and controversy is unfortunately associated with the fandom. The Anthropomorphic Animal Appreciation Association hopes to serve and portray the furry population on campus positively, as well as foster community collaboration between furries at Berkeley with other interest-based or academic groups.

The American Indian Graduate Student Association (AIGSA) is dedicated to bringing Native and Indigenous identifying graduate students together from across campus. Through academic, social, and outreach events, AIGSA works towards strengthening the Native American/Indigenous student community on-campus and beyond. AIGSA also provides opportunities for Native grad students to connect with other students, staff, and faculty who are Native or work in areas that impact Native peoples.

Founded in 1975, Berkeley ABA is a consulting organization with 5 teams: Business Development, Finance, Marketing, Non-Profit Organization, and Strategy. Our founders set out to provide a bridge between the professional world and the students of the UC Berkeley campus. Over the course of 45+ years of history, ABA has expanded its mission and now represents many diverse majors and cultures:
ABA’s mission as a business organization is to develop well-rounded business leaders who put our skills to work and never compromise our humility, integrity, or passion for each other and the work that we do. As such, we provide our members with opportunities to gain hands on professional experience through various industry-focused projects.
ABA has become a well-respected organization among the campus, the business community, and the business world. With over 500 Alumni, it is the undergraduate business organization on campus with the largest alumni network.

Additional Information
INFORMATION ABOUT HOW TO GET INVOLVED WITH THIS ORGANIZATION IS FOUND HERE
Please check out berkeley-aba.com/apply to find all the information regarding our recruitment process. We encourage you to send any questions you might have to abapresident.berkeley@gmail.com!

The Armenian Students Association at the University of California, Berkeley was founded in 1976. Its mission since has been to foster a community where Armenian students can embrace their heritage and cultivate a spirit of appreciation towards Armenian history and culture through social, cultural, philanthropic, and professional events. 
ASA strives to foster and support its members, as well as enhance their college experience at Cal by allowing them to come together and connect with their roots, give back to their community, and celebrate their culture and history without any outside political affiliations and/or religious influence. 
 

Additional Information
INFORMATION ABOUT HOW TO GET INVOLVED WITH THIS ORGANIZATION IS FOUND HERE
To get involved in Cal ASA, please follow our Instagram account (@cal_asa) for updates about upcoming events, cultural development, and more ways to get involved in our link tree.

The Bangali Student Association at Berkeley's primary goal is to provide a space for those affiliated with or interested in the Bangali nation and culture to meet other members of the community and celebrate our language, customs and history. The BSA stands on the principles of diversity and inclusiveness for all community members, including both Bangladeshi and West Bengali/Indian students of all heritages, backgrounds, and religious affiliations. Aside from fostering a social and educational community for Bangali students, we strive to promote awareness and appreciation of Bangladesh and Bangali people in the general UC Berkeley community through the celebration of various social and cultural activities. We also seek to improve the quality of life of the Bangali people through contributions to nonprofit organizations and relief efforts that support education, health, climate resilience and economic development in Bangladesh.

column3: BATS - Association of Taiwanese Students at Berkeley

column6: "Bears for Palestine is a student organization designated to enlighten, educate and raise awareness about Palestinian culture, values and history; with an overall goal to share the Palestinian story with the campus community through activism."

The Berkeley Cambodian Student Association was originally founded to unite and support people who share an interest in Cambodia and Cambodian culture by fostering an appreciation of that culture.
Over the years, the Berkeley Cambodian Student Association has evolved to place greater emphasis upon recognizing and sharing the Cambodian-American experience with the UC Berkeley community. The Cambodian-American story is neither a relic of the past nor an inert fact of today. Thus, the Berkeley Cambodian Student Association aims to reclaim Cambodian cultural and political histories, create socially aware individuals, inspire leadership and service, and bridge generations. We aim to eliminate the invisibility of the Cambodian-American community and empower its members.

The Berkeley Student Leadership Academy is a series of engaging workshops and customized experiences that help undergraduate students develop leadership competencies. The workshops relate to leadership, engagement, and diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging (DEIB) on campus.
Registered participants will receive information about Berkeley Student Leadership Academy workshop series, specialized content, and access to mentorship and networking opportunities.
Visit the Berkeley Student Leadership Academy website for more information.

ASL at Berkeley aims to discuss and learn ASL, facilitate a community between hearing and Deaf communities, and to bring awareness to ableism and the issues that the Deaf community face. Our goal is to spread resources made by the Deaf and hard of hearing people to amplify their point of views on the issues they face. 
  If you are interested in bringing awareness to the issues the Deaf community faces, learning basic ASL then join us at one of our meetings. 
Fill out our Membership Form to keep up with meetings and events: https://forms.gle/ZtPQkccWFGWMAQaP6 
Follow us on instagram @aslatberkeley or join our discord (https://discord.gg/kuUqwJDUUQ).
This organization is a way for Armenian peers to connect with graduate students in thier intended pre-health fields while allowing them to make connections and enable them to network with others.

The purpose of the Asian American Association is to be at the forefront of uniting the Asian American community at Berkeley. AAA seeks to develop proactive and community-oriented leaders through a social, educational awareness, and service network. It enhances the quality of life at Berkeley through its focus on diversity appreciation.

APAPLA aims to provide guidance for Asian/Pacific Islander undergraduate students who are considering law school. We collaborate with the Asian American Law Journal (AALJ) at BerkeleyLaw to create a mentorship program for such students to explore the legal field and current API issues. We hope to continue cultivating a tight-knit community of pre-law API undergraduates, addressing inequities by hosting workshops and panels open to the community, as well as fundraise for local community organizations.

Additional Information
INFORMATION ABOUT HOW TO GET INVOLVED WITH THIS ORGANIZATION IS FOUND HERE
APAPLA runs recruitment every Fall semester for our fellowship program. Please check our social media for more information on the application process.

column3: Asian Pacific Islander Social Worker Caucus
column6:
The Asian and Pacific Islander Social Worker Caucus is a group of MSW students at UC Berkeley who self-identify as Asian and/or Pacific Islander (API). The purpose of the group is to promote networking and connection amongst emerging social workers of API backgrounds, as social services catered to the broad API community are so sparse and limited. API Caucus was also formed to create a safe holding space for API folks to build community with each other and reflect about their experiences in and out of the MSW program. API Caucus also serves to empower and uplift the voices of self-identified Asian and/or Pacific Islander students within a program that lacks representation of this community.

Additional Information
INFORMATION ABOUT HOW TO GET INVOLVED WITH THIS ORGANIZATION IS FOUND HERE
Email Sianne Susbilla at sssusbilla@berkeley.edu.

Melissa Landeros

column3: Black Engineering and Science Students Association
column6:
The Black Engineering and Science Student Association, also known as BESSA, is the University of California, Berkeley chapter for our parent organization the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE). We are a student run, non-profit organization that thrives on its members support, success, and commitment. We diligently work to provide academic and social support not only to our engineering and science community but to the entire Black community. In addition, we happily coordinate programs during the year to integrate our greater Bay Area community. Through these events, we are able to form and foster relationships that bridge the gap between the prestigious university and our close-but-distant community. This organization is a strong believer in academic excellence, personal growth, and a commitment to minority communities in and out of the classroom.
Our Objectives:
Retain, support, and increase the number of Black students within the College of Engineering (COE) as well as other science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields.
Introduce and develop the professional skills needed to succeed in the professional field.
Cultivate a network between students, professionals, and companies. 
Give our greater community access to our resources for support in areas that are lacking.

Believe it or not, about $9 out of every $10 you deposit into the bank is sent out to finance other programs and initiatives. At BMO, we know money deposited in a bank has the power to finance positive change. That's why we take everyday action to support activities that help protect the planet, improve people’s lives, and strengthen communities.  Please visit the branch in the ASUC Student Union, located on the lower level of MLK Hall.
  BMO Grant Program
All registered student organizations (RSOs) and recognized CalGreeks fraternities and sororities can apply for the BMO Student Organization Grant Program. The program provides funds for events, activities, projects, or programs that advance one of the Bank’s interest areas:
Sustainability
Financial Literacy
Women’s Empowerment
To be eligible, events, activities, projects, or programs must happen before May 15, 2024. No retroactive funding will be provided.
  HOW TO APPLY
Fill out the application form. The application deadline will be set for October. Applications will be reviewed by the Campus staff and BMO. BMO will determine what student organizations to fund and how much to fund them. Applicants will be notified of the award and amount by November.

column3: Black Graduate Engineering and Science Students
column6: The Black Graduate Engineering and Science Students Society is an academic and social support network that targets black graduate students and allies of black students within the University of California at Berkeley’s STEM disciplines. Through our programming, we help ensure that black graduate students can successfully contribute to both scientific research and the college’s learning environment.

The Black Graduate Student Association primarily seeks to build community amongst incoming and continuing graduate students of African descent across the African diaspora. We also seek to reach out and support other members of the Black community on the UC Berkeley campus and in the East Bay. BGSA's creation was sparked by graduate students' firm belief in the power of having an organized and active space for Black graduate students to know each other, support each other, and address various concerns of the Black community both inside and outside of the University. We also seek to build alliances and partnerships with other organizations across campus.

Alpha Chi Omega - Pi Chapter at UC Berkeley 
Real. Strong. Women.
Alpha Chi Omega was founded on October 15, 1885 by seven amazing women at DePauw University in Greencastle, Indiana. Anna Allen, Olive Burnett, Bertha Denison, Amy DuBois, Nellie Gamble, Bessie Grooms, and Estelle Leonard founded Alpha Chi. It was the first, and most likely last, musical fraternity. The group was thus named Alpha, meaning first, and Omega, meaning last, using Chi as a link. The purpose of Alpha Chi Omega was to provide the advancement of the intellectual, social, and moral culture of its members. The Berkeley AXO Pi Chapter was founded on May 7, 1909.
Visit us on social media!
Website
Facebook
Instagram
Tumblr
National Website

column6: Bears for Financial Success is a peer-to-peer financial wellness program housed in the Financial Aid and Scholarships Office at UC Berkeley. We offer workshops and one-on-one appointments to help students manage their personal finances in college and beyond.

The Berkeley Art Studio offers classes in ceramics, design, painting, drawing, and photography. The Studio has a rich history of providing quality art instruction for our members through our staff of professional artists. The Berkeley Art Studio is a welcoming place for students and artists at various skill levels. Berkeley Art Studio registration is open to the entire community as well as UC Students, Faculty, and Staff.
Over it's 40 year history the Berkeley Art Studio has proven to be more than just a space, but a community of artists committed to their craft.

Keep up with Alpha Delta Pi on our social media pages!
Find us on Instagram @caladpi and on our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/UC-Berkeley-Alpha-Delta-Pi-132391421981/?fref=ts
  Alpha Delta Pi was founded by Eugenia Tucker in 1851 at the Wesleyan Female College in Macon Georgia. It holds the distinction of being the first secret society for women, and therefore the foundation of the entire sorority system, hence our motto- First, Finest, Forever.
  Psi Chapter of ADPi was founded in Berkeley in 1913- the 23rd national chapter to be established. In 1931, the chapter purchased our current home, 2400 Piedmont Ave. The house was formerly the summer home of notable Bay Area heiress Phoebe Hearst, and was recognized immediately as the showplace of the campus.
Since then, the mansion has had several modern conveniences added on, but it still retains its original character. It serves as a charming home to almost sixty girls.
  With its location on Channing circle, Psi chapter of Alpha Delta Pi lies at the very heart of the present-day Greek community.

column3:
C
Campus Dept | Berkeley Language Center

column6:
Since its founding over a century ago, Alpha Kappa Alpha’s mission has been to cultivate and encourage high scholastic and ethical standards, to promote unity and friendship among college women, to study and help alleviate problems concerning girls and women in order to improve their social stature, to maintain a progressive interest in college life, and to be of “Service to All Mankind.”
Rho Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated was chartered at the University of California, Berkeley on August 21, 1921 by 6 women under the leadership of Soror Ida Louise Jackson. With the chartering of Rho Chapter, the landmark expansion of the sorority to the West Coast began. Rho women have been striving to fulfill Ida’s dream of nothing short of excellence for the chapter. The women of Rho exemplify the Alpha Kappa Alpha woman through their professional and personal development, community service, sisterhood, and commitment to academic excellence at Cal and beyond.

Hello everyone! 
If you want to know more about our chapter, please visit our Instagram @calalphaphi or feel free to reach out to our Chapter President, Sydney Roberts, at calalphaphipresident@gmail.com!

This diverse group of women supports and celebrates individual pursuits and interests while remaining united under the common bonds of the fraternity. In joining Chi Omega, our members enrich their college experience by growing as individuals, while also growing together as a sisterhood. Being a part of Chi Omega at Cal means you are among women who inspire you daily and encourage you to be the best you can be. Each woman in our chapter is unique, beautiful, and accomplished in her own way.
Contact our President, Julia, at calchiomegapresident@gmail.com, or our Recruitment Chair, Elle, at calxorecruitment@gmail.com for more information.  Go Bears, go Greek, go Chi O!
  Please visit our website, www.calchiomega.com, our Instagram (@calchiomega), or our Facebook (UC Berkeley Chi Omega) for more information!

Our founders envisioned a women’s fraternity that would inspire the ideals of truth, self-sacrifice and friendship. Tri Delta’s Purpose keeps those values alive with our members today.
LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT
Whether serving as officers or participating in a chapter’s educational programming, our members are offered the support and opportunity to grow as leaders. There are four areas of growth that Tri Delta’s leadership education focuses on: organizational growth, intrapersonal growth, interpersonal growth and professional growth. Throughout the collegiate experience, Tri Delta’s members will attain core competencies and skill development in each of these areas.
SCHOLARSHIP
Tri Delta understands that its members are college women first, and part of Tri Delta’s Purpose is to broaden the moral and intellectual lives of members. Whether by providing scholarship funds through the Foundation to assist with educational costs, or by promoting academic success through a chapter’s Academic Excellence Initiative, Tri Delta offers encouragement and support to collegiate members as they pursue academic achievement.
PHILANTHROPY
Members of Tri Delta have a long history of supporting children’s cancer charities at the local level with local children’s hospitals and at the national level with our philanthropic partner, St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital. The Fraternity and its chapters also consistently provide opportunities to raise funds to support the Tri Delta Foundation. This emphasis on philanthropy and service allows our members to develop qualities of unselfish leadership and assume the highest responsibilities of college women.
MEMBER DEVELOPMENT
As part of the collegiate chapter experience, Tri Delta members will participate in multi-dimensional – “3D” – educational and leadership programs designed to inspire them to Live, Learn and Lead in accordance with Tri Delta’s Purpose. Over the course of the collegiate experience, Tri Deltas enjoy a host of opportunities for personal growth and development while building lifelong friendships.

Delta Gamma offers women of all ages a rich heritage baded upon the ideals of personal integrity, philanthropy, intellectual honesty and above all, Doing Good. Our primary purpose is to foster ideals of friendship, promote educational and cultural interests, create a true sense of social responsibility, and develop the finest qualities of character.
Through our membership, we have all made close and lasting friendships, gained a widespread support system, and found a second home. DG offers a study buddy, a friend with whom to go on any adventure, and a confidant. As DGs, we applaud each other's successes, and help each other through individual struggles. Our chapter is made up of women of diverse individual talents, goals, and achievements brought together by a commitment to unwavering and unconditional friendship
The Delta Gamma Foundation fosters lifetime enrichment for members, promotes Service for Sight, and partners with the Fraternity to ensure the future of our sisterhood.
Service for Sight has been at the heart of Delta Gamma’s philanthropic mission since 1936. The Delta Gamma Foundation has given over $2,800,000 in Service for Sight grants to organizations and schools that share the Foundation’s mission: to promote sight preservation and assistance to children and adults who are blind or visually impaired.
Service for Sight supports the four schools founded by Delta Gammas for the visually impaired and other North American organizations that promote sight preservation and provide assistance to children and adults who are blind or visually impaired. This philanthropy has been at the heart of the Delta Gamma mission since 1936 when a member who was blind, Ruth Billow, Eta-Akron, petitioned members to adopt "Aid to the Blind" as our official philanthropy.

Gamma Phi Beta is an International Sorority dedicated to helping women realize their full potential. Of course, you will make lifelong friends here – and in the future after college. But it’s here you will have the opportunity for individual growth through academic excellence, leadership development, social enrichment and philanthropic involvement that will take you wherever you want to go with your life. 

We believe that the result of contribution to community, developing moral and ethical integrity in all aspects of life, and striving for excellence in all levels of your endeavors are elements that one learns as a part of sorority life. Being part of a social organization is also an important "fun" aspect of college life. 

Becoming self-reliant, looking inward toward sisterhood for support and celebrating your individualism are benefits not found in many other organizations.

Every member is selected to life membership. This choice of membership does not relate simply to one college campus or community, for every member belongs to the International Sorority and enjoys a member’s rights, privileges and responsibilities wherever she may live, study, work or travel. As a member, you have the opportunity to be a part of a sisterhood that has blossomed from Four Founders to over 140,000 members with 114 collegiate chapters and 156 alumnae chapters.

Alpha Phi Alpha (ΑΦΑ) is the first Black, inter-collegiate Greek-lettered fraternity. It was founded on December 4, 1906 at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York. Its founders are known as the "Seven Jewels". It employs an icon from Ancient Egypt, the Great Sphinx of Giza, as its symbol. Its aims are "manly deeds, scholarship, and love for all mankind," and its motto is First of All, Servants of All, We Shall Transcend All.
Alpha Phi Alpha evolved into primarily a service organization and provided leadership and service during the Great Depression, World Wars, and Civil Rights Movements. It addresses social issues such as apartheid, AIDS, urban housing, and other economic, cultural, and political issues of interest to people of color. The Martin Luther King, Jr. National Memorial and World Policy Council are programs of Alpha Phi Alpha. It also conducts philanthropic programming initiatives with March of Dimes, Head Start, Boy Scouts of America, and Big Brothers Big Sisters of America.
Members of Alpha Phi Alpha include Jamaican Prime Minister Norman Manley, Nobel Prize winner Martin Luther King, Jr., Olympian Jesse Owens,Justice Thurgood Marshall, United Nations Ambassador Andrew Young, singer Lionel Richie and Atlanta mayor Maynard Jackson.

Kappa Alpha Theta, the first Greek letter fraternity among women, was founded in 1870 by Bettie Locke Hamilton, Alice Allen Brant, Bettie Tipton Lindsey, and Hannah Finch Shaw. Theta has over 170 chapters with houses throughout the United States and Canada. More than 250,000 women have been initiated into Kappa Alpha Theta, forming strong friendships in chapters from all over, holding the sisterhood strong. The Omega Chapter was founded at University of California, Berkeley in 1890. Our Chapter occupied the first women's chapter house built by Omega sister Julia Morgan, the first woman to study architecture at the Ecole de Beaux Arts in Paris. 
  Kappa Alpha Theta is proud to be national supporters of Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA). CASA is an organization that provides mentors for abused, abandoned and neglected children. These mentors establish close bonds with the children as they interact one-on-one and serve as a voice for the children during the judicial process.
The Omega chapter of Kappa AlphaTheta supports CASA in a number of ways including donations from our annual philanthropic fundraising events, Theta Dodgeball and Cafe Casa (our famous Theta Brunch held at our beautiful Theta home, open to the Berkeley community).
  For any questions regarding Recruitment or Letters of Reference, please contact our Vice President of Membership at omegathetacro@gmail.com.

Aion interest group is an officially recognized interest group for an Asian Interest Sorority at the University of California, Berkeley. We are striving to bring this Asian-Interest sorority to campus. We want our group to foster long-lasting relationships and build our community through breast cancer and mental health awareness, leadership, scholarship, and Asian awareness. 
Our pillars are:
Leadership
Scholarship
Community
Philanthropy (Breast Cancer Awareness, Mental Health Awareness)
Asian Awareness

Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Incorporated founded on January 13th, 1913 on the campus of Howard University, is a public service organization based on the principles of sisterhood, scholarship, and service; committed to the constructive development of its members and to service of the Black community.
Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc., Kappa Chapter was chartered on the campus of the University of California, Berkeley on February 21, 1921. It is the first historically Black Greek Letter Organization at the University of California, Berkeley, and the first historically Black sorority chartered west of the Rocky Mountains. For more than 100 years, this public service organization has served this campus, the Bay Area, and the state of California.

The Gamma Alpha Chapter of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Incorporated was chartered October 23, 1947, which now spans the campuses of the University of California, Berkeley, San Francisco State University, and the University of San Francisco.

University of California, Berkeley chapter of Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc.

On Friday evening, November 17, 1911, three Howard University undergraduate students, with the assistance of their faculty adviser, gave birth to the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. This event occurred in the office of biology Professor Ernest E. Just, the faculty adviser, in the Science Hall (now known as Thirkield Hall). The three liberal arts students were Edgar A. Love, Oscar J. Cooper and Frank Coleman. From the initials of the Greek phrase meaning "Friendship is Essential to the Soul," the name Omega Psi Phi was derived. The phrase was selected as the motto. Manhood, Scholarship, Perseverance and Uplift were adopted as cardinal principles.

Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. was founded on November 12, 1922 on the campus of Butler University in Indianapolis, Indiana by seven accomplished community-driven young educators. They believed that the self-respect, knowledge and discipline gained through study would help individuals to recognize their duty and responsibility for their society. Founded on the precept of education, Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc., as a leading national service organization, continues to meet the challenges of the day, promoting and encouraging high scholastic attainment, and continues to grow through Sisterhood, Scholarship and Service.

Alpha Epsilon Omega, established at the University of California Berkeley in August 2022, holds a mission centered around uniting students dedicated to fostering cultural stimulation on campus. This dedication aims to kindle interest in the Armenian language, history, and culture, all while upholding rigorous standards of academic excellence. The fraternity's objective revolves around nurturing a community where brothers wholeheartedly embrace their culture and heritage through philanthropic, cultural, and professional events. AEΩ has established and will continue fostering a supportive network for its members, contributing significantly to academic and social success.

Unity of Strength and Knowledge | Գիտության եվ Հզորության Միություն

Acacia Fraternity was founded in 1904 at University of Michigan, Ann Arbor on May 12th. The California chapter was founded 1905, having the distinction of being one of the oldest operating chapters in the National organization.
However, "an organization is not necessarily good because it is old, but old because it is good." There are a lot of great fraternities out there, and only you can decide which one is right for you. Here are a few reasons why Acacia Fraternity should be on your short list.
Acacia Emphasizes Academic Achievement
Academic achievement should be the first and foremost priority of all university students. It is also central to the mission of Acacia Fraternity, whose chapters stress academics above all else. Moreover, the Acacia Fraternity Foundation assists deserving Acacians with cash scholarships — over $250,000 in scholarships and educational grants were awarded by the foundation during the 2007-2008 academic year alone.
Acacia Develops Leaders
Acacia Fraternity is dedicated to building leaders by providing a wealth of leadership opportunities for our members. From social issues to academic, business to philanthropy, the Acacians of today are the leaders of tomorrow. Click here to view a list of prominent Acacians.
Acacians Help Better the Communities in Which We Reside
Our motto is "Human Service," and we take it very seriously. As member of Acacia Fraternity you will have ongoing opportunities, through structured community service programs, to make a difference in the lives of those in need.
Acacians Value Fitness
Members of Acacia are encouraged to participate in intramural sports, a system in which athletes of all caliber find camaraderie and physical challenge. Whatever the sport, and whatever your skill level, as a member of Acacia you will always have a place on the team.
Acacians Know How to Have Fun
Forget the "Animal House" stereotype of reckless partying and irresponsible behavior. Acacia's policy is that each chapter maintains a fun yet responsible social policy that promotes responsible choices and the dignity of every individual as well as zero tolerance for illegal activities.

Aero Assist is the Graduate Student Organization for the Gambaro Graduate School of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AAE). 
The goal of Aero Assist is to enhance graduate student experience in the department by providing opportunities for social, athletic, academic, and professional involvement, and to represent AAE graduate students to the department and the university.
Typical activities conducted by Aero Assist include: 
• Mentorship Program
• Sport Activities (ultimate, soccer, football, softball, chess, including pick-up games)
• Study Break Regular Socials
• Other socials (tailgate picnic, corn maze)
• Professional Development Seminars
• Research Symposium Series (co-organized with RSS committee)
• USAF Museum Trip to Dayton, OH
We are very excited to be involved in AAE graduate student life and provide the students with various activities and involvement opportunities. Check out our Facebook page to see what's happening at the present time as well as posts and photos form the past events!

The Afghan Student Association works to showcase Afghan culture and educate the Purdue community about Afghanistan.

Office Hours:
Krach 2nd Floor/Space 2 | M: 2-4pm, T: 4-6pm, W: 3-4pm, Th: 3-5pm
  The African Students' Association is an independent, non-profit, non-sectarian, sociocultural and educational student organization. 
Preambles
We the African students of Purdue University, in order to form a more perfect union, establish mutual understanding, provide for the common good, promote culture and stronger ties with various students, and secure the blessings of freedom to ourselves, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the African Student Association.
The Aims of the Association shall be:
1. To consolidate and promote mutual understanding among the African Students.
2. To promote a better mutual understanding and stronger ties with the American community.
3. To Promote understanding with students and other student organization in and around the University.
4. To act as liaison between the African Students of the University and other African Students organizations outside. 
5. We aim to introduce our diverse culture to the Purdue community through a myriad of events and ourselves learn from the native culture(s)

Bring the AgEcon student body together; to promote academic and social communication among all AgEcon graduate students; to provide a forum in which AgEcon graduate students can voice their concerns and expectations; and to act as a liaison.

The purpose of this organization, All For Autism, is to bring students and faculty from every area of campus together to work towards raising awareness of Autism on campus and create a safe space where neurodiverse individuals can learn and share their experiences.
All for Autism promotes furthering awareness of Autism within the Lafayette and West Lafayette community. We also aim to create a space where individuals can learn from others, share personal experiences, and educate themselves on the subject.

The Allergenic Foodie Club is made for anyone with allergies or anyone who would like to learn more about them. It is a space for people with allergies to support each other, learn about cooking alternatives, learn about allergy self-advocacy, educate others about allergies, and most importantly, bond over food that is safe to eat.

ALPFA's purpose is to empower and develop Latino men and women as leaders of character for the nation in every sector of the global economy. Our organization hosts professional development events with partner companies to set our members up for success in their future careers. We aim to build a close-knit community among all our members through social events. 
Everyone is welcome to join!

We are a roller skating and rollerblading club! The goal is to create a community of people who enjoy skating. Those who don't know how to skate but would like to learn are more than welcome to join (we are currently building an equipment inventory and may be able to lend you some supplies). We have official meetings once a month on Thursday evenings, 7:00 PM. Club activities include skating around campus together, visits to the local roller rink, and our annual end-of-year ice skating session at Tapawingo Park! We are a group that is just looking to make friends and enjoy our mutual hobby.

We are a casual group of acrobats who meet weekly to practice partner acrobatics. We are committed to fostering a safe and supportive environment and love to introduce newcomers to acrobatic yoga. We work together to lift each other to new heights, safely stepping out of our comfort zones to grow!

You do not need any experience or equipment to start airsoft with us! Our goal is to minimize the barrier to entry for airsoft as much as possible.
  The Purdue Airsoft Club is dedicated to promoting the sport of airsoft within the Purdue community and upholding values such as teamwork, integrity and fitness. All club members have FREE access to over $10,000 in high quality airsoft guns, tactical gear, uniforms, safety gear, and other equipment such as radios for team communication. BBs are provided for free. All members get free equipment "rentals". Additionally, we provide an off-campus storage unit for all personal airsoft guns, as they cannot be stored on campus per Purdue rules. Everyone in the club loves the sport of airsoft, and we want to share it with as many people as possible!
  For the 2023 Spring semester, we will attend at least 4 events including a 2.5 day event which may have up to 400 players. Regular events primarily consist of 1-day "open-play"s at local fields, and more events may be organized. Most club events require members to pay the field/event fee (normally around $30 for the day), but larger, more cost-prohibitive events, are often club-funded. Carpools and equipment rentals are organized through the club Discord.
  Discord is our main form of communication. We coordinate events and answer questions on the discord server.
Discord

- Free BBs at all club events
- Free equipment rentals (over $10,00 worth of equipment)
- Free off-campus storage for personal airsoft gear
- Organized club events (carpools, event discovery, etc)
- A great group of people willing to help out anyone!

With a lot of ideas within the group but starting small, our focus for this semester is to 1. make sure that all incoming students who have interest in the club can find the club as we promote the club around Purdue 2. set up frequent meetings, both informal and formal ones, to work on developing the club and making it a bigger community 3. set up events with strong involvement with other cultural clubs and with everyone here at Purdue, to promote our values and traditions, as well as showing what defines us 4. establish connections both within and outside of Purdue, with other students, professors, and professionals, having guests and encouraging other Argentinians and Uruguayans to be part of this initiative
The Mission of Army ROTC (Reserve Officer Training Corps) is to train and prepare the future officers of the United States Army for commissioning and a career in the Army.

Asha for Education is a secular organization dedicated to change in India by focusing on basic education in the belief that education is a critical requisite for socio-economic change. For more details please check http://www.ashanet.org/purdue/
In keeping with this focus, our volunteers are involved with and support projects that are secular and have an education-related component to them. The objectives of this group are:
To provide education to underprivileged children in India.
To encourage the formation of various local groups across the world to reach out to larger sections of the population.
To support and cooperate with persons and groups already engaged in similar activities.
To raise the required human and other resources to achieve the group objectives.
To provide opportunities to individuals living outside India who wish to participate in Asha activities in India.
To address, whenever possible, other issues affecting human life such as health care, environment, socio-economic aspects and women's issues.

Association of Zamorano Alumni (AZA) is a nonprofit student organization. Zamorano is a panamerican agricultural university located in Honduras and has students for most Latin American countries. It offers degrees in Food Science and Technology, Agribusiness, Environmental and Socio-economic development and Agronomy. AZA's mission is to support and advance the professional development of current Zamorano students that come to Purdue as visiting scholars and alumni that begin graduate studies or obtain research scholar positions at Purdue. AZA offers support in academic, social and research activities at Purdue University. It also aids as a link between Zamorano faculty members.

The aim of the club is to bring together all levels of badminton players at Purdue University by offering a healthy environment for competitive badminton.

The Aerial Robotics Team at Purdue (PART) manages a portfolio of Uninhabited Aerial System (UAS)
design projects. It was formally a committee under the Purdue IEEE Student Branch. The mission of
the Purdue Aerial Robotics Team is to mature students into principled industry leaders for their postundergraduate careers by executing a comprehensive industry standard approach to interdisciplinary design, prototyping, and systems engineering. Currently, PART designs, builds, and tests a two-vehicle system from the ground up each year to compete in an international competition. PART’s Uninhabited Aerial
System (UAS) air-drops an Uninhabited Ground Vehicle (UGV), both of which will complete a series of
tasks demonstrating their ability to operate and navigate autonomously while performing remote sensing
missions representative of real-world problems. PART also engages in multidisciplinary research in the
areas of collision avoidance, sensor development, and Vertical Takeoff and Landing (VTOL) aircraft.

Alpha Eta Rho is an internationally recognized Professional Aviation Fraternity aimed to provide its members with an enriched experience in Aviation. We facilitate professionalism, mentorship, and industry connections with the goal of improving the transition between students and industry.
Members of Alpha Eta Rho have the opportunity to participate in various events aimed at providing a better aviation experience. We often take trips to various locations such as major airports, company headquarters, and others. As a club we also bring in speakers from the industry to give us their perspective and help us jump-start our careers. We also have a social aspect, as we are brothers and friends to each other.

Founded in 1928, the original purpose of the American Association of Airport Executives (AAAE) was to represent airport management throughout the United States. 85 years later, AAAE's primary goals remain heavily involved with representing airport management personnel at public use airport nationwide, particularly assisting them in fulfilling their responsibilities to the airports and communities they serve.
The purpose of this student chapter of AAAE is to foster the development of aviation professionals through active engagement in opportunities such as professional networking, facility tours, and the recruitment of guest speakers to speak to the organization. Student chapter members are not actively engaged in airport management, but they are affiliated with Purdue University, which has a direct interest in airport management through the Department of Aviation Technology.

Welcome to the Purdue Chapter of the American Institute of Aeronautics & Astronautics!
  The purpose of Purdue AIAA is to:
     1) Serve within its locality the purposes and program of the national AIAA
     2) Create awareness of National AIAA conferences and opportunities.
     3) Foster faculty-student relations through social and academic projects.
     4) Provide networking opportunities through industry contracts.
     5) Provide social activities for AIAA members to network with each other.

The Autonomous Robotics Club of Purdue was was created to design and build autonomous robotic systems for Purdue's campus.
We welcome new members of any skill level and background. ARC provides an environment for members to learn about topics such as state estimation, control algorithms, and machine learning. New members have opportunities for leadership early on and can gain in-depth experience working on projects that interest them. ARC projects typically include a mix of hardware and software design.
For more information, see our website: https://www.purduearc.com/
Join our Discord server! https://discord.gg/ddkzfD2cyu

Aviation Ambassadors lead tours and information sessions of the department facilities for prospective students and their families, along with other aviation executives, local schools, and future faculty. We represent the School of Aviation and Transportation Technology by traveling to local schools, fly-ins, airshows, college fairs, and other public or industry-related events. Members get the opportunity to attend trips and take tours to airline or corporate aviation facilities around the midwest with opportunities for networking and practice with public-speaking to large groups on a regular basis.

The council represents and supports graduate students in the School of Aviation and Transportation Technology (SATT). The council aims to provide graduate students with opportunities and resources that will facilitate research and academic achievement in the graduate program. Activities, workshops, and seminars are planned to help build camaraderie among graduate students and networking possibilities in the aviation industry.  AGC is committed to serving both faculty and staff while supporting other collegiate aviation organizations and industry partners.

Agricultural Communicators of Tomorrow (ACT) is a nationwide preprofessional organization for university students who are interested in the field of communication related to the agricultural sciences.
  Membership in the organization is open to any major. Many members are pursuing careers in agricultural public relations, advertising, journalism, or organizational communications, but any student with an interest in agriculture and communication may join.
    The Mission of National ACT is to build relationships among agricultural communication professionals and college students and faculty, to provide professional and academic development for members and to promote agriculture through communications efforts.

The Association for Women in Communications (AWC) is a professional organization that champions the advancement of women across all communication disciplines by recognizing excellence, promoting leadership and positioning its members at the forefront of the evolving communication era.

The Purdue Chapter of AWC offers a welcoming place for students to connect, grow and succeed. We are one of the nation’s oldest professional communications organizations. Anyone interested in the studying or pursuing a career in the field of communication is encouraged to join AWC! We are a diverse organization that serves the broad spectrum of the communication industry including advertising, public relations, marketing, graphic design, film, print and broadcast journalism, organizational communication, human resources, among others. 

As a member of AWC you’ll have access to networking opportunities, scholarships, internship and job postings, and have the chance to build and strengthen your resume and portfolio with hands on experience at chapter meetings, special events, fundraisers and philanthropies. Furthermore, you’ll build meaningful, long lasting relationships with other members and professionals, who share common interests and goals. The Purdue Chapter is about developing the young professional woman. 
Connect and network with Purdue students and communication professionals 
Meaningful career development techniques that will help you build your professional profile
Gain study, professional, and social support from fellow communication students
Interactive Chapter meetings that provide enriching and inspiring information 
Minimal time requirements means you decide how much you want to be involved
Opportunity to develop leadership skills and experience
Access to special scholarship opportunities
Be part of an international organization with a special focus on women’s issues
Strengthen your resume and portfolio through various workshops
Access to many different internship/job and networking opportunities
The AWC Purdue Chapter offers a welcoming place for communication students to connect, grow, and succeed. 
    Mission:  The Association for Women in Communications is a professional organization that champions the advancement of women across all communication disciplines by recognizing excellence, promoting leadership, and positioning its members at the forefront of the evolving communication era.

Excalibur Club's purpose is to serve the residents of Wiley Hall and create an active and positive community to impact University Residences.
Mission Statement: We exist to enhance the residential life experience and prolonged stay of all residents of Wiley Hall by presenting them with opportunities to grow within their communities, offer them unique channels of leadership development, and to instill in them a sense of power, duty, and responsibility towards their hall.

The Purdue Amateur Radio Club is a ham radio club for the students of Purdue and for the amateur radio operators of the Lafayette area. The club is based out of the West tower of the Purdue Memorial Union, in room 370. Here, members can talk to other ham radio operators around the world with high frequency (HF) radios, work on their projects with club equipment, rest between classes, and collaborate with other members. The club also partners with several organizations around campus including the weather balloon team, the student radio station WCCR, the Association for Mechanical Engineering Technologists (AMET), the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), and others.

Engineering and technology students will be able to apply knowledge gained in the classroom to the real world through the clubs' projects and operation. The school year is saturated with ham radio contests and social events that members are encouraged to participate in. By joining W9YB, students will become a part of a legacy which has changed the face of mondern radio communication, and may very possibly make a few friends along the way.
  Club Facility: PMU 370, Purdue Memorial Union
Mailbox: Box 507, Stewart Center

Purdue Han Culture Association is a student organization that focuses on Chinese Han region culture (the major part of Chinese culture). Weekly meetings are held for discussion on Han culture-related topics. Members are encouraged to share their thoughts on topics that include but not limited to traditional Han clothing, food, tea culture, ancient poetry, music, and art. DIY activities are held occasionally, where members get to make hairpins, herbal perfume bags, or other traditional items on their own. We aim to create a casual, and harmonious atmosphere for members to learn and make friends. For more information, feel free to email lin1511@purdue.edu.

Purdue Vinyl Club is an organization for anybody interested in vinyl records or music in general! The aim of this organization is to create an environment for people to discuss, share, and enjoy their passion for music and vinyl records. The club will be devoted to maintaining and sharing interest in the vinyl record format, as well as educating newcomers about physical music collection.
We have a Discord server where you can keep up with the latest announcements, talk to members outside of meetings, and participate in album listening parties: https://discord.gg/8qp5fX4hsv
Please ask on the Discord, or email purduevinylclub@gmail.com / eoberoi@purdue.edu for more information about meeting times!

The Residence Hall Association at Purdue University is composed of the Residence Hall Senate, with two representatives from each hall elected by their peers to speak and vote on their behalf. In the Senate, senators draft legislation, talk about issues, collaborate with their peers from other halls, and listen to constituent issues. 
RHA communicates with various departments of Purdue University, such as University Residences, and Purdue Dining and Catering, in order to represent student interest, as well as represents the Purdue University Residential Community on the National and International scale as a part of National Association of College and University Residence Halls (NACURH). 
RHA is also committed to giving back to the residential community by hosting events, sponsoring activities for the community, and engaging with our fellow students.
  Website: https://rha-resources.weebly.com/

column3: Boiler ATA Martial Arts of Purdue
column6:
We are a club under the American Taekwondo Association that practices Songahm Taekwondo. Saturday trainings occur from 10:00-11:30 and focus on Traditional Forms, Weapons Forms, Self-Defense, and General Fitness. 
  Meetings during the week occur Monday through Thursday at McFall's Black Belt Academy.
White-Green belt forms: 6:00-6:45pm
Sparing: 6:45-7:15pm
Purple+ forms: 7:15-8:00pm

Make friends, then beat them up!
At Boiler Blade, we host and run a full contact, free to play, medieval combat sport. Battle games occur on campus at Krach lawn every Saturday from 2pm to 6pm. We play games such as capture the flag, team deathmatch, and more!
We use foam weapons, such as swords, shields, spears, bows, and axes. For new fighters, we have loaner weapons available for use. We host build sessions for those interested in having their own customized weapons. We also have training sessions for those who want to get better.
Our rule sets are based on the foam combat sports Dagorhir and Belegarth. We also participate in outside events in the foam fighting community such as Oktoberfest, War, Wolfpack Opener, and more. It's great for bonding, teambuilding, and practice against those outside of our field. On occasion we also host semesterly tournaments with prizes!
So come and join Boiler Blade! Make friends or bring them, team up with them or fight them! See our trebuchet launch! And most importantly, have fun!
Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/PC8XHDTGNG
Instagram :https://www.instagram.com/boilerblade/

The C. Richard Petticrew Forum is Purdue’s competitive speech and debate team. The Forum is named after the late C. Richard Petticrew, a Purdue alumni whose generous endowment provides the lion’s share of the team’s operating budget.
The Petticrew Forum competes in interpretative, limited preparation, and general address individual speaking events (IEs), as well as in policy debate. The team is a member of the American Forensics Association (AFA), the National Forensics Association (NFA), and the National Debate Tournament (NDT).
Members of the team practice an average of four hours each week and compete in an average of four speech and debate tournaments each semester. Travel, lodging, and registration expenses associated with these competitions are subsidized by the team – though students are prioritized for travel on the basis of their prior competitive success.
Students interested in joining the Petticrew Forum should contact the team’s head coach, Jim Schultz, at  Schul214@purdue.edu. In your email, please mention (a) your year and major, (b) your prior experience in competitive speech and debate activities, (c) whether you’re interested in competing in IEs or policy debate, and (d) any other information that you think might be pertinent (e.g., what specific IEs you’d like to compete in, or what your speaking positions are, etc.).
The Petticrew Forum does not accept ‘walk-ons’ throughout the course of the academic year, as this disrupts our practice and competition schedule. Those interested in joining the team are strongly encouraged to contact the team’s coach before the start of the fall semester so that they can be made aware of the team’s policies and expectations.

The Club Sports program operates under Recreation & Wellness at Purdue University.  Club Sports recognizes 32 unique clubs who vary greatly in activity and competition level. Some of our clubs compete on a regional and national level, while others form for the sole purpose of getting together to practice their sport or skill.  Club Sports are a great way to learn a new sport, continue to play a sport competitively that you love, and to meet new friends!

Please consult our website or instagram for announcements and updates.
Website
Instagram
Purpose:
Club Tennis is designed for avid tennis players who are looking to continue with the sport throughout their college years. Our practices include a wide variety of drills and match play.
Practices:
-We practice 4 times a week 6-8 PM outside at Schwartz Tennis Center until October Break.
-After October Break, we practice Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays from 10-12PM and Sundays 8:30-10 PM indoors at Schwartz Tennis Center. 
-After Spring Break, we move back outdoors to the same times as the fall semester.
- At practice we do drills and matchplay against each other.
  Travel Team:
There is a Travel Team with around 4 boys and 4 girls that travels all over the midwest to compete against other schools. In previous years the travel team has qualified for nationals (Placing 8th in 2023)!
  Joining:
We hold tryouts during the second week of classes every semester. Info on social media!
In order to join club tennis, you come to the practices that work best with your schedule, and pay the dues before requesting to join on boiler link. Club tennis dues are $150 per semester which covers court time and tennis balls. The travel team pays additional fees to help cover travel expenses.  
Come out and have fun playing the sport you love while meeting lots of new people!
Please contact purdueclubtennis@gmail.com with any questions.

We are a cricket-centric organization and host social events focused on cricket lovers getting to know one another. Our cricket tournament hosted every semester is open to everyone interested in the game, irrespective of their expertise in it. So, whether you are an avid player of the game, or want to try it out for the first time, there is a spot for you with us. We also organize watch parties, fundraisers, and celebrations for major South Asian festivals. We hope that this will enable people from different backgrounds to play and interact with one another and boost Purdue’s cultural diversity. We hope to spread key messages like unity, sportsmanship, and teamwork through cricket and our events.

The official club for cricket at Purdue University. We welcome all Purdue students, staff, and faculty from all nationalities and walks of life. Whether you are an experienced player, or just want to learn the game, we are the team to join. Throughout the summer, Purdue Cricket Club participates in the MidWest Cricket Tournament (MCT-35), a league that hosts about 60 teams from the MidWest area for leather ball cricket. Practices are typically Tuesdays and Thursdays at 5:45 PM, with matches on most weekends from May through September. During Fall and Spring semesters, we conduct Indoor Cricket League (ICL) on the Purdue campus hosting about 10 teams and around 120 participants every semester. Please get in touch with us for more information.
