column3: "AQUAE" The Purdue Student chapter of AWWA/IWEA
column6:
AQUAE has a main objective to cluster students interested in water issues. There is an emphasis on encouraging students to pursue academic or professional careers that address water related problems. Today, almost half of the world's workers - 1.5 billion people - work in water related sectors, and nearly all jobs depend on water or ensure its safe delivery. As Purdue students, we are willing to have a positive impact on the sector. By being a student chapter of the most prestige water professional association AWWA (American Water Works Association) and IWEA (Indiana Water Environment Association) it would be possible to provide leadership and networking opportunities to Purdue students.
The aim of the chapter is to promote among Purdue student the passion for water issues and the potential of developing a career as a researcher or professional on the water sector.
This organization is a student chapter of the Indiana American Water Works Association and the Indiana Water Environment Association. AWWA and IWEA are members of the Water Environment Federation.
  Possible Related Activities
Organize talks by students or faculty.
Sponsor lectures by guest speakers.
Host lunch discussions on the training students need for careers in water.
Organize team projects such as undergraduate competitions.
Host social functions (lunches, dinners, movie nights, picnics).
Tours of water treatment facilities, utilities, etc.
Field trips to AWWA/WEA conferences and events.
Host interdisciplinary activities with other Association on campus
Set up chapter website.
Mentor lunches.
Establish an internship or job shadow program
Volunteer activities focus on local community’s water issues

The purpose of the Purdue Accounting Association is to help students develop a better understanding of the accounting profession and to prepare them for the job search process. The club also provides a social setting for Purdue students to expand their educational and social boundaries through peer interaction, professional engagements and community service.
  If you want to be up-to-date about the events and opportunities: join our GroupMe for daily updates; check out our website here; and join us here on BoilerLink to be on the mailing list. If you have any questions, send an email to our Secretary at PAAattendance@gmail.com. We encourage anyone with an interest in accounting to get involved and be an active member!

ACM (Association for Computing Machinery) at Purdue is an organization for connecting students, faculty and companies for the betterment of the computing community. As a representative of one the world's most influential computing organizations, we provide academic resources, forums for the spreading of ideas, and communities for technological discovery and growth.
  To support a multitude of interests, ACM is divided into several sub-groups, called Special Interest Groups (SIGs). Here’s our current list of them:
SIGBots (Robotics)
SIGAPP (App Design)
SIGGD (Game Design)
In these groups, students get the chance to develop technologies and applications in a team environment that has a meaningful impact in a wide variety of places. 
  Some of the great things that have come out of Purdue ACM include PROS (an open source robotics operating system used by over 21 thousand users for VEX micro-controllers), 7 unique and complex independent games since 2011, and the Official Purdue App.
  TLDR: We make cool stuff and have fun doing it, so check us out! We accept all majors!
Learn more at: https://acm.cs.purdue.edu/
You can ask us questions at: https://discord.gg/2pEsxdA

Purdue University ACM SIGGRAPH Chapter is a student chapter of the ACM SIGGRAPH organization, which is an acyronm for Association for Computing Machinery's Special Interest Group on Graphics and Interactive Techniques. Our chapter is comprised of Purdue students from majors within the Computer Graphics Technology college in Polytechnic. We hold various activities each month, focused on professional development for students interested in entering the film/gaming industry. Club meetings often are either tech demos showcasing various industry standard software, resume and portfolio reviews, speakers who work in the industry, or game/animation jams where anyone can make something under a time constraint for a contest.

We keep our most up-to-date information posted in our Discord server
Here is our Public Calendar for 2023-2024

The Aerial Robotics Team at Purdue (PART) manages a portfolio of Uninhabited Aerial System (UAS)
design projects. It was formally a committee under the Purdue IEEE Student Branch. The mission of
the Purdue Aerial Robotics Team is to mature students into principled industry leaders for their postundergraduate careers by executing a comprehensive industry standard approach to interdisciplinary design, prototyping, and systems engineering. Currently, PART designs, builds, and tests a two-vehicle system from the ground up each year to compete in an international competition. PART’s Uninhabited Aerial
System (UAS) air-drops an Uninhabited Ground Vehicle (UGV), both of which will complete a series of
tasks demonstrating their ability to operate and navigate autonomously while performing remote sensing
missions representative of real-world problems. PART also engages in multidisciplinary research in the
areas of collision avoidance, sensor development, and Vertical Takeoff and Landing (VTOL) aircraft.

column3: Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering Student Advisory Council
column6: The Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering Student Advisory Council (AAESAC) is comprised of students within the School of Aeronautics and Astronautics. AAESAC meets regularly as an organization and with the administration. The group serves to facilitate interactions and the relationship between faculty and the student body, to advise the administration on issues and concerns of students pertaining to the department, and generally strives to improve the school in hopes of enhancing the educational experience.

The Purdue AgriBusiness Club works to create networking opportunities for our members with industry professionals. Our goal is to expose our members to agricultural companies that are looking for interns or full time cantidates.

column3: Agricultural and Biological Engineering Graduate Student Association
column6: The Agricultural and Biological Engineering Graduate Student Association is an organization that consists of students engaging in research or pursuing an advanced degree in the Department of Agricultural and Biological Engineering at Purdue University. The purpose of ABE GSA is to provide ABE graduate students with social, professional development, and mentoring opportunities that enhance and enrich their graduate career at Purdue.

Agricultural Communicators of Tomorrow (ACT) is a nationwide preprofessional organization for university students who are interested in the field of communication related to the agricultural sciences.
  Membership in the organization is open to any major. Many members are pursuing careers in agricultural public relations, advertising, journalism, or organizational communications, but any student with an interest in agriculture and communication may join.
    The Mission of National ACT is to build relationships among agricultural communication professionals and college students and faculty, to provide professional and academic development for members and to promote agriculture through communications efforts.

Bring the AgEcon student body together; to promote academic and social communication among all AgEcon graduate students; to provide a forum in which AgEcon graduate students can voice their concerns and expectations; and to act as a liaison.

The purpose of this organization is to assist no-kill animal shelters in the Lafayette area by volunteering, and organizing events to raise money for these shelters.
For any inquiries about our club please use the club email: acp@purdue.edu
Link to join our Slack group: 
https://join.slack.com/t/acauseforpaws/shared_invite/zt-1msc3ix75-aBfb30gBn3BIrkSeRhMP3A

Since 1907, Purdue Acacians share a uniquely lifelong brotherhood between the undergraduates and an expansive alumni network of distinguished Purdue alumni, executives, and philanthropists, who remain closely tied with Purdue and Acacia's mission.
Human Service, "ΩΦΕΛΟΥΝΤΕΣ ΑΝΘΡΩΠΟΥΣ," is the pillar upon which the network of Acacia chapters across the country stands.
Inside our beautiful chapter house, you will find brothers bettering themselves academically and professionally, enjoying a social life and lifelong brotherhood, and living up to our historic purpose by serving the community.

As part of our adoption program, we partner Purdue students with elderly individuals in the community to have regular visits, where students get to know their “adopted grandparent.” Students will visit with their grandparents, play cards, watch movies, assist them with everyday household chores, or just call to talk and check up on them.
We also host monthly socials where the Adopt-A-Grandparent Club visits as a group to the retirement communities and assisted living homes. This provides opportunities for students to meet and get to know the residents, possibly pairing them together as part of the adoption program. A few of our social events with the residents include ice cream socials, craft nights, euchre, and trivia challenges. Our club typically has one social a month at the various retirement communities. 
Check us out on Facebook and Instagram!
 If you have any further questions, feel free to DM the Instagram account @purdueadoptagrandparent
Join the GroupMe here: https://groupme.com/join_group/88886619/QQcN45GE

column3: Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma
column6:
Find current information about Purdue ALDPES by clicking the "News Article" link below! It includes who we are, what we do, how to join, current events, and more!
  News Article: https://docs.google.com/document/d/19RsFjvp2PaRD8dT7vUl16Jo8njQiXSnnM4WA1UC_mmI/edit?usp=sharing 
  Connect With Us!
Instagram: @purduealdpes
Facebook: @PurdueALDPES
Twitter: @aldpes_purdue
Website: https://web.ics.purdue.edu/~aldpes/index.html
  Alpha Lambda Delta and Phi Eta Sigma are two of the oldest and most prestigious national honor societies on the Purdue University Campus.  Both honor societies are rich in history and tradition at hundreds of campuses across the nation.  Phi Eta Sigma was founded in 1923 at the University of Illinois as a freshman honor society designed to promote academic achievement among male students.  Alpha Lambda Delta was originally founded as an honor society strictly for women at the University of Illinois in 1924.  A chapter was founded at Purdue University in 1926.  In the mid-1970s, Alpha Lambda Delta and Phi Eta Sigma became co-ed national honor societies.  Each of these societies operates separately at the national level.  However, both Alpha Lambda Delta and Phi Eta Sigma operate as one entity on the Purdue University campus, as well as many other campuses across the nation.  The goals of both honor societies are better served when operating as a single team dedicated to academic excellence and community service.
  Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma promotes hard work and dedication in and out of the classroom.  By encouraging incoming freshmen to earn a 3.5 GPA, the honor society creates a strong foundation for later collegiate success.  In addition to helping young college students develop and realize goals within their academic curriculum, Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma encourages students to recognize achievable goals within the community.  Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma and its members participate in a variety of community service projects each year. 
  The Purdue University chapter is no exception to this national standard.  Officers and volunteers from the campus chapter offer a well-developed tutoring program for children who reside in Purdue Village.  Serving Thanksgiving dinner at the local homeless shelter, ringing bells for the Salvation Army, and participating in the Walk for Life are just a few of the ever-increasing and ever-changing examples of the community service performed by Purdue University members.  The local chapter also sponsors the Boiler Academic Super Bowl where various student organizations have the opportunity to form teams and compete in academic challenges to raise money for the local Lafayette Adult Resource Academy.  Each year, the chapter officers seek new projects for member involvement.  It is the goal of Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma's Purdue officers to participate in at least one service project each month. 
  From its promotion of scholastic achievement to its strong involvement in the local community, Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma at Purdue University demonstrates its dedication to the growth and positive development of its members.  It certainly proves to be an excellent student organization for participation.

Gamma Rho Chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity Inc.
         Since its founding on December 4, 1906, Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc. has supplied voice and vision to the struggle of African-Americans and people of color around the world. Alpha Phi Alpha, the first intercollegiate Greek-letter fraternity established for African-Americans, was founded at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York by seven college men who recognized the need for a strong bond of Brotherhood among African descendants in this country. The visionary founders, known as the 'Jewels' of the Fraternity, are Henry Arthur Callis, Charles Henry Chapman, Eugene Kinckle Jones, George Biddle Kelley, Nathaniel Allison Murray, Robert Harold Ogle, and Vertner Woodson Tandy.

       The Fraternity initially served as a study and support group for minority students who faced racial prejusdice, both educationally and socially, at Cornell. The Jewel founders and early leaders of the Fraternity succeeded in laying a firm foundation for Alpha Phi Alpha's principles of scholarship, fellowship, moral character, and the uplifting of humanity.
       Gamma Rho Chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc. was established at Purdue University on April 24, 1948 by the following charter members. James C. Butler, Chester L. French, Raymond L. Hall, Milton B. Kendrick, John E. Littman, William N. Lovelace, Jimmie Mosley John E. Rudder, Richard Wallace, Walter H. White and George A. Younger. Since its founding at Purdue University, Gamma Rho Chapter boasts a rich legacy of producing successful men.

      Gamma Rho Chapter has maintained the fraternity's tradition of excellence in manly deeds, scholarship, and great regard of all mankind. As a demonstration of this commitment, the chapter sponsors a myriad of community service events including: Annual Voter's Registration Drive, Study Tables & Tutoring, Big Brothers Big Sisters mentoring, Food & Clothing Drives for the Needy, along with Alpha Phi Alpha's mandated programs.

         Affectionately known as "Gangsta Gamma Rho," the Brothers continue the rich tradition of community uplift and empowerment, as we live true to the Alpha motto: First of All, Servants of All, We Shall Transcend All.

Community Service? Alpha Phi Omega. We are Purdue's national gender-inclusive service organization, bringing together college students in developing Leadership, promoting Friendship, and providing Service to humanity since our chapter's founding in 1932.
  Alpha Phi Omega is open to students of any background and focuses on volunteering on campus, in the local community, and with national organizations. We also donate to a number of charities via member-raised donations.
  APO is a service-oriented organization as opposed to social fraternity. For this reason, we do not share a house, but instead have a large co-working office in the Purdue Memorial Union. Make no mistake though, joining APO is like joining a family. With approximately 60 active members in our chapter and 350 active chapters nationwide, you will be a part of a large network of members and alumni. Purdue’s Alpha Gamma chapter in particular has always ranked as one of the top chapters in the national organization and prides itself on being a fun and welcoming organization. 
  We would love to have you in our chapter! Come over to PMU B050E anytime and someone would be happy to tell you more about us. Find out more through our national office at apo.org or our chapter website at purdueapo.org.
  If you're interested in joining for Fall 2023, fill out the following Google Form so we can keep you up to date with callout and event information: https://forms.gle/vXL14aPwWrjbh8fN9. We can't wait to meet you!
  Our Office Hours are posted, if you want to stop by and check us out!
Mondays: 11-12
Mondays: 1-2
Wednesdays: 12-2
Thursdays: 11-12

Alpha Xi Delta is a greek letter fraternity for women founded in 1893. The Alpha Eta chapter of Purdue University was founded in 1921 and strives to make our founders proud of the growth and development we have made. We strive to be the best women that we can be, and involve ourselves in many of the organizations that Purdue has to offer! Our chapter hopes to leave a legacy for future members to follow in, and create memories to look back on with fondness for a lifetime. Alpha Xi Delta's vision statment is "inspiring women to realize their potential", and the Alpha Eta chapter does just that. We encourage you to check out our website and social media pages to get more information!
The Mission of Army ROTC (Reserve Officer Training Corps) is to train and prepare the future officers of the United States Army for commissioning and a career in the Army.
A Professional, Honorary, Service organization serving AFROTC Cadets of the 220th Cadet Wing, Purdue University, and the Greater Lafayette community.

Asha for Education is a secular organization dedicated to change in India by focusing on basic education in the belief that education is a critical requisite for socio-economic change. For more details please check http://www.ashanet.org/purdue/
In keeping with this focus, our volunteers are involved with and support projects that are secular and have an education-related component to them. The objectives of this group are:
To provide education to underprivileged children in India.
To encourage the formation of various local groups across the world to reach out to larger sections of the population.
To support and cooperate with persons and groups already engaged in similar activities.
To raise the required human and other resources to achieve the group objectives.
To provide opportunities to individuals living outside India who wish to participate in Asha activities in India.
To address, whenever possible, other issues affecting human life such as health care, environment, socio-economic aspects and women's issues.

Purdue University’s chapter of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) has one goal: prepare its members to land the job or internship of their dreams! With over 7 different design teams developing projects such as Grand Prix Karts, Prosthetics, and Hydroponics, alongside CAD and FEA Training in collaboration with MILESTONES, ASME offers incredible opportunities to get hands on engineering experience. The chapter hosts weekly professional development sessions, an extensive network of company connections, FE Exam Prep resources, social events, and so much more. As the fastest growing organization on campus and Purdue’s Year of Excellence award winner, they strive to provide members of any major with first class opportunities for growth and leadership. Asian American & Asian Art Collective
column6: The AAAAC is a archival collection that specifically focuses on art either made by Asian and/or Asian American artists or yielding from an Asian culture. Our organization will explore the background of the art before archiving or displaying it. Anybody interested in exploring and promoting Asian art is welcome to join, regardless of racial or cultural identification. Our purpose is to introduce this art to our local communities to promote cultural awareness and celebrate cultural diversity.

Ann Tweedale Cooperative is the largest women's cooperative house at Purdue University. Every spring, the women of this house welcome new members to their home. Incorporating academics, sisterhood, and philanthropy, AT provides a positive atmosphere where women can learn about themselves and about each other. Existing on Purdue's campus since 1937, members have the opportunity to be a part of an organization that is rich in history and tradition. AT provides a diverse atmosphere where education, sisterhood and fun meet. It is a place to be challenged and a place to be constantly growing both personally and professionally. AT is more than just a place to stay to the women of Ann Tweedale. It's a place to call home.

Devonshire was founded here at Purdue in 1997! We have a living capacity of 17 members and we have several out-of-house members, all from a wide variety of majors! As a cooperative house, Devonshire has a strong sense of community while offering one of the most affordable housing options at Purdue. Members are in charge of decision making and running all aspects of the house, from overseeing house finances and house recycling to participating in weekly cooking and cleaning duties. We participate in sporting events and social functions that include tailgating with our football buddies, barn dance, Winter Tea, intramural sports, Spring Formal, and May Day Tea. Devonshire also participates in philanthropy and fundraising efforts.

-Cooperative Housing FAQ-
What is a cooperative house?
A house where students live and work together to promote friendship, leadership, and life skills. Cooperative houses have between 14 and 60 members which share responsibilities such as cleaning and preparing meals to maintain a comfortable and affordable living environment. Members of the cooperative houses have between 2 and 4 hours of house duties a week.
  What is recruitment?
A time when cooperative members showcase their houses and invite prospective members to come and learn more about joining a cooperative.
  How many cooperative houses exist at Purdue?
There are 11 houses--7 women, 4 men.
  What is the average rent in a cooperative house?
Depending on the house, rent is about 300-500/month. This fee typically includes all utilities, room, and meals. House bills are only paid eight months out of a year.

3DPC is dedicated to bringing 3D printing technology to Purdue and making it accessible to all students and staff. The club also supports any questions regarding CAD software or 3D printing. For the Fall 2022 semester, 3DPC will be working  in person. For more information please visit our website.

Important Announcement:
This semester, Contact Improvisation at Purdue will not be hosting any events on campus! Given the pandemic, we are unable to do contact dance without physical contact, so for everyone's safety we will not be having any events this semester. However, if you are interested in hearing about dance improvisation events in the community, or opportunities for virtual dance gatherings, please check out our facebook! https://www.facebook.com/purduecontactimprov/
Contact Improvisation is a partner dance form based on the physical principles of touch, momentum, shared weight, and most quintessentially - following a shared point of contact. It does not require any previous dance/acro/martial arts experience, but all from these fields and other walks of life are welcome! This is a form of movement that allows you to have fun and get a good workout.
The Purdue Contact Improv club meets regularly, both on Friday nights at 5:00 pm and Sundays at 4:30 pm, about biweekly. Watch for additional details on the information board next to the dance division studios, PAO 1171/1179, and check our Facebook, Instagram, and Boilerlink events page for dates and times as the jams come about! We also hold our annual Contact Improvisation Gathering [CIG] every spring, watch for dates coming up soon
  Jams: Will not be occurring this semester! See the first paragraph to find out more!
When: N/A
Where: N/A
Who & What to bring: N/A
  Contact Improvisation Gathering (CIG): TBA
  CIG--What is it?: CIG is a workshop-packed weekend of dance where Purdue dancers have the opportunity to learn with other dancers from around the Midwest, and learn from some of the Midwest's best contact dance teachers. Come learn new skills, meet new people, and have a great time!
CIG--When: TBA
CIG--Information: Registration will begin soon, so keep an eye out on our Facebook page for our poster! The cost for the whole weekend is only $10 for Purdue students, but register soon!
What is Contact Improvisation?
Check out this article at wikipedia.   Contact Improvisation
  Is Contact Improvisation a form of improv comedy?
No, Contact Improvisation is a dance form that focuses on exploring movement through partnering and sharing weight.
  Interested in other Contact Improvisation events?
Check out the GLACIER (Great Lakes Area Contact Improvisation Enthusiasts Retreat) community website for contact events/jams/workshops all over the Great Lakes area.

Purdue Contemporary Dance Company is an organization that gives anyone who is interested in modern/contemporary dance several opportunities to further expand their passion for this art form. Members are able to learn modern dance via an anatomically-based focus, take workshops with well known choreographers from around the country, and perform in a professionally-run concert at the end of the semester.  PCDC is a great way to interact with student and faculty artists in a collaborative, creative and inventive process for creating dance works.
Auditions for the Purdue Contemporary Dance Compony Winter Works Concert is Tuesday, August 30, 2022 from 6:00pm to 8:00pm in Pao Hall 1171. 
https://cla.purdue.edu/academic/rueffschool/dance/index.html
Requirements include enrollment in DANC 24500 to receive credit for rehearsing and performing.  There are 3 hours of rehearsal per week, 2 showings on Saturdays. Rehearsal times are built in with flexibility regarding each dancer's schedule.
  The Purdue Contemporary Dance Company will perform its Spring Works 2022 Dance Concert on April 29 & April 30 at 7:30pm each evening with a matinee performance at 2:30pm on April 30.

Alpha Eta Rho is an internationally recognized Professional Aviation Fraternity aimed to provide its members with an enriched experience in Aviation. We facilitate professionalism, mentorship, and industry connections with the goal of improving the transition between students and industry.
Members of Alpha Eta Rho have the opportunity to participate in various events aimed at providing a better aviation experience. We often take trips to various locations such as major airports, company headquarters, and others. As a club we also bring in speakers from the industry to give us their perspective and help us jump-start our careers. We also have a social aspect, as we are brothers and friends to each other.

Mission Statement
alpha Kappa Delta Phi Sorority, Inc. fosters the making of successful leaders by assisting and challenging our members to reach their maximum potential. We strive to maintain the highest levels of integrity and innovation in the promotion of sisterhood, philanthropy, scholastic excellence, and Asian-Awareness in the community while creating lifelong relationships.
Vision Statement
alpha Kappa Delta Phi Inc. will be the most respected, premier network of innovative female leaders within the community by: 
Encouraging the growth of our members through cultural diversity and the expression of individuality;
Empowering our members to become pioneers for philanthropic, cultural, and scholastic programs worldwide;
Developing strategic collaborations and partnerships; and
Supporting initiatives promoting the sustainability of our organization and its mission.
Philanthropy 
In 1998, alpha Kappa Delta Phi launched its first-ever National Service project. Through our 22 chapter effort, we dedicated the year of 1998-99 to Breast Cancer Awareness by educating ourselves, our college campuses, and our communities. Through the efforts of our active sisters and alumnae, we have raised over $250,000 throughout the years for breast cancer research. In addition to raising funds, awareness is spread on all our campus communities through service projects, workshops, informational booths, or forums.
Random Facts:
Founded in the fall of 1989 at the University of California, Berkeley
First, Largest, and Only Internationally Recognized Asian American Sorority
More than 63 Chapters worldwide

Gamma Rho Chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity Inc.
         Since its founding on December 4, 1906, Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc. has supplied voice and vision to the struggle of African-Americans and people of color around the world. Alpha Phi Alpha, the first intercollegiate Greek-letter fraternity established for African-Americans, was founded at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York by seven college men who recognized the need for a strong bond of Brotherhood among African descendants in this country. The visionary founders, known as the 'Jewels' of the Fraternity, are Henry Arthur Callis, Charles Henry Chapman, Eugene Kinckle Jones, George Biddle Kelley, Nathaniel Allison Murray, Robert Harold Ogle, and Vertner Woodson Tandy.

       The Fraternity initially served as a study and support group for minority students who faced racial prejusdice, both educationally and socially, at Cornell. The Jewel founders and early leaders of the Fraternity succeeded in laying a firm foundation for Alpha Phi Alpha's principles of scholarship, fellowship, moral character, and the uplifting of humanity.
       Gamma Rho Chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc. was established at Purdue University on April 24, 1948 by the following charter members. James C. Butler, Chester L. French, Raymond L. Hall, Milton B. Kendrick, John E. Littman, William N. Lovelace, Jimmie Mosley John E. Rudder, Richard Wallace, Walter H. White and George A. Younger. Since its founding at Purdue University, Gamma Rho Chapter boasts a rich legacy of producing successful men.

      Gamma Rho Chapter has maintained the fraternity's tradition of excellence in manly deeds, scholarship, and great regard of all mankind. As a demonstration of this commitment, the chapter sponsors a myriad of community service events including: Annual Voter's Registration Drive, Study Tables & Tutoring, Big Brothers Big Sisters mentoring, Food & Clothing Drives for the Needy, along with Alpha Phi Alpha's mandated programs.

         Affectionately known as "Gangsta Gamma Rho," the Brothers continue the rich tradition of community uplift and empowerment, as we live true to the Alpha motto: First of All, Servants of All, We Shall Transcend All.

The American India Foundation (AIF, founded 2001) is a nonprofit American development organization that is devoted to accelerating social and economic change in India. The AIF has invested in over 100 Indian non-governmental organizations while raising about $50 million since its inception. It is one of the largest secular, non-partisan American organizations supporting development work in India.
AIF works with partners to implement programs in education, livelihood, and public health sectors in India - with emphases on elementary education, women's empowerment, and HIV/AIDS, respectively. AIF through it's program Digital Equalizer attempts to bridge the digital divide by providing computers, internet access and training to improve learning and critical thinking amongst students of under-resourced Indian schools. It also implements the Service Corps Fellowship, which sends skilled young Americans to work with NGOs in India for a ten month period. The fellowship helps exchange technical skills, intellectual resources and helps increase the capacity of Indian NGOs to continue their work while giving American leaders a good understanding of India.

AIF works out of New York and Silicon Valley in the US, and New Delhi and Bangalore in India.
Mission
The American India Foundation is devoted to accelerating social and economic change in India.
Vision
To contribute to building an India where all people can gain access to education, healthcare, and employment opportunities and where every Indian can realize their full potential.
To build a trusted bridge between the dreams and aspirations of individuals who care about India and their realization.
To provide a secure channel for philanthropic funding in the US and its effective utilization in India in partnership with best-of-breed NGO’s, foundations and non-profit organizations
To build a professional organization that is secular, transparent, credible, and accountable for all of its activities.

column3: American Indian Science and Engineering Society
column6:
The mission of the American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) is to substantially increase the representation of American Indians and Alaskan Natives in engineering, science, and other related technology disciplines.
Since 1977, AISES has worked to substantially increase American Indian and Alaska Native representation in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields — as students, professionals, mentors, and leaders. AISES employs a "full circle of support" model that begins with pre-college programs, progresses into collegiate life, and then into the professional years of members and on into retirement.
AISES works to promote, initiate, and provide educational services for American Indian and Alaska Native pre-college,college, and graduate students in STEM. AISES also supports early-, mid-, and executive-level professionals in STEM through professional development, mentoring, networking, community service, and awards programs and initiatives. AISES is the only professional society established by and for American Indian and Alaska Natives that specifically emphasizes lifelong learning and educational achievement by utilizing cultural aspects with STEM.

Still growing and evolving, the women of the Phi Upsilon chapter are excited to bring rubies back to the West Lafayette Campus, and provide a little bit more of Phi Upsilon's submotto, "Perfect Understanding."

The Association for Women in Communications (AWC) is a professional organization that champions the advancement of women across all communication disciplines by recognizing excellence, promoting leadership and positioning its members at the forefront of the evolving communication era.

The Purdue Chapter of AWC offers a welcoming place for students to connect, grow and succeed. We are one of the nation’s oldest professional communications organizations. Anyone interested in the studying or pursuing a career in the field of communication is encouraged to join AWC! We are a diverse organization that serves the broad spectrum of the communication industry including advertising, public relations, marketing, graphic design, film, print and broadcast journalism, organizational communication, human resources, among others. 

As a member of AWC you’ll have access to networking opportunities, scholarships, internship and job postings, and have the chance to build and strengthen your resume and portfolio with hands on experience at chapter meetings, special events, fundraisers and philanthropies. Furthermore, you’ll build meaningful, long lasting relationships with other members and professionals, who share common interests and goals. The Purdue Chapter is about developing the young professional woman. 
Connect and network with Purdue students and communication professionals 
Meaningful career development techniques that will help you build your professional profile
Gain study, professional, and social support from fellow communication students
Interactive Chapter meetings that provide enriching and inspiring information 
Minimal time requirements means you decide how much you want to be involved
Opportunity to develop leadership skills and experience
Access to special scholarship opportunities
Be part of an international organization with a special focus on women’s issues
Strengthen your resume and portfolio through various workshops
Access to many different internship/job and networking opportunities
The AWC Purdue Chapter offers a welcoming place for communication students to connect, grow, and succeed.

CHAARG stands for Changing Health, Attitudes, + Actions to Recreate Girls. We are all about liberating girls from the elliptical and helping them find their fit. Our goal is to show women that fitness can (+should) be fun and that it shouldn't be a chore. We meet two times a week -- once as a chapter and once with a smaller group of girls. We also have socials and extra events throughout the semester. We have a big presence on social media (check out #purduechaarg on instagram) in which we focus on creating a community of empowering women. 
If you have any questions regarding CHAARG or would like further information, please email purduechaarg@gmail.com. You can purchase your membership here: https://shop.chaarg.com/products/purdue-university-membership
  CHAARGon

The Computer Science Women's Network (CSWN) is an organization at Purdue University that is dedicated to helping women navigate the field of CS/DS and the tech industry.
  CSWN organizes different activities meant to encourage young women to connect with one another and learn.
  Apply here to become a member!

The primary activity of Delight Ministries is to launch, grow and sustain Christ-centered women's communities at college campuses across the country. We work with passionate college women who yearn for deeper community on their campus by providing them with the training, tools, resources and encouragement needed to start and lead a Delight chapter. 
Delight is more than just a bible study! Each community meets weekly to share stories of God at work. They also incorporate worship nights, opportunities to serve and fun get-togethers that help foster relationships. We fully believe in doing life together. Delight provides the opportunity for hundreds of women to Delight in the Lord together throughout their college journey. 
The heart of Delight Ministries is to provide an environment for women to vulnerably share about how Christ has been at work in their lives. Our curriculum is made of stories from college women sharing about the ups and downs of their faith journeys. We've heard stories of depression, loneliness, heartbreak, identity crisis and pain, but the common theme throughout them all is that even still, God is good. 
These stories are paired with scripture and discussion questions and are used weekly by all Delight communities. Stories of real women opens the door for authentic conversations and deep-rooted relationships. We truly believe in the power of vulnerability and how it impacts our relationship with Christ and others. 
It's so easy to walk through college and never encounter true community or a relationship with Jesus. Delight Ministries desires to change the college experience for women everywhere by helping them to transform their stories. We believe that transformation happens when we live fully invested in pursuing Christ, vulnerability and community. Our stories become no longer about us, but rather about Christ in us.

The sisters of Delta Phi Lambda feel privileged to be enriched with our close-knit sisterhood. We seek to reach out to young women so that they can be welcomed into our family and enjoy the benefits of our organization. Motivated and ambitious, we strive to promote every conviction of Delta Phi Lambda. Thus, we aspire to reach out to female college students to enrich their lives, and by doing so, enriching ours.

Our purpose includes promoting multiculturalism with an emphasis on Asian awareness, reaching out to the community as a whole, and embracing fellow collegiate women into a nurturing environment.

As an Asian-interest sorority, the Sisters understand how difficult it is to be a part of the minority population. By uniting with other cultures, everyone takes part in overcoming adversity. Also, uniting with students with different nationalities provides the Sisters of Delta Phi Lambda an opportunity to learn about other cultures, appreciate our differences, and share our similarities. We will take initiative to assist any minority organization or community that is interested in promoting multiculturalism and bridging the gap between all minority groups.

Not only do we strive for unity in our communities, we also participate in several philanthropic events that concentrate on helping women and children. Serving our community is our passion. We must not forget how fortunate we are to be able to give to the community and we must not forget how to give.
  We hope to expand our Sisterhood on a larger scale to create a support system of sisterhood across the United States. By doing so, Sisters would be able to find other Sisters no matter where their plans may take them. Moreover, having additional chapters nationally will help Sisters better adjust to their new environment should their plans take them to greater things in life.

Finally, we hope to develop well-rounded individuals by both nurturing our natural talents, as well as by helping each other strengthen our weakness. By accomplishing these two tasks, we feel that our members are better prepared to walk into the real world with confidence.

Delta Phi Lambda provides a once in a lifetime experience that exhibits our unique sisterhood, community involvement, preparedness for the real world, and tremendous leadership.

Delta Phi Mu was founded on August 28th, 1991 at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana by five courageous and determined Latina womxn. They dreamt of a Sisterhood which would unite all womxn interested in the Latinx culture and in intercultural exchange to empower them to become leaders through personal, academic, and professional fulfillment. Ever since, the Distinguished Ladies of Delta Phi Mu have fulfilled the dreams of our Founding Mothers by flourishing within a bond of true sisterhood which is based on the principles of support, guidance, assistance, and love. Although we come from different backgrounds, together we have formed a united family of sisters who support, guide, assist, and love one another in all that we strive to do.
  Our motto, "La Esperanza del Futuro Está en las Manos de la Mujer" or "The Hope of the Future Lies in the Hands of the Woman", epitomizes the purpose that lies within our Sisterhood to work tirelessly toward making the world a better place for all womxn. We do so by uplifting our communities through service and advocacy and by motivating all womxn to become leaders through personal, academic, and professional development. 
  Delta Phi Mu Sorority, Inc. is nationally recognized as an official sponsor of The Heart Truth® initiative through the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute. We additionally support the Go Red for Women campaign through the American Heart Association. Through these two initiatives, we hope to provide awareness of the effects of heart disease, which disproportionately effects womxn of color in the U.S. We hope to advocate for better access to medical treatments and resources that will relieve womxn of color from shouldering the burden of this disease.
  Delta Phi Mu Sorority, Inc. is a non-profit, 501©7 public service organization. Delta Phi Mu is open to all womxn, regardless of race, religion, color, age, national origin or ancestry, marital status, parental status, sexual orientation, disability, or status as a disabled war veteran.

column3: "AQUAE" The Purdue Student chapter of AWWA/IWEA
column6:
AQUAE has a main objective to cluster students interested in water issues. There is an emphasis on encouraging students to pursue academic or professional careers that address water related problems. Today, almost half of the world's workers - 1.5 billion people - work in water related sectors, and nearly all jobs depend on water or ensure its safe delivery. As Purdue students, we are willing to have a positive impact on the sector. By being a student chapter of the most prestige water professional association AWWA (American Water Works Association) and IWEA (Indiana Water Environment Association) it would be possible to provide leadership and networking opportunities to Purdue students.
The aim of the chapter is to promote among Purdue student the passion for water issues and the potential of developing a career as a researcher or professional on the water sector.
This organization is a student chapter of the Indiana American Water Works Association and the Indiana Water Environment Association. AWWA and IWEA are members of the Water Environment Federation.
  Possible Related Activities
Organize talks by students or faculty.
Sponsor lectures by guest speakers.
Host lunch discussions on the training students need for careers in water.
Organize team projects such as undergraduate competitions.
Host social functions (lunches, dinners, movie nights, picnics).
Tours of water treatment facilities, utilities, etc.
Field trips to AWWA/WEA conferences and events.
Host interdisciplinary activities with other Association on campus
Set up chapter website.
Mentor lunches.
Establish an internship or job shadow program
Volunteer activities focus on local community’s water issues

Purdue University’s chapter of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) has one goal: prepare its members to land the job or internship of their dreams! With over 7 different design teams developing projects such as Grand Prix Karts, Prosthetics, and Hydroponics, alongside CAD and FEA Training in collaboration with MILESTONES, ASME offers incredible opportunities to get hands on engineering experience. The chapter hosts weekly professional development sessions, an extensive network of company connections, FE Exam Prep resources, social events, and so much more. As the fastest growing organization on campus and Purdue’s Year of Excellence award winner, they strive to provide members of any major with first class opportunities for growth and leadership. Check out their website to learn more information and to join the Slack!

Alpha Chi Sigma is the co-ed professional chemistry fraternity. Our primary purposes are summarized in our objects:
  To bind its members with a tie of true and lasting friendship.
To strive for the advancement of chemistry both as a science and as a profession.
To aid its members by every honorable means in the attainment of their ambitions as chemists throughout their mortal lives.

The student chapter of the American Association of Feline Practitioners welcomes both veterinary and veterinary technician students to become members of the club and enjoy the fun events planned for the upcoming year!
The club strives to supplement the knowledge of veterinary and veterinary technician students through monthly lunch lectures. In addition to the lectures, members of SCAAFP have the opportunity to participate in a wet lab each semester. In an effort to encourage members to take an active role in the well-being of the feline population, there will also be a fundraiser and volunteer opportunity each semester.
Come join our club and learn why cats are definitely not small dogs.

column3: American Indian Science and Engineering Society
column6:
The mission of the American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) is to substantially increase the representation of American Indians and Alaskan Natives in engineering, science, and other related technology disciplines.
Since 1977, AISES has worked to substantially increase American Indian and Alaska Native representation in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields — as students, professionals, mentors, and leaders. AISES employs a "full circle of support" model that begins with pre-college programs, progresses into collegiate life, and then into the professional years of members and on into retirement.
AISES works to promote, initiate, and provide educational services for American Indian and Alaska Native pre-college,college, and graduate students in STEM. AISES also supports early-, mid-, and executive-level professionals in STEM through professional development, mentoring, networking, community service, and awards programs and initiatives. AISES is the only professional society established by and for American Indian and Alaska Natives that specifically emphasizes lifelong learning and educational achievement by utilizing cultural aspects with STEM.

Welcome to the Purdue Chapter of the American Institute of Aeronautics & Astronautics!

     2) Create awareness of National AIAA conferences and opportunities.

We are a roller skating and rollerblading club! The goal is to create a community of people who enjoy skating. Those who don't know how to skate but would like to learn are more than welcome to join (we are currently building an equipment inventory and may be able to lend you some supplies). Club activities include skating around campus together, visits to the local roller rink, and our annual end-of-year ice skating session at Tapawingo Park! We are a group that is just looking to make friends and enjoy our mutual hobby.

Founded by 3 undergraduate students in the Fall of 2016, the AcaBellas are set to deliver a new sound to Purdue's campus.  The Bellas were created to add a diverse repertoire to Purdue University's a Capella scene and to captivate its audiences through soulful, upbeat, melodies. This amazing team strives to promote leadership and development through community engagement, and unite music lovers from all backgrounds. The AcaBellas strive not to only be a team, but a family.

ACM (Association for Computing Machinery) at Purdue is an organization for connecting students, faculty and companies for the betterment of the computing community. As a representative of one the world's most influential computing organizations, we provide academic resources, forums for the spreading of ideas, and communities for technological discovery and growth.
  To support a multitude of interests, ACM is divided into several sub-groups, called Special Interest Groups (SIGs). Here’s our current list of them:
SIGBots (Robotics)
SIGAPP (App Design)
SIGGD (Game Design)
In these groups, students get the chance to develop technologies and applications in a team environment that has a meaningful impact in a wide variety of places. 
  Some of the great things that have come out of Purdue ACM include PROS (an open source robotics operating system used by over 21 thousand users for VEX micro-controllers), 7 unique and complex independent games since 2011, and the Official Purdue App.
  TLDR: We make cool stuff and have fun doing it, so check us out! We accept all majors!
Learn more at: https://acm.cs.purdue.edu/
You can ask us questions at: https://discord.gg/2pEsxdA

column3: Alpha Eta Mu Beta Biomedical Engineering Honors Society
column6: AEMB is the Purdue chapter of the national BME honors society. As an honors society, the general members and leaders must be within the top fifth of their class as juniors or top third of their class as seniors, and everyone must pay dues as set by the AEMB national chapter. A main goal of AEMB is to promote the excellence of the BME profession at Purdue.

column3: Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma
column6:
Find current information about Purdue ALDPES by clicking the "News Article" link below! It includes who we are, what we do, how to join, current events, and more!

  Alpha Lambda Delta and Phi Eta Sigma are two of the oldest and most prestigious national honor societies on the Purdue University Campus.  Both honor societies are rich in history and tradition at hundreds of campuses across the nation.  Phi Eta Sigma was founded in 1923 at the University of Illinois as a freshman honor society designed to promote academic achievement among male students.  Alpha Lambda Delta was originally founded as an honor society strictly for women at the University of Illinois in 1924.  A chapter was founded at Purdue University in 1926.  In the mid-1970s, Alpha Lambda Delta and Phi Eta Sigma became co-ed national honor societies.  Each of these societies operates separately at the national level.  However, both Alpha Lambda Delta and Phi Eta Sigma operate as one entity on the Purdue University campus, as well as many other campuses across the nation.  The goals of both honor societies are better served when operating as a single team dedicated to academic excellence and community service.
  Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma promotes hard work and dedication in and out of the classroom.  By encouraging incoming freshmen to earn a 3.5 GPA, the honor society creates a strong foundation for later collegiate success.  In addition to helping young college students develop and realize goals within their academic curriculum, Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma encourages students to recognize achievable goals within the community.  Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma and its members participate in a variety of community service projects each year. 
  The Purdue University chapter is no exception to this national standard.  Officers and volunteers from the campus chapter offer a well-developed tutoring program for children who reside in Purdue Village.  Serving Thanksgiving dinner at the local homeless shelter, ringing bells for the Salvation Army, and participating in the Walk for Life are just a few of the ever-increasing and ever-changing examples of the community service performed by Purdue University members.  The local chapter also sponsors the Boiler Academic Super Bowl where various student organizations have the opportunity to form teams and compete in academic challenges to raise money for the local Lafayette Adult Resource Academy.  Each year, the chapter officers seek new projects for member involvement.  It is the goal of Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma's Purdue officers to participate in at least one service project each month. 
  From its promotion of scholastic achievement to its strong involvement in the local community, Alpha Lambda Delta Phi Eta Sigma at Purdue University demonstrates its dedication to the growth and positive development of its members.  It certainly proves to be an excellent student organization for participation.

Alpha Pi Mu (APM) was founded in 1949 by Industrial Engineering (IE) students at Georgia Tech. It was created to be an organization that would allow students to exchange ideas and develop their professional networks. By 1959, Alpha Pi Mu became a part of the Association of College Honors Societies (ACHS), making it the only nationally accepted honors society for Industrial Engineering.
  Our Purdue University chapter is one of over 60 active chapters that exist today. Our mission is to recognize junior and senior students who have demonstrated academic excellence in the Department of Industrial Engineering and encourage them to further their knowledge and develop a strong professional network. APM frequently works with the other IE societies, such as IISE (Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineers), to offer programs and activities to all of the Engineering students of Purdue.
  Membership is by invitation only to third year IE students in the top one fifth of their IE class and to fourth year IE students in the top one third of their IE class. Members work to improve the surrounding community by performing acts and duties that bring a greater understanding of Industrial Engineering to Indiana. On top of our community focus, Purdue's chapter aims to help its members in various capacities that provide value to their career and educational aspirations.
  Why should you join Alpha Pi Mu?
Direct connections to networking opportunities with alumni, faculty, and company representatives
Access to professional development resources for suggestions on resumes, interviews, and visa/sponsorship information
Life membership and society award scholarship opportunities
Leadership opportunities within the school of industrial engineering
Advice from fellow IE students in different classes
Social, corporate, and career networking events and activities
Fun, inclusive opportunities to work with other industrial engineers

Purdue's Honorary Theatre Society
Alpha Beta Omega Chapter
  Alpha Psi Omega was organized as a theatre honor society for the purpose of providing acknowledgment to those demonstrating a high standard of accomplishment in theatre and, through the expansion of Alpha Psi Omega among colleges and universities, providing a wider fellowship for those interested in theatre. The society is not intended to take the place of any regular theatre clubs or producing groups, but as students qualify they may be rewarded by election to membership in this society.

Association of Zamorano Alumni (AZA) is a nonprofit student organization. Zamorano is a panamerican agricultural university located in Honduras and has students for most Latin American countries. It offers degrees in Food Science and Technology, Agribusiness, Environmental and Socio-economic development and Agronomy. AZA's mission is to support and advance the professional development of current Zamorano students that come to Purdue as visiting scholars and alumni that begin graduate studies or obtain research scholar positions at Purdue. AZA offers support in academic, social and research activities at Purdue University. It also aids as a link between Zamorano faculty members.

Inside our beautiful chapter house, you will find brothers bettering themselves academically and professionally, enjoying a social life and lifelong brotherhood, and living up to our historic purpose by serving the community.

Purdue University ACM SIGGRAPH Chapter is a student chapter of the ACM SIGGRAPH organization, which is an acyronm for Association for Computing Machinery's Special Interest Group on Graphics and Interactive Techniques. Our chapter is comprised of Purdue students from majors within the Computer Graphics Technology college in Polytechnic. We hold various activities each month, focused on professional development for students interested in entering the film/gaming industry. Club meetings often are either tech demos showcasing various industry standard software, resume and portfolio reviews, speakers who work in the industry, or game/animation jams where anyone can make something under a time constraint for a contest.

  The African Students' Association is an independent, non-profit, non-sectarian, sociocultural and educational student organization. 
Preambles
We the African students of Purdue University, in order to form a more perfect union, establish mutual understanding, provide for the common good, promote culture and stronger ties with various students, and secure the blessings of freedom to ourselves, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the African Student Association.
The Aims of the Association shall be:
1. To consolidate and promote mutual understanding among the African Students.
2. To promote a better mutual understanding and stronger ties with the American community.
3. To Promote understanding with students and other student organization in and around the University.
4. To act as liaison between the African Students of the University and other African Students organizations outside. 
5. We aim to introduce our diverse culture to the Purdue community through a myriad of events and ourselves learn from the native culture(s)

Mission Statement
alpha Kappa Delta Phi Sorority, Inc. fosters the making of successful leaders by assisting and challenging our members to reach their maximum potential. We strive to maintain the highest levels of integrity and innovation in the promotion of sisterhood, philanthropy, scholastic excellence, and Asian-Awareness in the community while creating lifelong relationships.
Vision Statement
alpha Kappa Delta Phi Inc. will be the most respected, premier network of innovative female leaders within the community by: 
Encouraging the growth of our members through cultural diversity and the expression of individuality;
Empowering our members to become pioneers for philanthropic, cultural, and scholastic programs worldwide;
Developing strategic collaborations and partnerships; and
Supporting initiatives promoting the sustainability of our organization and its mission.
Philanthropy 
In 1998, alpha Kappa Delta Phi launched its first-ever National Service project. Through our 22 chapter effort, we dedicated the year of 1998-99 to Breast Cancer Awareness by educating ourselves, our college campuses, and our communities. Through the efforts of our active sisters and alumnae, we have raised over $250,000 throughout the years for breast cancer research. In addition to raising funds, awareness is spread on all our campus communities through service projects, workshops, informational booths, or forums.
Random Facts:
Founded in the fall of 1989 at the University of California, Berkeley
First, Largest, and Only Internationally Recognized Asian American Sorority
More than 63 Chapters worldwide

The American India Foundation (AIF, founded 2001) is a nonprofit American development organization that is devoted to accelerating social and economic change in India. The AIF has invested in over 100 Indian non-governmental organizations while raising about $50 million since its inception. It is one of the largest secular, non-partisan American organizations supporting development work in India.
AIF works with partners to implement programs in education, livelihood, and public health sectors in India - with emphases on elementary education, women's empowerment, and HIV/AIDS, respectively. AIF through it's program Digital Equalizer attempts to bridge the digital divide by providing computers, internet access and training to improve learning and critical thinking amongst students of under-resourced Indian schools. It also implements the Service Corps Fellowship, which sends skilled young Americans to work with NGOs in India for a ten month period. The fellowship helps exchange technical skills, intellectual resources and helps increase the capacity of Indian NGOs to continue their work while giving American leaders a good understanding of India.

AIF works out of New York and Silicon Valley in the US, and New Delhi and Bangalore in India.
Mission
The American India Foundation is devoted to accelerating social and economic change in India.
Vision
To contribute to building an India where all people can gain access to education, healthcare, and employment opportunities and where every Indian can realize their full potential.
To build a trusted bridge between the dreams and aspirations of individuals who care about India and their realization.
To provide a secure channel for philanthropic funding in the US and its effective utilization in India in partnership with best-of-breed NGO’s, foundations and non-profit organizations
To build a professional organization that is secular, transparent, credible, and accountable for all of its activities.

column3: American Society of Heating, Refrigerating & Air-Conditioning Engineers
column6:
We are the Purdue University Student Branch of the American Society of Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE), a society that was formed by a merger in 1959 of American Society of Heating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHAE) founded in 1894 and The American Society of Refrigerating Engineers (ASRE) founded in 1904.
Since 1948, we are active on campus to advance the arts and sciences of heating, ventilating, air conditioning and refrigerating to serve humanity and promote a sustainable world. The society and its members focus on building systems, energy efficiency, indoor air quality and sustainability within the industry. Through our local chapter (Central Indiana Chapter), we are part of an international organization with more than 50,000 members.
Embedded in a global organization, we can provide scholarships, professional support in form of publications and handbooks, and helps students to network and found the career in the field of HVAC&R. The regular attendance of the ASHRAE conferences gives a platform to publish and present own research work and ensures close contact with industry professionals.
With our work in the student branch, we strive for continuous improvement and innovation in all our practices and products and will always reflect the best practices that lead our industry. Our aim is to create a sustainable future by improving energy efficient building technology and components and aiming for the electrification of society and industry due to applications such as heat pumps.
We are open to students from all fields of research who are passionate about serving the built environment, creating value, and recognizing the accomplishments of others. ASHRAE is committed to the highest ethical standards. We work transparently, observing essential requirements for due process and peer reviews to assure our members and stakeholders that we do the right things the right way.

With a lot of ideas within the group but starting small, our focus for this semester is to 1. make sure that all incoming students who have interest in the club can find the club as we promote the club around Purdue 2. set up frequent meetings, both informal and formal ones, to work on developing the club and making it a bigger community 3. set up events with strong involvement with other cultural clubs and with everyone here at Purdue, to promote our values and traditions, as well as showing what defines us 4. establish connections both within and outside of Purdue, with other students, professors, and professionals, having guests and encouraging other Argentinians and Uruguayans to be part of this initiative

Inside our beautiful chapter house, you will find brothers bettering themselves academically and professionally, enjoying a social life and lifelong brotherhood, and living up to our historic purpose by serving the community.

The world needs a few good men. The kind of men who lead by the example of their character and the value of their actions. For more than 100 years, Alpha Gamma Rho Fraternity has successfully endeavored to make such men taking the best and making them better by helping to harness the power within each man to achieve his potential.

Alpha Gamma Rho is actually two fraternities in one. We're a social fraternity offering a host of experiences that involve our members in the rich social fabric of college life, plus we're a professional fraternity bonding our members in a common cause to better themselves as they pursue careers in agriculture, food or fiber industries.

For every man, the road to personal excellence offers both trial and triumph. The road is never easy. But in AGR, you'll find a group of men of brothers dedicated to helping each other find triumph on that road.

Come with us. Share the journey.

BYX is a lifelong brotherhood of committed Christian men seeking the bonds of brotherhood and unity in Christ through the avenue of social fraternity on a college campus.
  Fairway Cooperative was initiated as the Alpha Chi chapter of BYX in spring 2017.

column3: Delta Pi Rho Fraternity Inc., Alpha Chapter
column6:
Delta Pi Rho was founded on December 9th, 2004 at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana by four proud Latinos. These four Gentlemen had a new vision to empower the Latino community through four pillars: Academics, Loyalty, Leadership and Hermanos Unidos. All Delta Pi Rho brothers stand by the Four Pillars.
The gentlemen of Delta Pi Rho's motto is "Encendiendo el Fuego de la Hermandad," which can be translated as "Lighting the Fire of Brotherhood." This motto exemplifies the brotherhood that the brothers of Delta Pi Rho strive for. Their mission is to promote scholarship, service and unity among brothers and other gentlemen interested in the Latino culture. 
Please feel free to contact us on our Facebook and Instagram or look for us at the Latino Cultural Center on campus!

The Halberdiers represent Tarkington Hall in any way they can. We are tasked with improving our Residence Hall, creating programs that promote good life styles, offering the men of Tarkington service projects that better our world, and seeing to it that every person in Tarkington is an important member of the community.

Our Executive Board and our Senators meet in Tarkington's West Activity Room most Tuesday nights at 6:30pm to discuss legislation designed to accomplish our goals and further the development of every man in Tarkington. If you want to know more, please join us for our meeting to see what it is we do!

column3: Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc.- Nu Chapter
column6:
Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Incorporated was founded on the principle of achievement. On October 5, 1920, the Nu of Kappa Alpha Psi was charted by Brothers Lionel F. Artis, Howard Dangerfield, Robert L. Bailey, Lucien B. Merriweather, Theodore W. Cable, and Frederick D. Smith in an effort to further the dream of our 10 astute founders to achieve in every field of human endeavor, and inspire service at the same time. The brothers of Nu are proud to live vicariously through the men who created this great fraternity and give back to the greater Purdue and Lafayette communities. 
  As an undergraduate chapter, we are responsible for assisting the aims and purposes of colleges and universities, another founding objective. We strive to achieve this by partnering with other on-campus organizations in an effort to create a welcoming environment for everyone in the Purdue community to thrive.
  Evolved from a 1921 program by Brother Leon W. Steward of the St. Louis Alumni Chapter, Guide Right was adopted as the national service program of Kappa Alpha Psi at the 12th Grand Chapter Meeting. Guide Right was founded to inspire service in the public’s interest by involving young men, primarily of African-American descent, in development and preparation programs. More than 100 years later, we are committed to seeing this through by starting a Guide Right program of our own, focused on the development of young men so they may succeed in professional spaces and to grow as individuals.
  Kappa Alpha Psi was founded to unite college men of culture, patriotism, and honor in a bond of fraternity. Nu chapter has always been notorious for having a strong brotherhood, among other things, which is where we derived our signature chant: Notorious Nu Chapter is a fruitful chapter, and the brotherly love found here shall never perish!

Additional Information
Primary Advisor Name (Purdue University Directory)
Shawn Wooden
Primary classification of the majority of the organizations current members.
Select the option which represents 50.1% of the group.
Undergraduate

Mission 
As a Brother of Kappa Pi Beta, I will strive hard to further the existence of this great fraternity. I will do my best to bring forth a bond of unity to all of my fellow Brothers that will stand the test of time. Along with the close relationships that are built, I pledge to promote academic excellence, brotherhood, cultural awareness, social mobility, philanthropy, gentlemen values, and respect towards the individual and community. Regardless of the letters I wear, what organizations I am in, or national origin, I will set the example that unity is the ultimate beginning of Brotherhood. I will use these attributes as development of my character and retain them even beyond my years of higher learning.
Vision
Through the practices of respect and etiquette, a GENTLEMAN of Kappa Pi Beta will adopt an agenda that proactively seeks to defy the stereotypes of the typical fraternity and create the ideals of unity within the community. By these premises, a stronger voice in representation among Asian Americans will generate.
Purpose
The Kappa Pi Beta Fraternity is an Asian American-founded service and social fraternity dedicated to the needs of the community alongside a commitment of higher learning, the promotion of the traditional Asian values of respect and discipline, and the overall essence of unity among all people of different background.
Philanthropy
  Asian Americans are generally not seen as overweight compared to the rest of the U.S. population. However, they are actually at a greater risk of developing diabetes, as Asian Americans often develop diabetes at a lower BMI. Furthermore, Asian Americans have the highest proportion of undiagnosed diabetes among all ethnic and racial groups (at 51 percent). Currently, 60% of the world diabetic population is Asian. Our Fraternity seeks to actively educate and work with the American Diabetes Association, through volunteering and fundraising, to build awareness and combat this growing concern among our community.
  American Diabetes Association
The American Diabetes Association is a United States-based association working to fight the consequences of diabetes and to help those affected by diabetes and as Brothers of Kappa Pi Beta Fraternity, Inc. we actively partake in the ADA’s events and make semi-annual donations from our Chapters.
Fraternal Facts
Motto: Unity is the Beginning of Brotherhood
Colors: Red, Black, Charcoal Grey
Fraternal Classification: Social and Service
Mascot: Phoenix
Founding Date: March 16, 2000
Founding Campus: Northern Illinois University
Charter Date: November 16, 2019

Marwood is a Cooperative House founded in 1936 and located on 136 Littleton St. for undergraduate men at Purdue University. Its members live together in a house which they cooperatively manage, control and maintain. 
Marwood strives to maintain a living arrangement that is comfortable and available at a low cost. It plans activities that are enjoyable yet socially responsible. It values wise financial decisions and prudent long-term planning to ensure a sound future for the organization. It desires alumni who are well-informed, active in alumni functions, financially supportive, and willing to lend experience and advice.
Members of Marwood strive to be successful, well-rounded individuals. They place the utmost emphasis upon academics and brotherhood. They are ethical and respectful of all individuals. They are active in their housing organization and dedicated to its mission. They are brothers to one another and proud of their affiliation with Marwood and Purdue University

column3: Boiler ATA Martial Arts of Purdue
column6:
We are a club under the American Taekwondo Association that practices Songahm Taekwondo. Saturday trainings occur from 10:00-11:30 and focus on Traditional Forms, Weapons Forms, Self-Defense, and General Fitness. 
  Meetings during the week occur Monday through Thursday at McFall's Black Belt Academy.
White-Green belt forms: 6:00-6:45pm
Sparing: 6:45-7:15pm
Purple+ forms: 7:15-8:00pm

Make friends, then beat them up!
At Boiler Blade, we host and run a full contact, free to play, medieval combat sport. Battle games occur on campus at Krach lawn every Saturday from 2pm to 6pm. We play games such as capture the flag, team deathmatch, and more!
We use foam weapons, such as swords, shields, spears, bows, and axes. For new fighters, we have loaner weapons available for use. We host build sessions for those interested in having their own customized weapons. We also have training sessions for those who want to get better.
Our rule sets are based on the foam combat sports Dagorhir and Belegarth. We also participate in outside events in the foam fighting community such as Oktoberfest, War, Wolfpack Opener, and more. It's great for bonding, teambuilding, and practice against those outside of our field. On occasion we also host semesterly tournaments with prizes!
So come and join Boiler Blade! Make friends or bring them, team up with them or fight them! See our trebuchet launch! And most importantly, have fun!
Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/PC8XHDTGNG
Instagram :https://www.instagram.com/boilerblade/
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCa8gbGOYnhIYls1TrKJ1mhw
More Questions?
Visit our office on Krach Leadership Center's second floor;
Mondays: 3:00-4:15 PM
Wednesdays: 6:00-8:30 PM
Thursdays: 5:45-7:00 PM

Combat:
Armored Combat (involves wearing chainmail and other protective gear while using wooden weapons)
Rapier Combat (this is the medieval version of fencing and involves rapiers, a thicker/heavier fencing sword that's dulled at the end) **It is recommended to bring your own fencing mask if you own one so the mask is more close-fitting and therefore more safe to fight in**
Other Medieval Arts can be found at events, such as our annual spring event, that will be posted: Dance Team (we mostly perform English Country dances, where if you can walk you can dance, as well as medieval Italian dances - Instruction available before every dance), Printmaking, Sewing/Fiber Work, Illumination and Calligraphy, Textile work, Archery, Axe Throwing
Fighter practice (heavy & rapier) is in the Purdue Armory (812 3rd St, West Lafayette, IN 47907) every Wednesday from 8-10pm. If you are interested in other activities, contact the club president at mdesmang@purdue.edu
The Medieval Society is closely associated with the local branch of the Society of Creative Anachronism (SCA), and thanks to their help we have an environment that is ideal for students to learn and explore their interest in various activities from the Middle Ages.

The purpose of the Boxing Club is to teach students self-discipline and self-defense through the art of boxing. The Boxing Club also promotes social cohesiveness among fellow Purdue students. Boxing will be used as a tool to build self-esteem, self-confidence, and teamwork abilities.
Typical schedule is below. However, confirm that you are on our mailing list before arriving at the location. Occasionally practice will be canceled due to unforeseen circumstances. Official practice schedule will be posted on our social media every week.
Tuesday and Thursday: 6 - 7 am at Co-rec Boxing Room in Basement (Room MP #2) 
Check out our social media (@purdue_boxing) or contact purdueboxing@gmail.com for more information.

The purpose of this organization is to provide training and instruction in the martial art of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.
- Open to all students of all experience levels
- Wear gym shorts/leggings and moisture wicking t-shirt/rashguard (both without pockets)
- Trim your nails and practice good hygiene
- Do not wear any jewelry (e.g. rings, necklaces, watches etc.) 
- We do not take attendance. Nevertheless, the more you train the better you get. It is your personal decision.
If you are interested in the club just show up ready to train and with a good attitude. Make sure to tell the instructor that you are new to the club. We understand that some might end class late so we have tolerance for being reasonably late.
