 You can submit 10 names per form but can submit as many times as you need to complete your nominations)
  The Emily Mauzy Vogel Sophomore Leadership Development Conference is held annually in September.  Sponsored by the Student Activities and Organizations area of the Office of the Dean of Students, the EMV Conference is made possible by a gift from Purdue alumnus Robert Mauzy. EMV is an overnight conference held at Camp Tecumseh just 30 minutes from Purdue. This conference includes topics such as diversity appreciation, networking for leadership, running effective meetings, and leadership styles. Faculty, staff, student organization presidents, and past EMV attendees are invited every spring to nominate freshmen who show potential for leadership.
  Former EMV participants are among the most involved students on campus and can be seen leading many student organizations at Purdue. EMV alumni have included past Purdue Student Government Presidents and Student Trustees.  As Purdue alumni they are very vocal about their EMV experience being a factor in their personal and leadership development.
  The 21st Annual Emily Mauzy Vogel Sophomore Leadership Development Conference will be held Friday, September 9 and Saturday, September 10, 2011 at Camp Tecumseh.

Fraternities, sororities, and cooperatives have a long history at Purdue University.  All provide students with great opportunities to build relationships, find a community, and get involved at Purdue. 
Fraternities and sororities have been a part of Purdue's campus for more than 130 years, where they've continuously been challenging students to achieve greater heights intellectually, personally, and professionally.  Our fraternity and sorority community is known to be one of the largest in the nation and strives to maintain a balanced life based on four principles:
Friendship
Scholarship
Leadership
Service
Currently, Purdue is home to 81 fraternities and sororities.
Members of fraternities and sororities are involved in a variety of programs which enhance their college experience.  In fact, members of fraternities and sororities report having a better overall undergraduate experience while at Purdue than non-members.  
Cooperative houses have been a part of Purdue University for 75 years.  In a cooperative house, students live and work together to promote friendship, leadership, and life skills. Currently, Purdue is home to 11 cooperative houses - 4 men's houses and 7 women's houses.
Learn more at https://www.purdue.edu/fscl/ 
Note:
On this page you will find forms and information regarding fraternities, sororities and cooperatives at Purdue University.  It is NOT necessary to be a member of this page.  When logged into BoilerLink, you do have access to the information provided here or from the Fraternity, Sorority and Cooperative Life Office. Membership in the organization on BoilerLink is limited to the staff members in the office for consistency on co-curricular transcripts. If you have any questions or are interested in joining an organization please feel free to contact our office at 765-494-5990.

This annual celebration grows bigger and better every year with more than 30 events including inflatables, movies, cultural events, cookouts, athletic events, and Grand Prix racing festivities.
Dozens of Purdue University student organizations and departments are teaming up to provide substance-free activities for students during the annual Grand Prix celebration.
Grand Prix Week (Alternative) is a program designed to offer substance-free events to the Purdue campus community during Grand Prix week (April 16-23). Grand Alternative was started in 1998 by the Wesley Foundation at Purdue (United Methodist Student Center) under the leadership of the Reverend Steve Cain, and student Amy Pritchard. 12 student groups hosted six events during the week prior to Grand Prix.
The Student Activities and Organizations office has served as the central office of the Grand Alternative initiative since 2001.  
The primary goal of Grand Prix Week (Alternative) is to empower student organization leaders to help provide solutions to high-risk and underage drinking problems at Purdue. By providing substance-free choices for Purdue students, the intent is that fewer acts of violence and vandalism will occur and fewer negative consequences from alcohol use will occur.

The National Pan-Hellenic Council, Incorporated (NPHC) is currently composed of nine (9) International Greek letter Sororities and Fraternities: Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc. Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc., Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc., Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc., Iota Phi Theta Fraternity, Inc., Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc., Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc. and Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc. NPHC promotes interaction through forums, meetings and other mediums for the exchange of information and engages in cooperative programming and initiatives through various activities and functions.
On May 10, 1930, on the campus of Howard University, in Washington DC, the National Pan-Hellenic Council was formed as a permanent organization with the following charter members: Omega Psi Phi and Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternities, and Alpha Kappa Alpha, Delta Sigma Theta and Zeta Phi Beta Sororities. In 1931, Alpha Phi Alpha and Phi Beta Sigma Fraternities joined the Council. Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority joined in 1937 and Iota Phi Theta Fraternity completed the list of member organizations in 1997.
The stated purpose and mission of the organization in 1930 was “Unanimity of thought and action as far as possible in the conduct of Greek letter collegiate fraternities and sororities, and to consider problems of mutual interest to its member organizations.” Early in 1937, the organization was incorporated under the laws of the State of Illinois and became known as “The National Pan-Hellenic Council, Incorporated.”
  Previously the Black Greek Council (BGC), the Purdue Chapter has been affiliated with the National Pan-Hellenic Council, Inc. since 2000. From it's inception, the local affiliates have made great strides to carry out our motto of "Where there is unity, there is strength."

Work collaboratively with other segments of the University to promote the personal and intellectual development of students; and
Assist in creating a University environment perceived as human and responsive to student concerns.

adworks is a student-run advertising agency within the W. P. Carey School of Business. Each semester we complete different projects by partnering with local agencies and other organizations to develop multi-media advertising campaigns. adworks provides businesses with marketing deliverables. From graphic design and logo making, to top-to-bottom branding and strategy. We are the future of advertising. Our organization is filled with the brightest talent and uniqueness you won't find anywhere else. As members, we develop connections amongst our fellow ASU students who share a passion for advertising, while receiving hands-on, professional experience alongside advertising experts across the valley.
Our application to be on a project team is open at the beginning of each semester. You can apply at adworksasu.com
  Interested in joining adworks?
Membership in adworks is open to all students who are enrolled in at least one (1) semester hour of University credit at ASU. We are an application-based organization since our work is done in project teams who are assigned to our partner agencies. Our application opens at the beginning of each semester. However, many of our Wednesday meetings from 6-7 pm AZ time are open to anyone and you are welcome to attend! Check SunDevilSync events to see which meetings you can attend.
Please fill out this form if you would like to be on the email list for general meetings. We can't wait to see you there!

AAM at ASU is both a program and an organization committed to the work related to the recruitment, retention and graduation of African American male students at Arizona State University. We are a community of men and women who apply ourselves to the task of self-development in an effort to realize our potential. We believe that holistic programming at the academic, civic, cultural, corporate and social levels prepares us for service to the greater community.

column3: (BLASTD) Leadership and Service Team at Barrett Downtown
column6: BLASTD makes community service accessible to college students and show them how they can get involved in their community while fostering a love for giving back that stays with them long after they graduate. We do internal events based on creating something, similar to a DIY project, that a community organization needs. We also go out into the community several times a year to volunteer at local organizations.

We are affiliated with the All Walks Project, which is a student-led nonprofit initiative here at ASU that raises awareness about human trafficking in the United States and abroad. AllWalks at ASU educates ASU students about domestic sex trafficking and how it impacts our communities.
Arizona Microcredit Initiative is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that empowers underserved entrepreneurs to start or expand businesses through business instruction, consulting services and microloans.

Barrett Choir is a singing community of friends who appreciate having choir as a creative outlet. We bring an unusual level of curiosity and a unique perspective to everything we do. We sing for the sake of singing, and while our rehearsals are informal, we care deeply about the music, one another, and giving high-quality performances. Many of the members are students in Barrett, the Honors College (and earn honors credit for their participation), but any motivated student from the university is welcome to join. Members play an important role in all aspects of the choir’s work, from choosing repertory to organizing social events to day-to-day musical decisions. We generally give two concerts each semester. One program each year is a pops concert made up mainly of student-organized solos and small ensembles. Rehearsals and performances share the joy and delight of making music together.
  AUDITION/HEARING: New members have a brief hearing for the conductor at the beginning of the semester. This involves singing simple vocal patterns, pitch-matching, and singing a familiar song like “Happy Birthday.” The purpose is mainly to determine the most appropriate voice part for you to sing in the choir. 
Course Number: MUP 459 Meetings: Tuesdays and Thursdays, 4-5:15 p.m. Gammage 301
1 or 2 credits (sign up for 2 credits if possible)

Barrett, The Honors College, is a community of students within Arizona State University who enjoy the considerable resources of a premier Research I university combined with the close, personal attention provided by the staff, faculty, and deans of the highest ranked honors college in the nation.

The honors college experience is available to students in an undergraduate degree program at any of the four metropolitan Phoenix campuses of ASU - Downtown, Polytechnic, Tempe, and West as well as online.

Barrett students benefit from being part of a fully developed four-year residential community and enjoy distinctive honors-only internship, research, and travel opportunities. The unique honors curriculum integrates seamlessly into their ASU degree requirements, while a three-pronged advising system and a dedicated core of honors faculty are in place to ensure a deeply supportive environment.

After graduation, Barrett students attend the best graduate schools, have tremendous success in national fellowship competitions, and accept positions with prominent non-profit and Fortune 500 companies.

column3: BLAST Leadership and Service Team Tempe
column6: The BLAST Leadership and Service Team (or BLAST as members affectionately call it) was founded in the fall 2006 semester. BLAST emphasizes providing leadership and service opportunities to its members through Social Service, Leadership Development, and Signature Events. The team works to create and organize new events that will build a strong community among Barrett students, past and present, and lay the foundation for longstanding traditions unique to Barrett, The Honors College. BLAST also supports the following Barrett Signature events: Family Weekend, Homecoming, Centennial Lecture, Honors Lectures, Rhodes Lecture, the Honors Thesis Symposium, Graduate Reception, and Convocation.

This first-generation club was created for Barrett students and ASU first-generation students to develop and grow them professionally, academically, and socially. Open to all students, especially to those whose parents have not graduated from college as well as those not familiar with college and the opportunities that may be available to them as first-generation students.
Look out for our events posted here and join our Discord: https://discord.gg/qMWxzNXPTx

The Honors College Council at Barrett, also known as HCC, is composed of elected students who work together to foster a community within Barrett, the Honors College. Working closely with other organizations, the HCC aims to provide Barrett students with numerous social, cultural, and community service events at little to no cost to the students. Some of our programs include Advocacy and Outreach for Barrett Students Class Connections Events Inter-Community Service Involvement and Engagement with other Barrett Student Organizations ...and MUCH MUCH MORE! HCC is always looking for ways to improve the Barrett experience!

Through the Barrett Mentoring Program, first year students are able to select their mentor group (comprised of sophomores, juniors, seniors, and alumni) and become a part of the Barrett Poly family. Mentors provide guidance, encourage involvement in Barrett and ASU activities, and help ease the transition to university life. Students choose their mentor group during Mentor Rush during the Fall Welcome Week in August prior, and participate in events with their entire mentor group throughout the year.

adworks is a student-run advertising agency within the W. P. Carey School of Business. Each semester we complete different projects by partnering with local agencies and other organizations to develop multi-media advertising campaigns. adworks provides businesses with marketing deliverables. From graphic design and logo making, to top-to-bottom branding and strategy. We are the future of advertising. Our organization is filled with the brightest talent and uniqueness you won't find anywhere else. As members, we develop connections amongst our fellow ASU students who share a passion for advertising, while receiving hands-on, professional experience alongside advertising experts across the valley.
Our application to be on a project team is open at the beginning of each semester. You can apply at adworksasu.com
  Interested in joining adworks?
Membership in adworks is open to all students who are enrolled in at least one (1) semester hour of University credit at ASU. We are an application-based organization since our work is done in project teams who are assigned to our partner agencies. Our application opens at the beginning of each semester. However, many of our Wednesday meetings from 6-7 pm AZ time are open to anyone and you are welcome to attend! Check SunDevilSync events to see which meetings you can attend.
Please fill out this form if you would like to be on the email list for general meetings. We can't wait to see you there!

column3: African Students Association at Arizona State University
column6: Welcome to the African Students Association. The African Student Association (AFSA) is an organization that was created out of the need for unity, camaraderie, fellowship and the desire to work together. AFSA is open to anybody that is interested in learning about and enjoying African culture. AFSA prides itself in creating a sense of community for students of African descent on campus and strives to educate its campus community on Africa-related topics. The African Students' Association aims to be a social forum for all students of African descent as well as all students who are interested in sharing the African experience at Arizona State University. Article II – Non-Discrimination Statement Membership and all privileges, including voting and officer positions, must be extended to all students without regard to age, ethnicity, gender, disability, color, national origin, race, religion, sexual orientation, or veteran status. Title IX of the Educational Amendments of 1972, Section 106.14, makes an exception for social fraternities and sororities, in regard to gender, for membership criteria. Religious student organizations will not be denied registration solely because they limit membership or leadership positions to students who share the same religious beliefs. These groups, however, may not discriminate in membership or leadership on any other prohibited basis (i.e., age, ethnicity, gender, disability, color, national origin, race, sexual orientation, or veteran status).

The AIGA Grad at Design School is a group for graduate students in the Masters of Visual Communications at Arizona State University. This group provides resources and events for graduate-level design students and is an advocate for improving the MVCD program while creating a community of collaborators in our field.

We seek to provide a kind community of musical album discussion, where members will discuss one album or more each week after listening to it, in a similar fashion to a book club. This is a place for people of all kinds to gather to listen and discuss all things music.
Feel free to come to any meeting! We meet Wednesdays at 7:00 PM. Even if you can't make the meetings, feel free to join the Discord below and discuss music with us! 
Join our Discord! https://discord.gg/BrAyfNg

The American Indian Art Association (AIAA) was created to support and promote the arts within the Indigenous community at ASU. AIAA has a commitment to strengthening Indigenous representation within Herberger Institute for Design and the Arts by fostering relationships between those who identify as American Indian/Native Alaskan/First Nations/Native American/Indigenous+ or those who otherwise support the goals and mission of AIAA. AIAA will adhere to this promise through prioritizing inclusion, collaboration, academic support, and creativity.

The American Indian Graduate Association (AIGSA) aspires to serve a critical role in promoting the professional development and cultural awareness of its graduate and undergraduate members in a collective, inclusive, and social environment at all four campuses. By fostering an atmosphere that promotes intellectual engagement, academic support, and a social network we hope to cultivate future leaders with a collective version focused on highlighting Indigenous concerns on a local, national, and international scale at Arizona State University.

Andaaz is the official Competitive Bollywood Fusion Dance Team at ASU! 
Mission: We wish to unite passionate dancers to form a dedicated family while creating a community on campus focused on representing South Asian culture and dance.
Description:
Andaaz is Arizona's one and only Competitive Collegiate Coed Bollywood Fusion Dance Team. We emphasize dance, community, and culture not only on campus but across the country. We compete nationally amongst other collegiate teams from other universities.
Competitions allow our team to grow as a community while networking with other dancers that are ignited with the same passion for South Asian dance as we are. This is a unique team that teaches and values time management, dedication, and culture. We are excited to have you all try out and become part of our family! If you dance, have dance on your mind, or in your hearts, we want you to come join us!
Please support and follow us on our Instagram @asuandaaz, Facebook: Andaaz, Tiktok @andaaz_asu, and Youtube pages to stay up to date with information regarding tryouts, competitions, and other local events Andaaz will be performing, participating and hosting. Help us show the nation what Andaaz is all about!

Asian Performance Inclusive Dance Diversity is a dance club focusing on Asian dance styles (fan, lion) but not limited to hip hop, aerial, & modern. Although dance is our main point, we include performance styles such as vocal and modeling. APIDD is open to everyone & will have performance, volunteer, and educational opportunities. This club is a safe space for self growth, discovering friendships, and learning about different asian cultures through the element of performance. Consider APIDD a club for dance, vocal, and modeling performance. (We are MAINLY dance).
  https://linktr.ee/APIDanceDiversity 🔱

The club is a social platform to introduce students to the Middle Eastern and Arab cultures. It is also a platform for networking between students and alumni through different hosted events. The club will be working on networking with Arab Leaders to promote leadership skills to other Thunderbird students and to enhance networking within the Arab Elite. The club has to promote engagement and better communicate cultural difference to be able within Thunderbird's students. In addition, the club will be able to promote empathy, peace and the ability to be part of a global society that take responsibilities to promote a better future by managing people and different recourses.

The Arab Student Association (ASA)'s mission and purpose are to represent Arab culture in an honorable manner while maintaining a social community with Arab students across all campuses. In addition, we seek to maximize the society's contribution to campus diversity while helping to bridge the gap between cultures at ASU.

International Students Club is a friendship organization for all international students. We befriend and help international students during their time here in the U.S.A. through practical help, social and recreational activities, trips, English conversation classes, and Bible studies. International students of every nationality, race, and religion are welcome

Asian Business Leaders Association was originally founded in 1994 by a small group of dedicated business students and still continues to meet today following many successful years. We serve the needs of career-oriented students through academic support, leadership opportunities, and social environments where members can interact with the campus and community leaders.
  The main emphasis of the organization is to educate members about various Asian cultures in the business setting. We accomplish these goals by holding weekly meetings where we discuss anything from cultural barriers to resume workshops as well as guest speakers from both alumni and from companies.
  In such meetings, we discuss various challenges one might face such as the cultural differences between corporate life and the culture members may have been raised in. We also have meetings with invited professionals and alumni to come and speak, letting members engage with professionals first hand in order to gain knowledge and connections, furthering their professional development.In addition to this, we hold social events throughout the school year to foster friendships and community within the organization.
  We strive to improve our members' cultural awareness between the business world and themselves while giving them a social space to connect and find a sense of community.

Supporting tactics:
Host virtual (until able to return to in-person) meetings with underrepresented business leaders that allow them to talk about their career and their journey as a minority employee.
Host Town Halls where perspective sharing is the objective. Have underrepresented minorities in the program share their background and what it took to get them to where they are today as well as having our allies share their perspectives.
Community outreach and engagement with underrepresented groups about their hopes, and dreams and how to navigate their path.
Work with underrepresented groups and their respective chambers of commerce to acquire consulting projects for their members and deliver pro bono work to be part of uplifting the local minority business communities.
Establish pipelines for our members and mentees with top companies focused on attracting, recruiting and retaining diversity and inclusion minded individuals to help shape their businesses moving forward.
Collaborate with minority groups in other Business Schools to host educative sessions (panel discussions etc) and social events.

We, the members of the AFRICAN Ph.D. NETWORK, out of a commonly identified need for the establishment of a family of scholars with roots in the African continent and the immutable belief that, as kinsmen, we must gather not because the moonlight is not visible from our individual compounds but because it is good to do so, agree to the regulations and policies of Arizona State University and establish this Constitution to govern the matters within
our organization.

Agape is a college ministry of Crossroads Lutheran Church in Queen Creek/San Tan Valley. Agape College Ministry serves as a supportive home away from home for college students. Agape is a community where one's faith is challenged and "re-owned" through sense of community, exploration, and friendship that develop over the semesters. For some people Agape is a significant core faith community during their college years while for others they simply enjoy some of the activities and events we sponsor.

column3: American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) Student Chapter at Arizona State University
column6: The American Institute of Chemical Engineers is a professional development club whose aim is to connect students with industry and academic professionals alike. Our work supersedes the Tempe borders, as we continue to build a talent pipeline which will benefit future communities and technical advancements for the coming years.

Delta Sigma Pi is a co-ed professional fraternity organized to foster the study of business in universities; to encourage scholarship, social activity and the association of students for their mutual advancement by research and practice; to promote closer affiliation between the commercial world and students of commerce, and to further a higher standard of commercial ethics and culture and the civic and commercial welfare of the community.
  DSP is an organization for undergraduate business students, with recruitment taking place at the beginning of each semester. If you are interested, please check out our Instagram or Website for more information.

Rotaract is a Rotary International sponsored service organization for young adults focused on community service, international relations, and leadership. Members have the opportunity to meet and do service with Rotarians in the Phoenix area, building their network of business and professional leaders. Our club has three sister clubs and twin clubs in South Africa, Turkey, Ukraine, and India, but we have access to a database for connecting with over 250,000 Rotaractors in over 10,000 clubs. Rotaract is a great way to build your resume, make international friends, and become a great leader.
When you request to join the organization here on SunDevilSync, you'll be added to our email subscription list. You can unsubscribe from this list at any time using the link at the bottom of our bi-weekly newsletters.
  If you would like to keep in better touch with current members, we suggest that you join our Slack to share ideas, ask questions, and stay up-to-date!

Science Detectives is a non-profit inquiry-based educational science program for elementary school students. We aim to introduce students to a wide breadth of science at a young age while providing them with engaging role models within an inclusive and fun atmosphere. Our volunteers teach students real scientific theory with interactive experiments, laying a solid foundation for their future science classes.
If you choose to volunteer with Science Detectives, you can expect to cultivate your love for teaching and solidify the foundational science concepts you learn in your undergraduate courses.                                                             Learn more: https://www.instagram.com/sciencedetectives

column3: SIAM Student Chapter at Arizona State University
column6: An interdisciplinary community based on the active exchange of ideas in industrial and applied mathematics, aiming to generate interest and promote research in the field while building a network with local industries and researchers in academia.

column3: Student Alumni Association at Arizona State University
column6: The Student Alumni Association is one of the largest student organizations at Arizona State University. We are responsible for maintaining some of the oldest traditions at ASU as well as promoting school spirit and encouraging the pride of ASU in every student and in the community. The memories that you make with the SAA will last a lifetime, from Echo from the Buttes to guarding the "A" from U of A Wildcats. Join and be involved in SAA and make wonderful long-lasting memories.

Devil Data Science is an organization that desires to help people understand the world better through data. We do this by providing a community for like-minded students to gather, putting on events like technical workshops and guest speaker Q&A sessions, and partnering with employers who offer interesting applications of data science. We hope to see you at a future meeting!

Any Skill Level And FREE. 
We'll teach you how to dance Tango!
  The Tango Club at ASU is open to all students interested in learning and dancing Argentine Tango. Argentine tango is an improvisational, social dance from Buenos Aires. We host a weekly practica, or open dance practice session, on Thursdays from 7:30pm to 9:30pm. Joining the ASU Tango Club is FREE. Come check us out! No partner or experience required. Find Tango Club at ASU on Facebook or @tangoclubatasu on Instagram and feel free to message any current officers if you have questions! We also host events, such as workshops with professional guest dancers and teachers, milongas (social dances), and various other community-building events.
  Join our Discord server here: https://discord.gg/yaQekwr2Np

Join us at the Union Stage in the Memorial Union Monday nights from 6:30-8:00PM! Please check out our event page for more information on meeting dates and extra events. We teach many line dances and swing dancing skills to all dance levels! We are also open to performance or teaching opportunities. If you have any questions, send us an email!
https://linktr.ee/thecdd_asu

A branch of the United Nations Foundation and UNA-USA, UNA at ASU is dedicated to building an understanding of, and support for, the ideals and work of the UN among the ASU community. We are also devoted to educating, inspiring, and mobilizing our members to support the principles and vital work of the United Nations, strengthening the United Nations system, promoting constructive United States leadership in that system and achieving the goals of the United Nations Charter.
  Members of UNA at ASU act as ambassadors for the United Nations and work to educate themselves and others on the vital work of the UN. Across the nation, a network of young UN supporters are mobilizing to build a bright future for our generation and inspire young students to advocate for the global issues that they care most deeply about.
  By joining UNA at ASU, members receive access to tools and resources to advocate for the UN and the opportunity to be lifelong leaders. Our mission is to help students build leadership skills that will propel them forward while making a difference, learn how to meet with elected officials to talk about the issues that matter most, and dive into some of the most pressing issues facing the world today.
  Interested in collaborating? Please email us at una.usa.asu@gmail.com and we will get back to you as soon as we can!

Advancing Women in Construction encourages construction related fields as a career path. AWIC provides both social and academic support, facilitates industry exposure and leadership opportunities for students interested in the field. These events focus on the construction, engineering, and architecture fields, but everyone is welcome!

We are the student chapter of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA). We participate in the AIAA international Design/Build/Fly (DBF) RC Aircraft competition. We also host speakers, and run field trips.

column3: American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) Student Chapter at Arizona State University
column6: The American Institute of Chemical Engineers is a professional development club whose aim is to connect students with industry and academic professionals alike. Our work supersedes the Tempe borders, as we continue to build a talent pipeline which will benefit future communities and technical advancements for the coming years.

column3: American Society of Civil Engineers - ASCE
column6: The objective of the American Society of Civil Engineers student chapter at Arizona State University shall be the development of a professional consciousness; to afford an opportunity for civil engineering students to become acquainted and to practice working together effectively; to promote a spirit of congeniality among them; and to establish friendly contact with the engineering profession. As the student chapter of ASCE we participate in various student engineering competitions, volunteer activities, and professional/student development and interaction opportunities.

The Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) represents all students pursuing or interested in biomedical engineering. We build up our community by giving students opportunities for professional development and community service, creating an atmosphere to socialize with like-minded peers, and establishing networks with faculty and industry professionals.
Stay updated by checking out our website and joining our email list!

CodeDevils at Arizona State University is a student-run, inclusive organization that supports ASU students in their software development journey. As one of ASU's largest organizations, we cater primarily to online students, fostering a thriving virtual community where members can learn, collaborate, and grow.
  Our mission is to help members enhance their software development skills through engaging projects and provide resume-building experiences while offering valuable resources and opportunities for growth. We aim to advance ASU's commitment to innovation by cultivating a wide range of projects for members to participate in and encouraging creativity, collaboration, and continuous learning within those projects.
  CodeDevils offers a range of exciting opportunities to our members, including exclusive workshops with industry partners, guest speakers from renowned companies and institutions, weekly HackerRank challenges, and hackathons. Additionally, we provide the chance to collaborate on resume-worthy projects and participate in weekly debugging sessions that make problem-solving enjoyable.
  Meetings, projects, guest speakers, and competitions are all organized and conducted virtually to ensure maximum accessibility and engagement for our members, regardless of their mode of attendance at ASU. Our commitment to the online format enables us to create unique opportunities for all students interested in software development and technology in general.
  To become a member of CodeDevils, make sure to join us on SunDevilSync and connect with our vibrant community through our Discord server. Embrace the future of software development and learning with CodeDevils, and take your skills to new heights.

column3: Design-Build Institute of America Chapter at ASU
column6: The DBIA Chapter at ASU was created in 2010 with the purpose of bringing ASU Construction, Engineering, and Architecture students to become more familiar with design-build through the national student competition, workshops, and more.

Engineers Without Borders at ASU is a non-profit humanitarian organization established to partner with developing communities to improve their quality of life through implementation of environmentally and economically sustainable engineering projects. This is accomplished by connecting university students, ASU faculty, and industry professionals in planning and implementing engineering projects.
Our meetings are on Wednesday at 7 PM.
To get involved, sign up for our newsletter here: https://ewbasu.org/

Eta Kappa Nu is a unique membership organization dedicated to encouraging and recognizing excellence in the electrical and computer engineering fields. Members consist of students, alumni, and other professionals who have demonstrated exceptional academic and professional accomplishments.

Fulton Ambassadors is a paraprofessional organization of students who dedicate their time to share personal experiences and the opportunities available in the Ira Fulton Schools of Engineering to potential students and the surrounding community.
Our application to become a Fulton Ambassador is not open right now. 
Interested in joining? https://forms.office.com/r/j63yeH4cYX. You will be notified when our application opens.

column3: Ambedkar Periyar Study Circle at ASU
column6: This club strives to create a space within ASU that nurtures Ambedkarite ideals and strengthens community bonds. Our focus on social justice and equality drives engaging conversations and projects, influenced by the wisdom of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, Periyar E.V. Ramasamy, and Jyotirao Phule. We facilitate vibrant discussions, interactive workshops, thought-stirring film screenings, and a variety of events. Through exploring themes like caste, gender, and religion, we intend to raise awareness and encourage positive transformations. Our purpose is to cultivate meaningful discussions, events, and initiatives centered around social justice, equality, and empowerment. We aspire to ignite positive change and establish a more inclusive and fair campus atmosphere by spreading awareness and knowledge of these principles among students.

column3: American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
column6: This club is a student-run chapter of the American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology to foster student involvement in research, increase scientific literacy in the general community, and promote career development through scholarship and networking.

column3: American Society of Highway Engineers at ASU

column6:
Asian Performance Inclusive Dance Diversity is a dance club focusing on Asian dance styles (fan, lion) but not limited to hip hop, aerial, & modern. Although dance is our main point, we include performance styles such as vocal and modeling. APIDD is open to everyone & will have performance, volunteer, and educational opportunities. This club is a safe space for self growth, discovering friendships, and learning about different asian cultures through the element of performance. Consider APIDD a club for dance, vocal, and modeling performance. (We are MAINLY dance).
  https://linktr.ee/APIDanceDiversity 🔱

Roundnet is a fast growing sport popularized by the company Spikeball. It involves two teams of two, a yellow ball, and a net a yard in diameter. For more information on what "Spikeball" is, just search it on your favorite search engine or on YouTube. Devils Roundnet is a growing community of players, ranging from competitive to beginner. We are always looking for new people to play with, even if you've never even heard of the sport!
Come check us out! We play every Tuesday from 7pm to 9pm at the North Fields on Dorsey Lane and every Thursday from 7pm to 9pm on the SDFC west fields (as long as no special occasion had been stated in the GroupMe or on Instagram).
Follow us on Instagram @devilsroundnet_asu
If you would like to be added to the Devils Roundnet GroupMe, go to the link in our Instagram bio, or email me at wtuneliu@asu.edu

We have moved all our activities to our website https://arizonaoutdoorsclub.com/registration
  For joining the club and for more info, visit our website or 
Instagram
Discord
    The Arizona Outdoors Club, based at Arizona State University, is a member-driven organization comprised of a large variety of people including students, faculty, staff, and alumni who are interested in outdoor adventures, road trips, and social gatherings. Our members range from highly experienced veterans of various disciplines to first-timers looking to try something new or travel to new places. All members are encouraged to suggest fun, exciting, and challenging activities! One never knows what they will be doing next. The adventures never end!

SKY MEDITATION empowers your potential through scientifically-proven meditation and yoga techniques. Our thrice-semesterly retreats offer deep peace, happiness, and lasting friendships. We provide a safe space to confront life's challenges and manage stress. With diverse events and workshops throughout the semester, we guide you towards inner freedom.
Grow stronger in love with us.

Accessibility Coalition's purpose is to support the disability community at ASU, including students, staff, faculty, and administration in addition to our surrounding community and social spheres, to combat ableism and misconceptions about disability. This is accomplished through leadership, advocacy, and community-building activities intended to promote accessibility and inclusion.

column3: ACHA Men’s Ice Hockey Club at Arizona State University
column6: To provide a top level hockey program to students at ASU. We are focused on providing our student athletes with a great experience in a club sport environment while the pursue their degree at ASU.

Before joining, please read all instructions below. If you do not follow all instructions, your membership request on our Discord server will respectfully be ignored. Thank you!
  Adventure Devils is a student organization at Arizona State University's Tempe Campus. We are dedicated to bringing students together for outdoor activity, service, and education. Whether you are entirely new to the outdoors or a seasoned adventurer, this club caters to your longing for serious trips in the back country and wilderness areas of the Southwest! What are you waiting for? Come adventure with us!
We do not charge dues. To join and be considered a member, you must complete the New Member Registration Form and press the join button here on SunDevilSync. NOTE: you are unable to attend off campus events without having completed the New Member Form. After you have completed the New Member Registration form and having successfully joined our club, you must join our Discord server and send us a message in the Membership Approval channel with your full name, letting us know that you have successfully filled out the form and have joined our club on SunDevilSync. 
We use a Discord Server to manage all club events: https://discord.gg/rGQxueb

Alpha Epsilon Delta is the National Health Preprofessional Honor Society dedicated to the encouragement and recognition of excellence in preprofessional health scholarship, including medicine, dentistry, veterinary, and others. The society welcomes ALL students engaged in the pursuit of a professional healthcare career. AED offers opportunities for intellectual and professional development, provides a forum for students with common interests, and extends a program of service to benefit Arizona State University and the surrounding community.

The American Indian Graduate Association (AIGSA) aspires to serve a critical role in promoting the professional development and cultural awareness of its graduate and undergraduate members in a collective, inclusive, and social environment at all four campuses. By fostering an atmosphere that promotes intellectual engagement, academic support, and a social network we hope to cultivate future leaders with a collective version focused on highlighting Indigenous concerns on a local, national, and international scale at Arizona State University.

column3: American Medical Student Association - Downtown Phoenix Campus
column6:
We are a chapter of the National American Medical Student Association. The mission of AMSA-DPC is to connect members with the resources and opportunities available to help members reach their goal of being accepted into medical school. AMSA-DPC is an independent organization of physicians-in-training. Anyone who is interested in a medical career, whether you want to be a dentist, pharmacist, emergency-room physician, etc, are welcome to join! AMSA-DPC will be engaging in various volunteer opportunities throughout the community. We will also hold meetings to keep all members informed as well as socials to provide opportunities for everyone to meet new people while having a great time!
Meeting Schedule:
Bi-Weekly, 5:30 pm on Mondays in person at UCENT 282
FIRST MEETING: TBA in Events

International Students Club is a friendship organization for all international students. We befriend and help international students during their time here in the U.S.A. through practical help, social and recreational activities, trips, English conversation classes, and Bible studies. International students of every nationality, race, and religion are welcome

column3: African Students Association at Arizona State University
column6: Welcome to the African Students Association. The African Student Association (AFSA) is an organization that was created out of the need for unity, camaraderie, fellowship and the desire to work together. AFSA is open to anybody that is interested in learning about and enjoying African culture. AFSA prides itself in creating a sense of community for students of African descent on campus and strives to educate its campus community on Africa-related topics. The African Students' Association aims to be a social forum for all students of African descent as well as all students who are interested in sharing the African experience at Arizona State University. Article II – Non-Discrimination Statement Membership and all privileges, including voting and officer positions, must be extended to all students without regard to age, ethnicity, gender, disability, color, national origin, race, religion, sexual orientation, or veteran status. Title IX of the Educational Amendments of 1972, Section 106.14, makes an exception for social fraternities and sororities, in regard to gender, for membership criteria. Religious student organizations will not be denied registration solely because they limit membership or leadership positions to students who share the same religious beliefs. These groups, however, may not discriminate in membership or leadership on any other prohibited basis (i.e., age, ethnicity, gender, disability, color, national origin, race, sexual orientation, or veteran status).

ALM is the first Muslim-interest fraternity in America which seeks to connect, build, and sustain a lifelong brotherhood through excellence in character, excellence in service, excellence in intellectual standard, and excellence in creativity amongst all members, chapters, conglomerates, and associates.

column3: All Things Gaming at ASU Online
column6:
Our goal is to get both on campus and online students to engage in group social activities. We host a discord where you can meet other fellow gamers or see our posted events ranging from online Friday night magic to call of duty Sunday. 
https://discord.gg/k63zdGXfeJ

Agape is a college ministry of Crossroads Lutheran Church in Queen Creek/San Tan Valley. Agape College Ministry serves as a supportive home away from home for college students. Agape is a community where one's faith is challenged and "re-owned" through sense of community, exploration, and friendship that develop over the semesters. For some people Agape is a significant core faith community during their college years while for others they simply enjoy some of the activities and events we sponsor.

The American Indian Graduate Association (AIGSA) aspires to serve a critical role in promoting the professional development and cultural awareness of its graduate and undergraduate members in a collective, inclusive, and social environment at all four campuses. By fostering an atmosphere that promotes intellectual engagement, academic support, and a social network we hope to cultivate future leaders with a collective version focused on highlighting Indigenous concerns on a local, national, and international scale at Arizona State University.

Amnesty International is the world's largest grassroots human rights organization. Our purpose is to protect people wherever justice, freedom, truth, and dignity are denied. Amnesty International investigates and exposes human rights abuses, gives activists the information and tools needed to take action, and rallies activists from all 50 states to demand that policymakers protect human rights in the U.S. and around the world.

This organization provides a safe and supportive space for students on the asexual, aromantic, and agender spectrums. Events feature community building, social, and educational activities focused around these identities to help them feel welcome and valid, and an active online space cultivates a great sense of belonging among members!

To provide opportunities for current and future Sun Devils to engage and find community. This effort will reflect the robust diversity of engagement opportunities that exist throughout various platforms within EOSS.

column3: BeYou at ASU (LGBTQIA2S+ Sun Devils and Allies)
column6: The purpose of BeYou at ASU at Arizona State University is to establish a supportive environment for LGBTQIA2S+ students. This group seeks to foster an academic friendly environment and also provide a sense of community and support among its members. We also seek to advocate for the interests of LGBTQIA2S+ students and the LGBTQIA2S+ community in general, from issues related to mental health, academic issues, social issues, and political issues. LGBTQIA2S+ students face unique challenges, and we seek to unite members of the LGBTQIA2S+ community and their allies from across all of ASU’s campuses.

The Black Graduate Student Association (BGSA) at Arizona State University (ASU) dedicates itself in nurturing the unique experiences of Black graduate students through scholarship, providing development opportunities, spreading activism, participating in mentorship, and collaborating with community-based activities. BGSA aims to build the coalition of Black graduates on all four ASU campuses by increasing and advocating their presence; this is at the very heart of our vocation. BGSA provides safe and radical spaces where all scholars of color can create community at ASU and beyond.
We primarily communicate through Slack so please reach out (bgsatempe@gmail.com) if you are interested in joining!!

Black Theatre Organization’s Mission is to address issues affecting and impacting our African American/Black theatre students. We want to be able to use art to encourage social consciousness, as well as cultural awareness. We blend African American/Black cultural legacy with contemporary artistic genre. We would like to push beyond the borders of "traditional" theatre asserting ourselves as a distinctive voice in the up and coming generation while creating community and sense of belonging. Although we are an African American/Black Theatre focused Organization, we do not discriminate, and welcome all who are interested in exploring more of our culture, with the knowledge that we will be focusing on our history in theatre and community building.
  Our purpose is to serve, support and educate the African American/Black theatre community as well as all other communities while elevating knowledge and promoting unity among all ASU organizations, students, faculty and staff.

column3: Black Women in STEM at Arizona State University

column6: Changemaker Central is a student-run centralized resource hub for student involvement in entrepreneurship, civic engagement, service learning and community service that catalyzes student driven social change. We are looking for energetic students to help advance the mission of Changemaker Central: Develop and nurture students by providing resources and opportunities to inspire, catalyze and sustain student-driven social change.

We are affiliated with the All Walks Project, which is a student-led nonprofit initiative here at ASU that raises awareness about human trafficking in the United States and abroad. AllWalks at ASU educates ASU students about domestic sex trafficking and how it impacts our communities.

column3: American Enterprise Institute Club at Arizona State University
column6: The American Enterprise Institute (AEI) Club at ASU is the AEI Executive Council at ASU’s outreach arm, which seeks to connect ASU students with the AEI and its mission, public policy information, and programs, both local and national. The club also seeks to promote intellectual diversity on campus through intelligent debates on important public policy issues. The goal of the club is to assist the Executive Council in its duties at ASU, which primarily includes the organization of various events. The kinds of events include, but are not limited to: lectures or discussions with AEI scholars or local professors; private dinners with scholars, business professionals, or government officials; student debates; reading groups; and film and debate viewings. Club members will have the chance to engage directly with Executive Council members and have their voice heard as the Council plans events and makes decisions.

The American Indian Graduate Association (AIGSA) aspires to serve a critical role in promoting the professional development and cultural awareness of its graduate and undergraduate members in a collective, inclusive, and social environment at all four campuses. By fostering an atmosphere that promotes intellectual engagement, academic support, and a social network we hope to cultivate future leaders with a collective version focused on highlighting Indigenous concerns on a local, national, and international scale at Arizona State University.

column3: Asian Native Hawaiian Pacific Islanders Visionary Action
column6: Asian Native Hawaiian Pacific Islanders Visionary Action’s (AVA) mission is to ensure that the ANHPI and other marginalized communities are a part of the decision-making process and garner the appropriate resources for the population in need. We will ensure the development of nuanced solutions to both ANHPI and broader community issues. AVA aims to facilitate conversations on representation and identity by creating a close-knit community of driven students and focusing efforts on civic engagement and social and cultural awareness.

To provide opportunities for current and future Sun Devils to engage and find community. This effort will reflect the robust diversity of engagement opportunities that exist throughout various platforms within EOSS.

The Black African Coalition (BAC) is dedicated to uniting African Americans, Blacks, and allies at ASU. While representing many organizations at Arizona State University, we continue to break barriers for equal opportunity and rights for all students. Our goals are to increase enrollment, retention, and advocacy.

The Black Graduate Student Association (BGSA) at Arizona State University (ASU) dedicates itself in nurturing the unique experiences of Black graduate students through scholarship, providing development opportunities, spreading activism, participating in mentorship, and collaborating with community-based activities. BGSA aims to build the coalition of Black graduates on all four ASU campuses by increasing and advocating their presence; this is at the very heart of our vocation. BGSA provides safe and radical spaces where all scholars of color can create community at ASU and beyond.
We primarily communicate through Slack so please reach out (bgsatempe@gmail.com) if you are interested in joining!!

We are an organization comprised of business students dedicated to enhancing the academic and extracurricular experiences of those within the W. P. Carey School of Business. Our responsibilities include presiding over business organizations, orchestrating fun and engaging events for business students, and providing numerous opportunities for professional development.

Asian Business Leaders Association was originally founded in 1994 by a small group of dedicated business students and still continues to meet today following many successful years. We serve the needs of career-oriented students through academic support, leadership opportunities, and social environments where members can interact with the campus and community leaders.
  The main emphasis of the organization is to educate members about various Asian cultures in the business setting. We accomplish these goals by holding weekly meetings where we discuss anything from cultural barriers to resume workshops as well as guest speakers from both alumni and from companies.
  In such meetings, we discuss various challenges one might face such as the cultural differences between corporate life and the culture members may have been raised in. We also have meetings with invited professionals and alumni to come and speak, letting members engage with professionals first hand in order to gain knowledge and connections, furthering their professional development.In addition to this, we hold social events throughout the school year to foster friendships and community within the organization.
  We strive to improve our members' cultural awareness between the business world and themselves while giving them a social space to connect and find a sense of community.
Acacia is a social fraternity dedicated to the search of virtue, knowledge, and truth.

Supporting tactics:
Host virtual (until able to return to in-person) meetings with underrepresented business leaders that allow them to talk about their career and their journey as a minority employee.
Host Town Halls where perspective sharing is the objective. Have underrepresented minorities in the program share their background and what it took to get them to where they are today as well as having our allies share their perspectives.
Community outreach and engagement with underrepresented groups about their hopes, and dreams and how to navigate their path.
Work with underrepresented groups and their respective chambers of commerce to acquire consulting projects for their members and deliver pro bono work to be part of uplifting the local minority business communities.
Establish pipelines for our members and mentees with top companies focused on attracting, recruiting and retaining diversity and inclusion minded individuals to help shape their businesses moving forward.
Collaborate with minority groups in other Business Schools to host educative sessions (panel discussions etc) and social events.

column3:
A
ADHD Combined Hyperactive Inattentive Club
column6:
Offer students opportunities to be included in the School of Social and Behavioral Sciences
Allow students the opportunity to learn more about Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
Represent and spread awareness for ADHD
Provide resources and support for students with ADHD, family members of individuals with ADHD, and the general student body

Advancing Women in Construction encourages construction related fields as a career path. AWIC provides both social and academic support, facilitates industry exposure and leadership opportunities for students interested in the field. These events focus on the construction, engineering, and architecture fields, but everyone is welcome!

adworks is a student-run advertising agency within the W. P. Carey School of Business. Each semester we complete different projects by partnering with local agencies and other organizations to develop multi-media advertising campaigns. adworks provides businesses with marketing deliverables. From graphic design and logo making, to top-to-bottom branding and strategy. We are the future of advertising. Our organization is filled with the brightest talent and uniqueness you won't find anywhere else. As members, we develop connections amongst our fellow ASU students who share a passion for advertising, while receiving hands-on, professional experience alongside advertising experts across the valley.
Our application to be on a project team is open at the beginning of each semester. You can apply at adworksasu.com
  Interested in joining adworks?
Membership in adworks is open to all students who are enrolled in at least one (1) semester hour of University credit at ASU. We are an application-based organization since our work is done in project teams who are assigned to our partner agencies. Our application opens at the beginning of each semester. However, many of our Wednesday meetings from 6-7 pm AZ time are open to anyone and you are welcome to attend! Check SunDevilSync events to see which meetings you can attend.
Please fill out this form if you would like to be on the email list for general meetings. We can't wait to see you there!

The Afghanistan Students Association at ASU(ASA) is a student organization that promotes cultural awareness and understanding of Afghanistan's rich history, traditions, and customs among the broader ASU community and advocates for human rights issues, including women's and minority rights. It is open to every ASU student interested in learning more about Afghanistan. In addition, ASA collaborates with local and international organizations to support programs and initiatives promoting education, literacy, and human rights. The ASA's efforts aim to contribute positively to social change and create a more inclusive and equitable environment at ASU and beyond.

AAM at ASU is both a program and an organization committed to the work related to the recruitment, retention and graduation of African American male students at Arizona State University. We are a community of men and women who apply ourselves to the task of self-development in an effort to realize our potential. We believe that holistic programming at the academic, civic, cultural, corporate and social levels prepares us for service to the greater community.
AAMASU has weekly meetings on Wednesday @ 6:30pm in the Student Pavilion 323
Please notify us of your interest and we will add you to our email list or follow us on Instagram @the.aamasu
  Members Join our AAMASU GroupMe

International Students Club is a friendship organization for all international students. We befriend and help international students during their time here in the U.S.A. through practical help, social and recreational activities, trips, English conversation classes, and Bible studies. International students of every nationality, race, and religion are welcome

Agape is a college ministry of Crossroads Lutheran Church in Queen Creek/San Tan Valley. Agape College Ministry serves as a supportive home away from home for college students. Agape is a community where one's faith is challenged and "re-owned" through sense of community, exploration, and friendship that develop over the semesters. For some people Agape is a significant core faith community during their college years while for others they simply enjoy some of the activities and events we sponsor.

AGORA seeks to bring together ASU students, both national and international, in meaningful interaction, so as to understand and adapt to a new cross-cultural context.  AGORA aims to be a safe-haven for students with spiritual, emotional, psychological, and physical needs, applying biblical principles of friendship, fellowship and by praying with them.  
For general events Professors from the ASU and other experts in the field would be invited to address the students on contemporary topics relevant for university students.  AGORA will connect its members with Org Sync when such topics are being discussed.
AGORA has many social activities like meeting parks, taking a trip to the Grand Canyon, Sedona and Flagstaff, etc.
In a nutshell, AGORA seeks to bring a holistic approach to the students.

ALM is the first Muslim-interest fraternity in America which seeks to connect, build, and sustain a lifelong brotherhood through excellence in character, excellence in service, excellence in intellectual standard, and excellence in creativity amongst all members, chapters, conglomerates, and associates.

The All Saints Catholic Newman Center is the central hub for Catholic campus ministry to ASU students and faculty at the Tempe campus. Our primary mission is to foster the spiritual growth of our ASU Catholic community through Christ-centered events, speakers and activities throughout the year. We form faithful Catholics according to the intellectual, spiritual, liturgical and moral heritage of our Christian tradition, and so equip them to mature as the saints that they are called to be. Our secondary mission is to dialogue with the wider student body - those of other faiths or no faith at all - and share with them the riches of our ancient faith as handed on to us by God's own divine Son, Jesus.
Whether you are a Catholic looking to mature in your faith, a "seeker" just wanting to find out more, or looking for Christian friendships - please know that you are most welcome at Newman. Our campus is at the corner of College and University - look for the red brick church. See our calendar or subscribe to our Instagram channel @asucatholic for the latest offerings.
We especially invite you to our main weekly event - Newman Nights, with a talk and dinner - on Wednesday evenings throughout the year - no reservations needed! Every Wednesday, we have one of three events:
Newman Night: Men and Women's Small Groups: 
Embrace who you are and envision who you want to become. Join us for our highly anticipated Men's and Women's nights, held monthly on Wednesdays. Forge unbreakable bonds of brotherhood and sisterhood while exploring the profound teachings of Christian views on masculinity and femininity. Don't miss out on these transformative opportunities! Mark your calendars and find your purpose with us. Check the Google calendar for small group dates
Newman Night: Christ on Campus:
Experience the ancient and profound practice of Eucharistic Adoration, where we worship Christ in the Eucharist, fully present in body, blood, soul, and divinity. This cherished tradition stems from the collective worship we share during Mass, reinforcing our belief in Christ's true presence among us.
Countless Catholics over the ages have discovered the transformative power of Eucharistic Adoration, as it intensifies prayer and establishes a profound connection with God. Beholding Christ in the Blessed Sacrament allows us to delve into the mystery of God's boundless love, harmonizing our prayers with our hearts and minds.
Led by passionate student leaders and guided by our devoted priests or deacons, Christ on Campus offers you an extraordinary opportunity to engage in prayerful communion with the Eucharistic King. Once a month, we invite you to pause, reflect, journal, pray with uplifting music, and bask in the serene presence of the Eucharist. The Sacrament of Reconciliation awaits those seeking spiritual renewal during this time as well
Newman Night: Witness
Twice a month, at the Newman Center you are invited to hear from inspiring and faith-filled speakers! Brace yourself for captivating talks that will ignite your curiosity and broaden your horizons. And the best part? The discussion doesn't end there! Stick around after the talk and relish a delightful, complimentary meal while exchanging ideas with like-minded individuals.
We extend this invitation to all students, so gather your friends and join us for intellectually stimulating evenings that will leave you inspired
Other events include:
Bible study groups
Classes in Catholic studies (for ASU credit)
Service events
Sports tournaments
Mission Trips
Welcome Video: 
Instagram Link: https://www.instagram.com/asucatholic/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/ASUCatholic
Website: https://www.asucatholic.org/index
        Calendar of Events:https://asucatholic.org/calendar

The American Indian Graduate Association (AIGSA) aspires to serve a critical role in promoting the professional development and cultural awareness of its graduate and undergraduate members in a collective, inclusive, and social environment at all four campuses. By fostering an atmosphere that promotes intellectual engagement, academic support, and a social network we hope to cultivate future leaders with a collective version focused on highlighting Indigenous concerns on a local, national, and international scale at Arizona State University.

ACF seeks to bring together ASU students wanting fellowship and prayer. ACF desires to be a safe-haven for ASU students with spiritual, emotional, psychological and/or physical felt needs. ACF participates in the Council of Religious Advisors at ASU and as such is purposed to help student achieve good holistic health.
ACF meets weekly for Christian Worship and refreshments on Saturdays at Christian Challenge (1322 S Mill Ave, Tempe, AZ 85281) at 12 noon.
All of you are welcome, we would love to have you!

The club is a social platform to introduce students to the Middle Eastern and Arab cultures. It is also a platform for networking between students and alumni through different hosted events. The club will be working on networking with Arab Leaders to promote leadership skills to other Thunderbird students and to enhance networking within the Arab Elite. The club has to promote engagement and better communicate cultural difference to be able within Thunderbird's students. In addition, the club will be able to promote empathy, peace and the ability to be part of a global society that take responsibilities to promote a better future by managing people and different recourses.

To provide opportunities for current and future Sun Devils to engage and find community. This effort will reflect the robust diversity of engagement opportunities that exist throughout various platforms within EOSS.

The Bhakti Yoga Club is meant to introduce students to the sustainable lifestyle of a Bhakti. Rather than merely focus on bending and stretching, the club explores the spiritual philosophy meant to stretch one's consciousness. Bhakti Yoga Club encourages a shift in spiritual consciousness that helps students lead wholesome and fulfilling lives through a blend of Bhagavad Gita discussions, mantra mediation, speaker/workshop events, yoga classes, vegetarian/vegan meals and cooking classes.

We are an organization comprised of business students dedicated to enhancing the academic and extracurricular experiences of those within the W. P. Carey School of Business. Our responsibilities include presiding over business organizations, orchestrating fun and engaging events for business students, and providing numerous opportunities for professional development.

SKY MEDITATION empowers your potential through scientifically-proven meditation and yoga techniques. Our thrice-semesterly retreats offer deep peace, happiness, and lasting friendships. We provide a safe space to confront life's challenges and manage stress. With diverse events and workshops throughout the semester, we guide you towards inner freedom.
Grow stronger in love with us.

column3: (BLASTD) Leadership and Service Team at Barrett Downtown
column6: BLASTD makes community service accessible to college students and show them how they can get involved in their community while fostering a love for giving back that stays with them long after they graduate. We do internal events based on creating something, similar to a DIY project, that a community organization needs. We also go out into the community several times a year to volunteer at local organizations.

100 Angels at ASU is a club that works closely with the 100 Angels Foundation in Central Arizona to help asylum seekers in various shelters across the valley by volunteering at these shelters and assembling and distributing Hygiene Kits. If intested in joining please fill out this form https://forms.gle/WWHQkqChZz7HAKCc9 and we will get back to you shortly.

Our mission is to bridge the gap between military affiliates and civilians, create an inclusive space, allow military veterans and dependents to socialize with the general student body without judgment, learn from each other's experiences, and create lasting memories.
Acacia is a social fraternity dedicated to the search of virtue, knowledge, and truth.

Accessibility Coalition's purpose is to support the disability community at ASU, including students, staff, faculty, and administration in addition to our surrounding community and social spheres, to combat ableism and misconceptions about disability. This is accomplished through leadership, advocacy, and community-building activities intended to promote accessibility and inclusion.

Before joining, please read all instructions below. If you do not follow all instructions, your membership request on our Discord server will respectfully be ignored. Thank you!
  Adventure Devils is a student organization at Arizona State University's Tempe Campus. We are dedicated to bringing students together for outdoor activity, service, and education. Whether you are entirely new to the outdoors or a seasoned adventurer, this club caters to your longing for serious trips in the back country and wilderness areas of the Southwest! What are you waiting for? Come adventure with us!
We do not charge dues. To join and be considered a member, you must complete the New Member Registration Form and press the join button here on SunDevilSync. NOTE: you are unable to attend off campus events without having completed the New Member Form. After you have completed the New Member Registration form and having successfully joined our club, you must join our Discord server and send us a message in the Membership Approval channel with your full name, letting us know that you have successfully filled out the form and have joined our club on SunDevilSync. 
We use a Discord Server to manage all club events: https://discord.gg/rGQxueb

Snow Devils is an active skiing/snowboarding club that welcomes beginners all the way to experts! The club offers the lowest price on the IKON pass that is available anywhere (up to 40% OFF)! We go on about 5 trips every winter season to resorts like Taos, Wolf Creek, Snowbird, and more. Becoming a Snow Devil will introduce you to many other riders and help you improve your skiing and boarding. The club tries its best to make the trips cost effective and will even pay for gas for independent trips to Snowbowl if you carpool with other members. Whether you're a boarder who needs to shred the whole day, or a laid back skier who just needs a few runs, sign on up because deep down we all just want some fresh pow.
For memberships please visit https://snowdevilsasu.com
  PLEASE EMAIL US @ snowdevilsasu@gmail.com FOR INFO ON HOW TO SIGN UP

Join our Discord for announcements and club meetings: https://discord.gg/CdehGpd
