However, many of our Wednesday meetings from 6-7 pm AZ time are open to anyone and you are welcome to attend! Check SunDevilSync events to see which meetings you can attend.
Please fill out this form if you would like to be on the email list for general meetings. We can't wait to see you there!

To promote excellence in architecture education, training and practice. To foster an appreciation of architecture and related disciplines. To enrich communities in a spirit of collaboration. To organize students and combine their efforts to advance the art and science of architecture.

We are the student chapter of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA). We participate in the AIAA international Design/Build/Fly (DBF) RC Aircraft competition. We also host speakers, and run field trips.

We seek to provide a kind community of musical album discussion, where members will discuss one album or more each week after listening to it, in a similar fashion to a book club. This is a place for people of all kinds to gather to listen and discuss all things music.
Feel free to come to any meeting! We meet Wednesdays at 7:00 PM. Even if you can't make the meetings, feel free to join the Discord below and discuss music with us! 
Join our Discord! https://discord.gg/BrAyfNg

column3: Men's Water Polo Club at ASU
column6:
We are a highly competitive team, practicing multiple times a week and traveling for tournaments. Our goal is to consistently qualify and compete for a National Championship.
Prior Water Polo Experience/Advanced Swim Experience Recommended

Roundnet is a fast growing sport popularized by the company Spikeball. It involves two teams of two, a yellow ball, and a net a yard in diameter. For more information on what "Spikeball" is, just search it on your favorite search engine or on YouTube. Devils Roundnet is a growing community of players, ranging from competitive to beginner. We are always looking for new people to play with, even if you've never even heard of the sport!
Come check us out! We play every Tuesday from 7pm to 9pm at the North Fields on Dorsey Lane and every Thursday from 7pm to 9pm on the SDFC west fields (as long as no special occasion had been stated in the GroupMe or on Instagram).
Follow us on Instagram @devilsroundnet_asu
If you would like to be added to the Devils Roundnet GroupMe, go to the link in our Instagram bio, or email me at wtuneliu@asu.edu

We have moved all our activities to our website https://arizonaoutdoorsclub.com/registration
  For joining the club and for more info, visit our website or 
Instagram
Discord
    The Arizona Outdoors Club, based at Arizona State University, is a member-driven organization comprised of a large variety of people including students, faculty, staff, and alumni who are interested in outdoor adventures, road trips, and social gatherings. Our members range from highly experienced veterans of various disciplines to first-timers looking to try something new or travel to new places. All members are encouraged to suggest fun, exciting, and challenging activities! One never knows what they will be doing next. The adventures never end!

Snow Devils is an active skiing/snowboarding club that welcomes beginners all the way to experts! The club offers the lowest price on the IKON pass that is available anywhere (up to 40% OFF)! We go on about 5 trips every winter season to resorts like Taos, Wolf Creek, Snowbird, and more. Becoming a Snow Devil will introduce you to many other riders and help you improve your skiing and boarding. The club tries its best to make the trips cost effective and will even pay for gas for independent trips to Snowbowl if you carpool with other members. Whether you're a boarder who needs to shred the whole day, or a laid back skier who just needs a few runs, sign on up because deep down we all just want some fresh pow.
For memberships please visit https://snowdevilsasu.com
  PLEASE EMAIL US @ snowdevilsasu@gmail.com FOR INFO ON HOW TO SIGN UP

The 942 Crew Executive Board is the official student booster group of Sun Devil Athletics. This is a passionate group of ASU student sports fans who work to improve the student game experience and raise the student attendance at Sun Devil Athletics sporting events.
Acacia is a social fraternity dedicated to the search of virtue, knowledge, and truth.

column3: ACHA Men’s Ice Hockey Club at Arizona State University
column6: To provide a top level hockey program to students at ASU. We are focused on providing our student athletes with a great experience in a club sport environment while the pursue their degree at ASU.

Before joining, please read all instructions below. If you do not follow all instructions, your membership request on our Discord server will respectfully be ignored. Thank you!
  Adventure Devils is a student organization at Arizona State University's Tempe Campus. We are dedicated to bringing students together for outdoor activity, service, and education. Whether you are entirely new to the outdoors or a seasoned adventurer, this club caters to your longing for serious trips in the back country and wilderness areas of the Southwest! What are you waiting for? Come adventure with us!
We do not charge dues. To join and be considered a member, you must complete the New Member Registration Form and press the join button here on SunDevilSync. NOTE: you are unable to attend off campus events without having completed the New Member Form. After you have completed the New Member Registration form and having successfully joined our club, you must join our Discord server and send us a message in the Membership Approval channel with your full name, letting us know that you have successfully filled out the form and have joined our club on SunDevilSync. 
We use a Discord Server to manage all club events: https://discord.gg/rGQxueb

Adventurers Wanted Inc. is a student organization that facilitates role-playing games alternating between Dungeons and Dragons and Other Systems (e.g. Pathfinder, Shadowrun, Star Wars, etc.). We strive to create a safe, fun, and welcoming environment for both new and seasoned players. We help pair players and game masters (Dungeon Masters) and provide resources for both.
Join our Discord for announcements and club meetings: https://discord.gg/CdehGpd

The Afghanistan Students Association at ASU(ASA) is a student organization that promotes cultural awareness and understanding of Afghanistan's rich history, traditions, and customs among the broader ASU community and advocates for human rights issues, including women's and minority rights. It is open to every ASU student interested in learning more about Afghanistan. In addition, ASA collaborates with local and international organizations to support programs and initiatives promoting education, literacy, and human rights. The ASA's efforts aim to contribute positively to social change and create a more inclusive and equitable environment at ASU and beyond.

We, the members of the AFRICAN Ph.D. NETWORK, out of a commonly identified need for the establishment of a family of scholars with roots in the African continent and the immutable belief that, as kinsmen, we must gather not because the moonlight is not visible from our individual compounds but because it is good to do so, agree to the regulations and policies of Arizona State University and establish this Constitution to govern the matters within
our organization.

The American Indian Graduate Association (AIGSA) aspires to serve a critical role in promoting the professional development and cultural awareness of its graduate and undergraduate members in a collective, inclusive, and social environment at all four campuses. By fostering an atmosphere that promotes intellectual engagement, academic support, and a social network we hope to cultivate future leaders with a collective version focused on highlighting Indigenous concerns on a local, national, and international scale at Arizona State University.

column3: American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
column6: This club is a student-run chapter of the American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology to foster student involvement in research, increase scientific literacy in the general community, and promote career development through scholarship and networking.

column3: American Society of Highway Engineers at ASU

column6: Amnesty International is the world's largest grassroots human rights organization. Our purpose is to protect people wherever justice, freedom, truth, and dignity are denied. Amnesty International investigates and exposes human rights abuses, gives activists the information and tools needed to take action, and rallies activists from all 50 states to demand that policymakers protect human rights in the U.S. and around the world.

column3: Asian Native Hawaiian Pacific Islanders Visionary Action
column6: Asian Native Hawaiian Pacific Islanders Visionary Action’s (AVA) mission is to ensure that the ANHPI and other marginalized communities are a part of the decision-making process and garner the appropriate resources for the population in need. We will ensure the development of nuanced solutions to both ANHPI and broader community issues. AVA aims to facilitate conversations on representation and identity by creating a close-knit community of driven students and focusing efforts on civic engagement and social and cultural awareness.

We are the student chapter of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA). We participate in the AIAA international Design/Build/Fly (DBF) RC Aircraft competition. We also host speakers, and run field trips.

Alpha Eta Rho (AHP) is the largest professional aviation fraternity in America. With a focus on flight, our chapter has frequent social gatherings, community service events, and sporting activities. We are comprised of mostly aviation majors, however there are several active members who simply have an interest in aviation.

Founded at Yale in 1845 by Louis Manigault, Horace Spangler Weiser and Stephen Ormsby Rhea, Alpha Sigma Phi has grown into one of the premier national fraternities. From the onset the organization has been committed to the awesome power for individual and social good that can be achieved when men of good character band together as brothers. Far from the stereotype of fraternities in recent years, Alpha Sigma Phi provides its undergraduate men with character and leadership development programs that are second to none. Each year the President’s Academy of Leadership offers our next generation of chapter officers and the alumni advisors who support their efforts a hands-on educational experience designed to enhance their strengths and support values based leadership. Additionally the award winning Ralph F. Burns Leadership Institute offers an annual opportunity for our newest members to examine the values of the fraternity and challenges them to emulate the program’s namesake by living life in pursuit of our Purpose: To Better the Man, through the creation and perpetuation of Brotherhood founded upon the virtues of character… Silence, Purity, Charity, Honor, Patriotism We hope you enjoy learning how Alpha Sigma Phi is building upon this noble calling while visiting this site.

The Amateur Radio Society at ASU is one of the oldest student organizations at Arizona State University. It was established during the 1930s, and the original callsign was W7TJV. In 1997 the club obtained the vanity callsign W7ASU, and in 2008 established a permanent station just north of the main campus in Tempe, Arizona, thanks to donated equipment from the family of Richard S. Juvet Jr. (WB7CDK/SK), the academic advisor for the club during the 1970s and 1980s. As of 2023, we have OVER 50 active members!
  W7ASU has a long tradition of communications service on campus and in the communities of Tempe and the surrounding greater Phoenix area. The club aims to mentor interested students and incoming members in Basic/Radio-Electronics, Amateur Radio Rules and Regulations among other things and help prepare for the FCC Amateur Radio Technicians Licensing Exam.
  By nature, amateur radio encompasses so many areas of educational content, such as science, engineering, technology, and math (STEM). Whether you are in a technical degree program, or not, you can gain valuable knowledge and skills by learning some of the aspects of amateur radio. This information can enhance your field of study regardless of the major.
  W7ASU allows you, the student, to explore past and present radio technologies, as well as participate in an international community with other amateur radio stations and operators around the world simply using the radio airwaves…no internet!
  Joining the ARS@ASU is free. The club's membership is Open to all ASU Students and Faculty and there are 'NO PRE-REQUISITES' to be involved in the club or its activities. HOWEVER, you MUST be a LICENSED FCC operator or operate under one in order to participate in our various transmitter operations.
  Participation in our events is voluntary, but participation in a school club looks great on your resume!
  Members of the ASU community can sign up on Sun Devil Sync (https://asu.campuslabs.com/engage/):  search for "Amateur Radio Club" and request to join.
  For any other questions please feel free to write to us by eMailing the Primary Contact person or Send us a question via the SunDevilSync portal. The e-mail, W7ASUradioclub@gmail.com, is also monitored and will be replied to when time allows.
73!
  P.S.: As of 2022 we can operate remotely from any authorized computer, thanks to the generous donation of Ham Radio Deluxe.  We have an ICOM 7300 with a TA33 beam at 55 ft.  A new rotor with computer interfaced control was installed in 2022. The club will also lend handheld VHF/UHF transceivers to licensed club members.
  We have a LARGE workspace for projects, lectures, etc. so PLEASE JOIN US!

column3: American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) Student Chapter at Arizona State University
column6: The American Institute of Chemical Engineers is a professional development club whose aim is to connect students with industry and academic professionals alike. Our work supersedes the Tempe borders, as we continue to build a talent pipeline which will benefit future communities and technical advancements for the coming years.

column3: American Society of Highway Engineers at ASU
American Society of Mechanical Engineers at Arizona State University
column6:
The American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) at Arizona State University aims to provide professional and academic development opportunities directed towards mechanical engineering students. Members will be able to connect with experienced people from industry, attend a variety of workshops and events, and socialize with like-minded peers.
  https://linktr.ee/asuasme

Welcome to the Polytechnic Veterans Club!
  The Veterans Club is a peer support group designed to ensure higher education success for veterans of the armed forces, their dependents, and supporters of the military currently attending ASU.

To be successful, Veterans must encourage collaboration among diverse units and stakeholders as well as eliminate the walls and barriers to education, prosperity, and wellness. We must eliminate the hedgerows that divide us and help redefine the relationship of our institutions: public and private, nonprofit and for profit, local, state and federal. By doing so, we will alter the trajectory of Veterans and redefine the roles that we play in education, in the economy, and in our communities. We look forward to having you be a part of this new model for Veteran success.

Meetings for Spring 2020 have all been conducted.  Meeting are in the Polytechnic Campus Pat Tillman Veterans Center enclave.  Future meetings will be posted here:
  Please join our Instagram for up-to-date information.  (www.instagram.com/polyveteransclub/)
Also, check out our Facebook page!  (www.facebook.com/PolytechnicVeteransClub/)

column3: Student Veterans Association at Arizona State University
column6: SVA Tempe leads, builds, and serves. The mission of SVA Tempe is to promote leadership, build community, and provide service for veteran and military-affiliated students at ASU, to ensure their success in higher education and future careers. The vision of SVA Tempe is that by leading, building, and serving the Student Veteran community, and collaborating with the affiliated SVA Chapters of ASU, to fully engage the 5,000 plus veteran and military-affiliated students at all ASU locations, in person and online, in programs of academic success, professional development, and social engagement. All veteran and military-affiliated students will succeed in higher education, integrate into college culture and civilian society, achieve their academic goals, gain meaningful employment, and become the future leaders of America. We are a Student Veterans of America Chapter. The Student Veterans Association at ASU Tempe, founded in 2009 as the ASU Veterans Club, carries on a tradition of veteran fellowship and cameraderie that goes back to the original ASU Veterans Club that was founded in the late 1960's. SVA Tempe is a peer group for students and faculty at ASU who are veteran and military-affiliated students, their dependents, and supporters and advocates. SVA Tempe promotes leadership among Student Veterans by advocating for the needs of veteran and military-affiliated students, enhancing the veteran-friendly climate at ASU, and inviting creative initiative from the Student Veteran community. SVA Tempe builds community among Student Veterans by encouraging the formation of veteran student organizations at ASU Tempe, such as Law Students for Veterans Legal Interests and Fulton Student Veterans Organization, in collaboration with their respective academic departments; engaging partner organizations such as SVA at Downtown, Polytechnic, West, Lake Havasu and the Tau Epsilon Phi ASU Veterans Fraternity; engaging partner departments such as the Pat Tillman Veteran Center, Veterans Upward Bound, the Disability Resource Center, and ROTC groups; utilizing social media to engage the veteran and military-affiliated student community, and recruiting new members or referring them to partner organizations. SVA Tempe provides service to Student Veterans by promoting academic success, professional development, and social engagement.

The purpose of the Student Veterans Organization is to prepare members for success after graduation. As an inclusive organization, Membership in the Student Veterans Organization is open to all students enrolled in at least one (1) semester hour of University credit at ASU.
We are a social peer network through the bond of common interests and experiences. Members will be introduced to our network and provided with information such as education benefits, career opportunities, and professional development workshops available at Arizona State University, Student Veterans of America, and other local and national resources.
On November 29, 2022 the Student Veterans Organization was recognized as a chapter of the Student Veterans of America (SVA), which elevates the academic, professional, and personal development of veterans in higher education through chapter programs and services.

Women Veterans Club is an organization for current members and veterans of the armed forces, their dependents, and supporters of the military who are currently attending ASU. Our focus is peer support and camaraderie while making an effort to respond to veteran needs in the local community. We will work together, as a whole, to encourage one another to achieve their educational, professional, and personal goals.

We are an organization comprised of business students dedicated to enhancing the academic and extracurricular experiences of those within the W. P. Carey School of Business. Our responsibilities include presiding over business organizations, orchestrating fun and engaging events for business students, and providing numerous opportunities for professional development.

Asian Business Leaders Association was originally founded in 1994 by a small group of dedicated business students and still continues to meet today following many successful years. We serve the needs of career-oriented students through academic support, leadership opportunities, and social environments where members can interact with the campus and community leaders.
  The main emphasis of the organization is to educate members about various Asian cultures in the business setting. We accomplish these goals by holding weekly meetings where we discuss anything from cultural barriers to resume workshops as well as guest speakers from both alumni and from companies.
  In such meetings, we discuss various challenges one might face such as the cultural differences between corporate life and the culture members may have been raised in. We also have meetings with invited professionals and alumni to come and speak, letting members engage with professionals first hand in order to gain knowledge and connections, furthering their professional development.In addition to this, we hold social events throughout the school year to foster friendships and community within the organization.
  We strive to improve our members' cultural awareness between the business world and themselves while giving them a social space to connect and find a sense of community.

Supporting tactics:
Host virtual (until able to return to in-person) meetings with underrepresented business leaders that allow them to talk about their career and their journey as a minority employee.
Host Town Halls where perspective sharing is the objective. Have underrepresented minorities in the program share their background and what it took to get them to where they are today as well as having our allies share their perspectives.
Community outreach and engagement with underrepresented groups about their hopes, and dreams and how to navigate their path.
Work with underrepresented groups and their respective chambers of commerce to acquire consulting projects for their members and deliver pro bono work to be part of uplifting the local minority business communities.
Establish pipelines for our members and mentees with top companies focused on attracting, recruiting and retaining diversity and inclusion minded individuals to help shape their businesses moving forward.
Collaborate with minority groups in other Business Schools to host educative sessions (panel discussions etc) and social events.

adworks is a student-run advertising agency within the W. P. Carey School of Business. Each semester we complete different projects by partnering with local agencies and other organizations to develop multi-media advertising campaigns. adworks provides businesses with marketing deliverables. From graphic design and logo making, to top-to-bottom branding and strategy. We are the future of advertising. Our organization is filled with the brightest talent and uniqueness you won't find anywhere else. As members, we develop connections amongst our fellow ASU students who share a passion for advertising, while receiving hands-on, professional experience alongside advertising experts across the valley.
Our application to be on a project team is open at the beginning of each semester. You can apply at adworksasu.com
  Interested in joining adworks?
Membership in adworks is open to all students who are enrolled in at least one (1) semester hour of University credit at ASU. We are an application-based organization since our work is done in project teams who are assigned to our partner agencies. Our application opens at the beginning of each semester. However, many of our Wednesday meetings from 6-7 pm AZ time are open to anyone and you are welcome to attend! Check SunDevilSync events to see which meetings you can attend.
Please fill out this form if you would like to be on the email list for general meetings. We can't wait to see you there!

column3: American Marketing Association at Arizona State University
column6:
The American Marketing Association is the largest marketing association in North America as well as the largest organization in the business college at ASU. Our focus is to teach students practical, real world skills for marketing themselves in a competitive business world. Whether you're a business, engineering or design major, you'll need to learn how to market yourself to potential prospects, employers, bosses and coworkers in order to get ahead of your competition. Here at AMA, we'll teach you how to put together a resume, how to dress professionally, how to speak to employers and help you develop real world leadership skills that will give you an edge in the business world. We'll also give you opportunities to develop friendships with college peers, network with executives from various different corporations and learn about how to effectively work together in teams in order to accomplish real world objectives. Our goal at AMA is to help prepare you to excel when you leave college and help you develop the necessary skills for business that you can't get from the classroom. Come visit us at our meetings and stay for one of our socials to find out more about AMA! 
https://youtu.be/ImPWKRO0SzU
Arizona Microcredit Initiative is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that empowers underserved entrepreneurs to start or expand businesses through business instruction, consulting services and microloans.

column3: Asian Corporate & Entrepreneur Leaders Collegiate Chapter at ASU
column6: The Asian Corporate & Entrepreneur Leaders collegiate chapter at Arizona State University (ACEL-ASU) allows a safe and professional setting for all individuals to develop their skills in order to pursue higher levels in their careers or executive roles in society. We accomplish this through biweekly general meetings, social events every two months, and service events for ASU students. Celebrations include a pre-thanksgiving dinner, hiking trips, and an end of year banquet. Workshops will be led by professionals from the ACEL professional chapter providing connections and networking, increasing our members’ personal confidence, and expanding their opportunities for future careers. The members of ACEL consist of a very large and diverse population of leaders and working professionals with all different backgrounds including journalism, political science, social workers, medicine, engineering, business, arts, law, entrepreneurs, and multitude more that appeals to students of all majors of every school. ASU student members will also be offered the chance to be a part of the mentorship program, where students are paired up with a professional from the organization, allowing for a tremendous opportunity for invaluable knowledge transfer. ACEL offers company tours with corporations as well as a buddy program for incoming freshmen and sophomores with upperclassmen. Members will be a part of the collegiate chapter but will also have the opportunity to be a member of the Arizona chapter, allowing for the opportunity to continue professional development beyond their undergraduate and graduate degrees and preparing us ASU students for success.

column3: Association of Latino Professionals for America (ALPFA) at ASU®
column6:
The Association of Latino Professionals for America was established in 1972 as the first-ever national Latino professional organization. Since its establishment over 45 years ago, ALPFA has grown to serve over 92,000+ professional and student members with more than 200 chapters nationwide. ALPFA at ASU was originally established in 2007 as an Accounting and Finance organization, and now serves as a Latino professional organization committed to the professional development of its members. ALFPA at ASU bridges the gap between the professional and the scholastic by hosting workshops with professional firms from the Phoenix Metropolitan area and beyond. The goal of these workshops is to provide professional perspective to our members while creating networking opportunities for both the firm and students. Students of any year, major, and racial/ethnic backgrounds are welcome to our organization.
!! Sign up to receive our weekly newsletter to stay up to date on when our events are happening !!
https://us6.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=9443705194a5c8fa556bbe051&id=2bc75fd328
  !! Follow us on Instagram: @alpfaasu !!

column3: Beta Alpha Psi Accounting Honorary Organization
column6: Beta Alpha Psi (Beta Tau Chapter) is an honorary organization for Financial Information students and professionals. The primary objective of Beta Alpha Psi Accounting Honorary Organization is to encourage and give recognition to scholastic and professional excellence in the business information field. This includes promoting the study and practice of accounting, finance, economics, and information systems; providing opportunities for self-development, service, and association among members and practicing professionals, and encouraging a sense of ethical, social, and public responsibility. Open to both undergraduate and graduate students enrolled with at least 1 credit hour. Be sure to check out our website for a more detailed description of our meetings, events, and national requirements!

column3: Business Ambassadors at W. P. Carey
column6: Business Ambassadors are student leaders of the W. P. Carey School of Business who represent the school at events and programs both on and off campus in a professional manner and build positive relationships with students, families, faculty, and the community. Additionally, Business Ambassadors are involved in the recruitment process of top students to the W. P. Carey School through collaboration with the Undergraduate Admissions Office. The school of business seeks students to be Ambassadors who are successful, professional and are proud to represent the W. P. Carey School of Business. “The mission of the W. P. Carey Business Ambassadors is to consistently and professionally represent the W. P. Carey School of Business.” Applications will open in the Fall semester.

Advancing Women in Construction encourages construction related fields as a career path. AWIC provides both social and academic support, facilitates industry exposure and leadership opportunities for students interested in the field. These events focus on the construction, engineering, and architecture fields, but everyone is welcome!

column3: African Students Association at Arizona State University
column6: Welcome to the African Students Association. The African Student Association (AFSA) is an organization that was created out of the need for unity, camaraderie, fellowship and the desire to work together. AFSA is open to anybody that is interested in learning about and enjoying African culture. AFSA prides itself in creating a sense of community for students of African descent on campus and strives to educate its campus community on Africa-related topics. The African Students' Association aims to be a social forum for all students of African descent as well as all students who are interested in sharing the African experience at Arizona State University. Article II – Non-Discrimination Statement Membership and all privileges, including voting and officer positions, must be extended to all students without regard to age, ethnicity, gender, disability, color, national origin, race, religion, sexual orientation, or veteran status. Title IX of the Educational Amendments of 1972, Section 106.14, makes an exception for social fraternities and sororities, in regard to gender, for membership criteria. Religious student organizations will not be denied registration solely because they limit membership or leadership positions to students who share the same religious beliefs. These groups, however, may not discriminate in membership or leadership on any other prohibited basis (i.e., age, ethnicity, gender, disability, color, national origin, race, sexual orientation, or veteran status).

Agape is a college ministry of Crossroads Lutheran Church in Queen Creek/San Tan Valley. Agape College Ministry serves as a supportive home away from home for college students. Agape is a community where one's faith is challenged and "re-owned" through sense of community, exploration, and friendship that develop over the semesters. For some people Agape is a significant core faith community during their college years while for others they simply enjoy some of the activities and events we sponsor.

We are affiliated with the All Walks Project, which is a student-led nonprofit initiative here at ASU that raises awareness about human trafficking in the United States and abroad. AllWalks at ASU educates ASU students about domestic sex trafficking and how it impacts our communities.

Alpha Chi Omega was founded on October 15, 1885 at DePauw University in Greencastle, Indiana by seven young women. Today, Alpha Chi has over 170,000 members located throughout the world. There are 135 collegiate chapters on college and university campuses throughout the United States and 200 alumnae chapters. On September 25, 1985 the Zeta Pi chapter of Alpha Chi Omega was the 13th National Panhellenic group to join the Arizona State University Greek system and the Chapter still stands strong today.

Founded in 1851 in Wesleyan Female College in Macon, Georgia, Alpha Delta Pi is a Panhellenic sorority dedicated to the improvement of its members through values of sisterhood, academics, social responsibility, and personal enrichment.

Alpha Epsilon was founded on October 24, 1909 at Barnard College in NYC by seven Jewish women. Today, Alpha Epsilon Phi has over 80,000 members located throughout the world. There are over 100 collegiate chapters on college and university campuses throughout the United States and over 70 alumnae chapters. On March 12, 2018 the ASU Colony of Alpha Epsilon Phi became the 16th National Panhellenic group to join the Arizona State University Greek system.

column3: Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc., Zeta Alpha Chapter
column6: Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority is America’s first Greek-letter organization established by Black college women. Founded in 1908, her roots date back to Howard University, Washington, D.C., where the idea for formation was conceived by Ethel Hedgeman Lyle of St. Louis, Missouri. She viewed the Sorority as an instrument for enriching the social and intellectual aspects of college life by providing mental stimulation through interaction with friends and associates. Through the years, however, Alpha Kappa Alpha’s function has become more complex. After her incorporation as a perpetual body in 1913, Alpha Kappa Alpha gradually branched out and became the channel through which selected college-trained women improved the socioeconomic conditions in their city, state, nation and the world. Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated is based on the principles of sisterhood, scholarship, and service to ALL mankind. Alpha Kappa Alpha has grown through the years to become an international organization with a membership in excess of 200,000 women. Membership in our organization consists of women of distinction and exemplary character. These women excel in all areas of life and work closely with the community. Alpha Kappa Alpha has undergraduate and graduate chapters located in the United States, West Africa, Great Britain, the Bahamas, the Virgin Islands, Korea and Germany. For more information on our national history, please visit www.aka1908.com.

The object of the Fraternity shall be to encourage a spirit of Fraternity and love among its members; to stand at all times for character, dignity, scholarship, and college loyalty; to strive for and support the best interests of the colleges and universities in which chapters are installed, and in no way to disregard, injure, or sacrifice those interests for the sake of prestige or advancement of the Fraternity or any of its chapters

Alpha Phi Gamma was established on February 1, 1994 at California State Polytechnic University, Pomona. The sorority unites women of all backgrounds through the bonds of friendship and sisterhood. Its mission is to promote Asian awareness and fight domestic violence at the University and in its surrounding communities. Alpha Phi Gamma is a national sorority with 14 chapters, 2 provisional charters, and 2 associate charters with over 1,600 sisters across the nation. Alpha Phi Gamma’s Xi Chapter at Arizona State University was chartered on May 21, 2017.

column3: Michigan State University Student Chapter of the American Association of Wildlife Veterinarians
column6: The MSU AAWV is a student chapter of the national AAWV designed to promote an interest in and provide educational information on wildlife health and wildlife veterinary medicine. MSU AAWV creates educational and career opportunities for veterinary students to expand their knowledge, skills, and involvement in wildlife medicine by curating guest lectures and creating hands-on wet lab events, as well as providing networking opportunities.

180 Degrees Consulting is the world's largest consultancy for non-profits & social enterprises. We provide high-quality consulting services to social impact organizations so they can improve and expand their services.

Our mission is to explore the legal intricacies surrounding the production and distribution of alcoholic beverages. By taking advantage of East Lansing’s unique proximity to many of the region’s alcohol producers, our goal is to take a deeper look at the implications of trademark, property, environmental, and regulatory legal issues, among others, in this constantly evolving industry.

Abide engages students ages 18-23. We do weekly Bible study, prayer and worship in a group fashion. The ministry also strives to meet the needs of students: spiritual, emotional, psychological and even physical.

In addition to competing in regional and national quizbowl tournaments, the Academic Competition Club promotes academic competition in the region by hosting quizbowl tournaments for collegiate, high school, and middle school teams.
  We are always looking for new members - of all skill levels - for our club, as well as volunteers to host our tournaments. Please fill out this short google form if you are interested in learning more and so that we can contact you for further information: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScN-LodbMp2JdbYeWo_ZmVQht_dEgEvwSSV5Z8vVAAMLTGp2g/viewform?usp=sf_link
  If you have any questions, please contact us at msucbowl@gmail.com.
  To learn more about quizbowl competitions, check out this informative wiki page hosted on qbwiki.com.

Accessibility entails striving for equal access regardless of ability or disability. Accessibility Professionals at MSU will foster students' interest in the field of accessibility by encouraging professional connections, job opportunities and learning more about the industry.

The Accounting Student Association of Michigan State University is organized by students for the purpose of providing those with an interest in accounting the opportunity to learn more about the profession and the many alternative careers paths within it. We strive to connect our members to prospective employers and prepare them for life beyond MSU’s Broad College of Business. We do this by providing opportunities to network and develop professionally and academically. The Accounting Student Association is an organization for all class levels and majors; all Spartans are encouraged to join.
The Accounting Student Association hosts guest speakers to introduce you to the many careers that accounting majors can follow such as those in industry, academia, or with public accounting firms. We hold seminars to help career development and plan trips that allow students to see the actual work environment. There are also social events to provide opportunities for you to meet with fellow students who have similar interests and community service events to give back to those in need and grow as professionals through giving.

Meetings will typically be held on either Sunday or Wednesday evenings. We will rotate between acro yoga, stretching, and workout classes. Join the Facebook, Instagram, or GroupMe for more information about days and times! No prior experience needed. Bring your friends!
The purpose of actuarial science club is to help students discover the professional and real-world applications of actuarial science.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b4oDygUOkq8

The purpose of this organization shall be to increase exposure to the Addictions Medicine subspecialty. The AMSIG aims to equip medical students with the knowledge needed to provide empathetic care to their patients affected by addiction regardless of the specialty they ultimately pursue. The AMSIG will also provide students with opportunities to learn about the impact of addiction through the perspectives of patients, physicians, and others working in the field.

Michigan State University Advertising Association is a networking and professional development organization that exists to provide MSU students with personal connections, as well as valuable insights into the advertising industry.
Check out our website!

To be a member of Aerospace Club, you must be a member of Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps (AFROTC) Detachment 380, a training program that prepares college students to become officers in the United States Air Force or United States Space Force. Students work with Det 380 to qualify for a commission while simultaneously completing their university undergraduate degree requirements.

The African Graduate Students Association was formed in 2015, under the leadership of the African Studies Center, as a forum for MSU African graduate students to exchange ideas and frame issues pertinent to the development of Africa through research and scholarship. AGSA is also meant to serve as a networking platform for African graduate students at MSU and to facilitate the development of the students’ professional and leadership skills.

The main objectives of the ASU are to foster pan-African unity, promote Afro-centric intellectual orientation and to direct our energies in shaping intellectuals who will in future work toward socio-economic, politico-cultural and spiritual rebirth of the peoples of Africa.

column3: Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources Education Club
column6: The purpose of this organization is to encourage collegiality among students who are either interested in or are majoring in Agriculture, Food, and Natural Resources Education, as well as provide professional resources, opportunities, and experiences related to Agriculture Food, and Natural Resources Education.

The Michigan State University Agronomy club is a agronomist based club where students are given the chance to network, gain experience, complete in colligate agronomy contest and attend pre-career fair mixers.

For creatives & designers of all majors. AIGA is the oldest and longest running professional association for design. Our focus is to connect with one another and celebrate design through creative workshops and events. Meeting biweekly on Wednesdays at 7 PM! Find our socials, email-list, and more at: MichiganStateAIGA.carrd.co
-
Website: MichiganStateAIGA.carrd.co
Email: MichiganStateAIGA@gmail.com
Instagram: @MichiganStateAIGA
Facebook: @MichiganStateAIGA
-
This organization will not discriminate on the basis of age, color, gender, gender identity, disability status, height, marital status, national origin, political persuasion, race, religion, sexual orientation, veteran status, or weight.

AFROTC is a training program that prepares college students to become officers in the United States Air Force or United States Space Force. Students participate in classes, physical training, leadership projects & positions, visits to Air Force bases, orientation flights, etc.

AASO is open to any MSU student who expresses an interest in learning more about the Albanian culture and its purpose. AASO engages through a mix of cultural, social, fundraising, and educational events. This organization will not discriminate on the basis of age, color, gender, gender identity, disability status, height, marital status, national origin, political persuasion, race, religion, sexual orientation, veteran status, or weight. Only MSU students may be officers and/or voting members.

Michigan State University's All-Girl Competitive Cheerleading Club Team is a student-led organization that participates in a collegiate style of cheerleading. Throughout the year we compete in both NCA and STUNT The Sport. We welcome intermediate to advanced talent and offer many opportunities for growth. It is a chance to meet new people and gain friendships and experiences that will last a lifetime.

column3: Alliance of Queer and Ally Students

column6: Alpha Chi Omega was founded on October 15, 1885, at DePauw University in Greencastle, Indiana. Alpha Chi Omega was founded at Michigan State University in September of 1926. Here at the Beta Epsilon chapter we believe that your time at Michigan State University should be an unforgettable experience. “Together let us seek the heights” is our open motto, and we strive each and every day to create the best sisterhood possible. Not only will you find your best friends at Alpha Chi, you’ll find your sisters. At the heart of every Alpha Chi Omega is a commitment to academic and personal excellence by continually being involved on campus and in our community. Take a look around our website and learn more about the real, strong women of the Beta Epsilon chapter of Alpha Chi Omega.

The American Red Cross prevents and alleviates human suffering in the face of emergencies by mobilizing the power of volunteers and the generosity of donors. Through multiple blood drives and fundraising events throughout the semester, being involved with the Emory Red Cross is not only fulfilling and fun! 
 This club has been founded on the principles of the American Red Cross and strives to do deeds that ultimately assist the Red Cross in its endeavors and serve the communities near Atlanta.

La Alianza Latinx is a student-led organization composed of Latinx and Latin American public health students interested in issues affecting the Latinx community at the Rollins School of Public Health, in the metro Atlanta area, throughout the United States, and internationally. We strive to strengthen and build a Latinx community at the Rollins School of Public Health by creating a space that enables students to excel academically, professionally, and socially. We are committed to building community, supporting mentorship, uplifting educational advancement, and promoting advocacy for and improvement of Latinx health, Latinx students, and undocumented students at Emory University.

The 1915 Scholars program is designed to help you meet your academic, social, and professional development needs as a first-gen college student. The program connects you with a small, intentional “family” cluster to provide support as you build a solid foundation for success. This family cluster includes first-generation peers, graduate mentors, and alumni mentors. The family cluster also serves as a supportive network for you on and off the Emory campus.

Are you interested in using cutting-edge technology to make a positive impact on your community? Then our 3D printing and modeling club is the perfect fit for you! We are a group of students who are passionate about using 3D printing to create innovative solutions for real-world problems. From designing toys to help children with disabilities to creating sustainable products that reduce waste, the possibilities are endless. Our club provides a platform for students to learn and collaborate on exciting projects that will make a difference in the world. Join us and discover how you can use your skills to change the world, one print at a time.

Youth in juvenile detention centers often experience gaps in their education that can leave them unprepared to return to school upon release. Education and mentorship are important factors that can potentially prevent youth from falling behind. Our organization seeks to tutor and mentor these youth to stay on track with their coursework and fill in any content gaps in any core academic subjects. We want to ensure that incarcerated youth receive the same level of  academic support as other students. We hope that Emory students can serve as positive role models for the youth at the DeKalb Regional Youth Detention Center and provide one-on-one and small group academic instruction that will allow them to excel.
  We are not actively recruiting.

Academic Success Programs (formerly EPASS) is comprised of academic coaching, learning assistance, and peer-tutoring. The mission of Emory’s academic success programs is to provide resources, services and workshops that support all undergraduate student achievements. 
We do this by:  
Collaborating with faculty and university departments to coordinate a campus-wide network of academic support;  
Supporting students as they transition to college-level learning 
Cultivating the lifelong skill of learning how to learn 
Proactively identify and support academically at-risk students to increase retention and graduation. 
Creating opportunities for student leadership development in service to the Emory community.

ACS ChemOx is Oxford College's official chemistry club. We're affiliated with the chemistry department of Oxford College, and are an active undergraduate chapter of the American Chemical Society. ChemOx aims to promote awareness of chemistry in a social atmosphere within the school as well as the local community, and we work toward providing members with a deeper understanding and appreciation of chemistry, and of how it influences our everyday lives.

Active Minds is a national non-profit that seeks to initiate conversations about mental health, increase awareness about mental illness, and use the student voice to radically change the language surrounding and attitudes towards mental health through research, advocacy, and education. The Emory chapter of this organization shares these same missions to educate the student body about mental health, discourage the stigmas associated with mental illness, and encourage students to use the resources available and seek help when necessary by hosting speakers and discussions and collaborating with other organizations to increase awareness on campus.

The Adam Smith Society is a nationwide, chapter-based association of MBA students, professionals, and business leaders who work to discuss and debate the contributions of the free market to advancing human flourishing and opportunity for all. Like its parent organization, the Manhattan Institute, the Adam Smith Society is committed to defending free enterprise while welcoming the participation of all those interested in the competition of ideas.

column3: Addiction Medicine and Harm Reduction Interest Group
column6:
We use a four pronged approach to increase knowledge around addiction and harm reduction:
We seek to offer medical students and current medical professionals in any specialty opportunities to learn about how they can integrate knowledge surrounding addiction medicine and harm reduction into their practice. 
We will provide current medical students opportunities for career development related to addiction medicine and harm reduction. 
We will engage with local communities to provide increased accessibility to harm reduction services and addiction related resources. 
We will advocate for curriculum advancement surrounding addiction and harm reduction for MD students.

Are you interested in using cutting-edge technology to make a positive impact on your community? Then our 3D printing and modeling club is the perfect fit for you! We are a group of students who are passionate about using 3D printing to create innovative solutions for real-world problems. From designing toys to help children with disabilities to creating sustainable products that reduce waste, the possibilities are endless. Our club provides a platform for students to learn and collaborate on exciting projects that will make a difference in the world. Join us and discover how you can use your skills to change the world, one print at a time.

The Emory chapter of this organization shares these same missions to educate the student body about mental health, discourage the stigmas associated with mental illness, and encourage students to use the resources available and seek help when necessary by hosting speakers and discussions and collaborating with other organizations to increase awareness on campus.

Ad Hoc is Emory University's only musical theater student group. Full fledged productions are performed annually with open auditions for students interested in exploring all aspects of theater at Emory. Ad Hoc Productions is open to all students and provides the opportunity to engage in positions both on stage and off stage including but not limited to acting, set building, singing, or playing an instrument.

Adrenaline is a Co-Ed hip-hop group which aims to share knowledge about hip-­hop dance, learning from each other and broadening their skills as movers through practice and performance.
Adrenaline also hopes to provide students with a platform upon which their ideas can be presented and developed, and in doing so produce dancers with stronger choreographic abilities and communication methods as teachers of their craft.
This portal will serve as a hub for communication to and from student organization advisors across the Emory campus.

AHANA A Cappella was founded in 2003 by Will Corbin and Jasmine McGinnis and has been a well-known group on campus since. The acronym AHANA stands for Asian, Hispanic, African, and Native American, though we celebrate and are accepting of all races and ethnicities. Since its inception, AHANA A Cappella has performed at events on and off campus, including most recently the 2022 Taste of Africa at the Fox Theatre and Emory’s Baccalaureate Ceremony in the spring. AHANA's mission is to serve our community and spread love through music. We greatly appreciate your support! 
Our Instagram is @ahana.acappella ! Follow us to stay up to date on performances and audition opportunities!
Alas de un Mismo Pájaro is a dance team that works to advocate for, support, and represent Afro-Latinx students at Emory and beyond by bringing awareness to underrepresented identities through dance.

Alloy Literary Magazine is a student-run literary and arts magazine for Emory undergraduate students featuring prose, creative nonfiction, poetry, photography, and other visual art forms. Alloy is published annually at the end of the academic year.

As the Emory chapter of the National Alpha Psi Omega Theatre Honor Society, our members are the leaders of the Emory Theater Community. Together, we strive to provide the leadership and support that is needed to create rich forms of performative art.

La Alianza Latinx is a student-led organization composed of Latinx and Latin American public health students interested in issues affecting the Latinx community at the Rollins School of Public Health, in the metro Atlanta area, throughout the United States, and internationally. We strive to strengthen and build a Latinx community at the Rollins School of Public Health by creating a space that enables students to excel academically, professionally, and socially. We are committed to building community, supporting mentorship, uplifting educational advancement, and promoting advocacy for and improvement of Latinx health, Latinx students, and undocumented students at Emory University.

The 1915 Scholars program is designed to help you meet your academic, social, and professional development needs as a first-gen college student. The program connects you with a small, intentional “family” cluster to provide support as you build a solid foundation for success. This family cluster includes first-generation peers, graduate mentors, and alumni mentors. The family cluster also serves as a supportive network for you on and off the Emory campus.

4 Justice is Emory University’s first Criminal Justice Reform Club. We seek to improve the criminal justice system in 4 steps:
Inform the public of the severity of racial injustice present in the justice system by publishing written reports about the true difficulties caused by incarceration as well as the seemingly nonsensical reasons why some people are incarcerated. 
Fight for clemency or pardon for individuals serving unusually long sentences
Work to improve conditions for children, families, and individuals impacted by the criminal justice system
Encourage legislators to implement strategies to prevent unnecessary incarceration

Discover giving opportunities that align with your passions and push the boundaries of leadership and knowledge. Learn about awards and leadership stipends that are donor funded. Together we can create, engage, and inspire.
This portal will serve as a hub for communication to and from student organization advisors across the Emory campus.

ACSU aims to enrich the community by organizing study breaks, vigils, and events with invited speakers. Our meetings and events will incorporate cultural education and take part in the dismantling of common stereotypes held towards the different aspects of African and Caribbean traditions.

The African Student Association is meant to promote African culture, politics, and people through educational and social programs that benefit Emory and the surrounding communities. Our initiatives work to engage these communities in a dialogue on topics related to the African diaspora. ASA also serves as a community for those who share similar interests with others concerning the African continent.

AHANA A Cappella was founded in 2003 by Will Corbin and Jasmine McGinnis and has been a well-known group on campus since. The acronym AHANA stands for Asian, Hispanic, African, and Native American, though we celebrate and are accepting of all races and ethnicities. Since its inception, AHANA A Cappella has performed at events on and off campus, including most recently the 2022 Taste of Africa at the Fox Theatre and Emory’s Baccalaureate Ceremony in the spring. AHANA's mission is to serve our community and spread love through music. We greatly appreciate your support! 
Our Instagram is @ahana.acappella ! Follow us to stay up to date on performances and audition opportunities!
Alas de un Mismo Pájaro is a dance team that works to advocate for, support, and represent Afro-Latinx students at Emory and beyond by bringing awareness to underrepresented identities through dance.

All Black Emory is a productive space for collaborative dialogue, where Black folx gather to have open and honest conversations about our experiences with and within institutions like Emory University. Our mission is to explore, evaluate and document Black life at Emory as we navigate the contemporary moment. You can find our podcast on YouTube, Spotify, and Apple Podcasts. 
  2023-2024 Executive Production Team 
Our meetings executive board meetings are on Monday at 10AM in AMUC 130.

AltKEY is a platform where activists and designers come together to spread awareness on upcycling, reducing consumption, and reusing pre-owned items. We strive to create an international organization that reaches many universities across the globe culminating in various sustainability fashion shows, conferences, and summits to educate others about how to be sustainable in the world of fashion and still be profitable. We will become the movement that changes the fashion industry forever, but first young talents.

We're an anime club that has bi-weekly meetings usually at White Hall and now hopefully through Discord. We watch anime suggested and voted on by the community and hopefully we'll be able to hold some events.

BLACKSTAR* Magazine is Emory's first and only Black publication on campus. BLACKSTAR*'s mission is to provide a voice through creativity for the Black community at Emory University, affirm a range of Black identities, and extend our reach to Atlanta.

BlaeZ is an established co-ed dance crew on campus, mainly focusing on street dance, choreography, and K-pop. Our vision is to unify multiple communities across Emory by embracing different pop cultures. We are run solely by students with a passion for dance.

column3: Asian Pacific Islander Desi American Activists
column6: Through a process of political activism, Asian Pacific-Islander Desi American Activists aim to address Asian Pacific-Islander Desi American issues through education and civic engagement. We hope to celebrate Pan-Asian culture by dispelling stereotypes, addressing and dismantling anti-blackness and reclaiming the Pan-Asian identities on campus as well as illustrating the diversity of concerns within the community.

Behind the Glass: Immigration Reflections leads the Emory University community in informed advocacy and activism for U.S. immigrant communities. Changing immigration legal systems and policies can be difficult to understand. In order to be allies in this movement, our work thus includes visiting Stewart Detention Center, letter-writing to detained immigrants, and connecting with Emory faculty, legal experts, and Atlanta organizations well-versed on institutional aspects of US immigration.
Students can maintain connections with detainees at Stewart Detention Center, the largest private detention facility in the US. They conduct humanitarian visits with undocumented immigrants detained at Stewart Detention Center. Amidst the pandemic, we have created a pen-pal program between detained immigrants and Emory University students, staff, and faculty. These are both a way of creating friendships with those separated and isolated, but also ensuring all detainees are living under sound conditions. Through letter writing corresponded and visitations, we, as a community, can gain a deeper understanding of the issue of immigration and detention from both factual and personal perspectives. We also plan to host panel events with guest speakers from leading law offices, organizations, and assemblies across the country who advocate for immigrant rights.
BTG Overview Presentation
Please contact Daisy Cossio at dcossio@emory.edu for any questions and concerns.

Ben Pius Mock Trial is Emory University’s undergraduate trial advocacy team. Each year we receive a case from the American Mock Trial Association and engage in trial simulations, filling both witness and attorney roles. We try the case against other schools, and are currently ranked in the top 20 teams in the nation.

The Emory Bioethics Society is an organization that provides a place for students to learn about and discuss bioethical issues. We promote conversations outside the classroom with discussions, panelist events, movie nights, and more.

The objective of the organization, as part of the national organization BridgeUSA, is to provide a free, open, and nonpartisan forum for political discourse, where a diverse body of non-like-minded individuals can engage in a civil, fact-based, and intellectual exchange of ideas. This group shall celebrate the full spectrum of opinions and create a spirit of community and mutual respect among its members.

The American Red Cross prevents and alleviates human suffering in the face of emergencies by mobilizing the power of volunteers and the generosity of donors. Through multiple blood drives and fundraising events throughout the semester, being involved with the Emory Red Cross is not only fulfilling and fun! 
 This club has been founded on the principles of the American Red Cross and strives to do deeds that ultimately assist the Red Cross in its endeavors and serve the communities near Atlanta.

180 Degrees Consulting (180DC) is the world's largest volunteer consultancy. We facilitate top students in creating social impact and gaining hands-on consulting experience by helping non-profits around the world solve their most challenging problems. Additionally, we offer professional training and development of transferable life skills to create a large, international network of future leaders in the consulting and non-profit fields.
Follow us on IG @emory180dc for additional information.

4 Justice is Emory University’s first Criminal Justice Reform Club. We seek to improve the criminal justice system in 4 steps:
Inform the public of the severity of racial injustice present in the justice system by publishing written reports about the true difficulties caused by incarceration as well as the seemingly nonsensical reasons why some people are incarcerated. 
Fight for clemency or pardon for individuals serving unusually long sentences
Work to improve conditions for children, families, and individuals impacted by the criminal justice system
Encourage legislators to implement strategies to prevent unnecessary incarceration

ChemOx aims to promote awareness of chemistry in a social atmosphere within the school as well as the local community, and we work toward providing members with a deeper understanding and appreciation of chemistry, and of how it influences our everyday lives.

The first student-managed quantitative investment fund at Emory University with $100k of the endowment under management, Algory Capital provides students a unique opportunity to gain experience in quantitative finance through the research, development, and utilization of statistical models and trading algorithms across a variety of equity sectors and asset classes.
Quantitative Investment and Global Market analysts undergo an intensive training process and work together to manage the fund's assets
We host events such as trading competitions, networking events, and discussion panels with industry experts throughout the academic year. Visit www.algorycapital.com to learn more.

Alpha Kappa Psi is the world's oldest and largest professional business fraternity, founded with the mission to become the premier developer of principled business leaders. While the national organization recognizes about 14,000 active members and over 200,000 alumni members, our chapter at Emory University consists of around 100 students of a variety of majors and interests. We seek to uphold Alpha Kappa Psi's core values of knowledge, unity, integrity, brotherhood, and service through our professional and networking events and support, our social events and emphasis on mentorship, and our service and fundraising outreach efforts in the community.

4 Justice is Emory University’s first Criminal Justice Reform Club. We seek to improve the criminal justice system in 4 steps:
Inform the public of the severity of racial injustice present in the justice system by publishing written reports about the true difficulties caused by incarceration as well as the seemingly nonsensical reasons why some people are incarcerated. 
Fight for clemency or pardon for individuals serving unusually long sentences
Work to improve conditions for children, families, and individuals impacted by the criminal justice system
Encourage legislators to implement strategies to prevent unnecessary incarceration

Adrenaline is a Co-Ed hip-hop group which aims to share knowledge about hip-­hop dance, learning from each other and broadening their skills as movers through practice and performance.
Adrenaline also hopes to provide students with a platform upon which their ideas can be presented and developed, and in doing so produce dancers with stronger choreographic abilities and communication methods as teachers of their craft.

Discover giving opportunities that align with your passions and push the boundaries of leadership and knowledge. Learn about awards and leadership stipends that are donor funded. Together we can create, engage, and inspire.
This portal will serve as a hub for communication to and from student organization advisors across the Emory campus.
Alas de un Mismo Pájaro is a dance team that works to advocate for, support, and represent Afro-Latinx students at Emory and beyond by bringing awareness to underrepresented identities through dance.

We're an anime club that has bi-weekly meetings usually at White Hall and now hopefully through Discord. We watch anime suggested and voted on by the community and hopefully we'll be able to hold some events.

column3: Asian Fusion Dance Team - Oxford College
column6: Welcome to Asian Fusion Dance Team (AFDT)! This dance team at Oxford College focuses on East Asian dances ranging from K-Pop to Chinese Traditional to Modern Asian Dance. All activities and dances are coordinated by students with a passion for this cultural dance, and all are welcome! The team's mission is to spread East Asian Culture through the medium of dance.

As Black student-athletes on a predominately white campus (PWI), we uphold not only our academics and athletics but also our identities. While some can relate to being a minority or student-athlete, very few meet at this intersection, which is why we have come together to form the Emory Black Student Athlete Group. We come with the mission to foster a stronger black student-athlete community, advocate for one another, and celebrate our black identity at a PWI. Our objectives include but aren’t limited to: boosting school spirit and attendance at sports events, giving back to the greater Emory and Atlanta communities, and promoting further development of athletes on and off the floor.

BlaeZ is an established co-ed dance crew on campus, mainly focusing on street dance, choreography, and K-pop. Our vision is to unify multiple communities across Emory by embracing different pop cultures. We are run solely by students with a passion for dance.

Break Emory is a group to cultivate the element of hip-hop known as breaking (commonly referred to as breakdancing) within Emory’s campus. Break Emory strives to provide connections between the local Atlanta dance community and Emory’s student body. Our mission includes offering practices, instruction, and providing a community of support for students who are interested in the art. Breaking can often seem intimidating at first and we want to make it more accessible to the student body. Break Emory is intended to provide a low-stress and freely accessible space for everyone and anyone who wants to learn the art of breaking. Peace, unity, love, and having fun are values of hip-hop that Break Emory seeks to incorporate in its activities and operations.

Our mission is to explore, evaluate and document Black life at Emory as we navigate the contemporary moment. You can find our podcast on YouTube, Spotify, and Apple Podcasts.
