column2: Religion, Spirituality, Faith - Based, and Philosophical
column6:
Beloved Community is Emory’s progressive, ecumenical Protestant worshipping community. Beloved Community’s membership includes currently registered Emory undergraduate students, but others are invited to join in worship and activities, including graduate/professional students, faculty, staff, and members of the wider community. A central value of Beloved community is contextualizing our faith within the current sociocultural context. People of all racial, cultural, and religious backgrounds are welcomed and affirmed. Beloved Community cultivates a sense of belonging through worship and lunch together after our services. We foster an inclusive environment through the diversity of voices we lift up each week.
  Beloved Community has its roots in a tradition of University Worship that began at Emory in the late 1960s during an important time of racial integration. It was felt at the time that there were not worship opportunities in the local area that were deeply inclusive of people of all races, and so the Emory university chaplain and students began University Worship. The community has always maintained a progressive, inclusive Christian worshipping community, which in time grew to include the full inclusion of LGBTQIA+ members in this Christian community. As Emory has broadened in its religious diversity, the community adopted the more modest name of “Beloved Community,” echoing a central theological concept for The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Today, Beloved Community continues to offer the only regular Protestant worship service in Emory’s Cannon Chapel on Sunday mornings during the academic term. It is a link to Emory’s United Methodist heritage that welcomes all into creative and ecumenical Christian worship that is intended to center the needs of current Emory students. Preachers come from the Emory community, including students, as well as prominent guests. Other aspects of our organization’s life include fellowship meals, Bible studies, retreats, the celebration of major Christian holidays and seasons, and works of service and social justice.

column2: Religion, Spirituality, Faith - Based, and Philosophical
column6: The Emory Bioethics Society is an organization that provides a place for students to learn about and discuss bioethical issues. We promote conversations outside the classroom with discussions, panelist events, movie nights, and more.

column2: Religion, Spirituality, Faith - Based, and Philosophical
column6: The Black Student Caucus (BSC) is a Candler-based organization for persons interested in enhancing Black identity through cultural awareness, community cohesiveness, and celebration of heritage. The BSC seeks to inspire spiritual maturity, promote academic excellence, and foster community within Candler School of Theology and Emory University. The BSC cultivates authentic and healthy relations between all persons through dialogue that promotes respect for, and understanding of, cultural and religious differences, and the needs relevant to those differences.

column2: Religion, Spirituality, Faith - Based, and Philosophical
column6: Bread Coffeehouse is a place unlike any other on campus…a place where good coffee flows freely, yummy treats are served daily, where residents and staff know your name, where you will be treated with love no matter what you believe, a place that never pushes Jesus on you but a place where the staff believes in serving Jesus by serving you and loving you. We have live bands, great dinners, quiet study times, deep conversations, great story tellers and people who will listen to you. And, we are a lot of fun! Come play ping pong or a board game, write quotes on the wall, swing in our indoor hammock, decorate a book page, play with our play dough or dance in the kitchen.

column2: Religion, Spirituality, Faith - Based, and Philosophical
column6:
Bread Coffeehouse is a place unlike any other on campus… a place where good coffee flows freely, yummy treats are served daily, where residents and staff know your name, where you will be treated with love no matter what you believe, a place that never pushes Jesus on you but a place where the staff believes in serving Jesus by serving you and loving you.
The house will be open Monday through Thursday at various times- check our Instagram for specific times!
Come by the house on TUESDAYS from 6-8 PM to grab a cup of soup and homemade bread! 
Souper Tuesday: Every Tuesday 6-8 PM @ Bread House - 303 Emory Street
Coffee on Campus: Tuesday 11 AM - 11:30 AM
Open House Hours: Monday-Thursday (various times posted to Instagram)

column2: Religion, Spirituality, Faith - Based, and Philosophical
column6:
The Candler Baptist Community is a student-led organization that gathers regularly for fellowship and support. The CBC consists of students from several Baptist denominations, and it encourages dialogue among all who share in the Baptist heritage. Periodic luncheons provide an opportunity for conversation and sharing.
The purpose of the CBC is fourfold: to provide support for Baptist students preparing for ministry; to provide opportunities for networking and job placement in cooperation with the Baptist Studies Program to raise awareness of issues of importance that affect Baptist students at Candler; to promote theological education that is enriched and enlivened through ecumenical dialogue and relationships.

column2: Religion, Spirituality, Faith - Based, and Philosophical
column6: C3's purpose is to coordinate activities and budget monies for all organizations, as well as to legislate policies for chartered organizations. The group is composed of representatives elected by student organizations, and various other student constituencies, and appointed representatives including students serving on Candler's standing committees. Diversity at Candler is what makes this experience so rich with opportunities for transformation and growth. We encourage you to join an organization with others who share your passion and add to the richness that is our legacy! Come. Connect. Create.

The American Red Cross prevents and alleviates human suffering in the face of emergencies by mobilizing the power of volunteers and the generosity of donors. Through multiple blood drives and fundraising events throughout the semester, being involved with the Emory Red Cross is not only fulfilling and fun! 
 This club has been founded on the principles of the American Red Cross and strives to do deeds that ultimately assist the Red Cross in its endeavors and serve the communities near Atlanta.

180 Degrees Consulting (180DC) is the world's largest volunteer consultancy. We facilitate top students in creating social impact and gaining hands-on consulting experience by helping non-profits around the world solve their most challenging problems. Additionally, we offer professional training and development of transferable life skills to create a large, international network of future leaders in the consulting and non-profit fields.
Follow us on IG @emory180dc for additional information.

Are you interested in using cutting-edge technology to make a positive impact on your community? Then our 3D printing and modeling club is the perfect fit for you! We are a group of students who are passionate about using 3D printing to create innovative solutions for real-world problems. From designing toys to help children with disabilities to creating sustainable products that reduce waste, the possibilities are endless. Our club provides a platform for students to learn and collaborate on exciting projects that will make a difference in the world. Join us and discover how you can use your skills to change the world, one print at a time.

Youth in juvenile detention centers often experience gaps in their education that can leave them unprepared to return to school upon release. Education and mentorship are important factors that can potentially prevent youth from falling behind. Our organization seeks to tutor and mentor these youth to stay on track with their coursework and fill in any content gaps in any core academic subjects. We want to ensure that incarcerated youth receive the same level of  academic support as other students. We hope that Emory students can serve as positive role models for the youth at the DeKalb Regional Youth Detention Center and provide one-on-one and small group academic instruction that will allow them to excel.
  We are not actively recruiting.

Active Minds is a national non-profit that seeks to initiate conversations about mental health, increase awareness about mental illness, and use the student voice to radically change the language surrounding and attitudes towards mental health through research, advocacy, and education. The Emory chapter of this organization shares these same missions to educate the student body about mental health, discourage the stigmas associated with mental illness, and encourage students to use the resources available and seek help when necessary by hosting speakers and discussions and collaborating with other organizations to increase awareness on campus.

column3: Addiction Medicine and Harm Reduction Interest Group
column6:
We use a four pronged approach to increase knowledge around addiction and harm reduction:
We seek to offer medical students and current medical professionals in any specialty opportunities to learn about how they can integrate knowledge surrounding addiction medicine and harm reduction into their practice. 
We will provide current medical students opportunities for career development related to addiction medicine and harm reduction. 
We will engage with local communities to provide increased accessibility to harm reduction services and addiction related resources. 
We will advocate for curriculum advancement surrounding addiction and harm reduction for MD students.

column6:
Alpha Phi Omega is a national coeducational service organization founded on the principles of Leadership, Friendship and Service. We are the Delta Kappa chapter.
The purpose of this Fraternity shall be to assemble college students in a National Service Fraternity in the fellowship of the principles derived from the Scout Oath and Law of the Boy Scouts of America; to develop Leadership, to promote Friendship, and to provide Service to humanity; and to further the freedom that is our national, educational, and intellectual heritage.

Discover giving opportunities that align with your passions and push the boundaries of leadership and knowledge. Learn about awards and leadership stipends that are donor funded. Together we can create, engage, and inspire.

Delta Tau Delta returned to Emory in 2015 and is offering a different kind of fraternity experience. Delta Tau Delta offers much more than just a social opportunity. With academics as a primary focus, becoming a member provides access to countless resources, leadership development opportunities and a network of over 100,000 living alumni. The men of Delta Tau Delta are Committed to Lives of Excellence and are looking for men at Emory who are ready to be a part of something extraordinary.

The BSC seeks to inspire spiritual maturity, promote academic excellence, and foster community within Candler School of Theology and Emory University. The BSC cultivates authentic and healthy relations between all persons through dialogue that promotes respect for, and understanding of, cultural and religious differences, and the needs relevant to those differences.

The Candler Baptist Community is a student-led organization that gathers regularly for fellowship and support. The CBC consists of students from several Baptist denominations, and it encourages dialogue among all who share in the Baptist heritage. Periodic luncheons provide an opportunity for conversation and sharing.
The purpose of the CBC is fourfold: to provide support for Baptist students preparing for ministry; to provide opportunities for networking and job placement in cooperation with the Baptist Studies Program to raise awareness of issues of importance that affect Baptist students at Candler; to promote theological education that is enriched and enlivened through ecumenical dialogue and relationships.

CISA represents the broad variety of international students within the Candler student body. The students delegate a representative from each country to form the association's executive committee. The purpose of CISA is to create and encourage a harmonious community for Candler's students, faculty, and administrators. To this end, CISA aspires to raise awareness of international concerns, provide a forum for discussion of such issues, enable students to share their gifts and talents, and support international students in their academic pursuits at Candler. It is hoped that by participating in and sponsoring activities such as workshops, worship services, community conversations, international lunches, and other special events, CISA will build community. CISA welcomes everyone to be a part of its community.

The Candler Women (CW) is a Candler-based organization for persons seeking to provide community support and advocacy for women. Candler Women also plans and participates in worship services for women, Women's Week activities, and Women's History Month, and promotes the program for Women, Theology, and Ministry. Candler Women co-sponsors events with other Candler groups that minister to the whole Candler community and/or support issues of reconciliation and justice. Membership is open to all women who are associated with Candler.

The American Red Cross prevents and alleviates human suffering in the face of emergencies by mobilizing the power of volunteers and the generosity of donors. Through multiple blood drives and fundraising events throughout the semester, being involved with the Emory Red Cross is not only fulfilling and fun! 
 This club has been founded on the principles of the American Red Cross and strives to do deeds that ultimately assist the Red Cross in its endeavors and serve the communities near Atlanta.

The 1915 Scholars program is designed to help you meet your academic, social, and professional development needs as a first-gen college student. The program connects you with a small, intentional “family” cluster to provide support as you build a solid foundation for success. This family cluster includes first-generation peers, graduate mentors, and alumni mentors. The family cluster also serves as a supportive network for you on and off the Emory campus.

Active Minds is a national non-profit that seeks to initiate conversations about mental health, increase awareness about mental illness, and use the student voice to radically change the language surrounding and attitudes towards mental health through research, advocacy, and education. The Emory chapter of this organization shares these same missions to educate the student body about mental health, discourage the stigmas associated with mental illness, and encourage students to use the resources available and seek help when necessary by hosting speakers and discussions and collaborating with other organizations to increase awareness on campus.

Allied Health - Department of Physical Therapy

column3: Alumni of Pennsylvania School for Excellence in the Agricultural Sciences
column6: Professional group related to the alumni of PGSAS/PSEAS providing outreach, network, and support. Focusing on efforts in education, increasing awareness of the agricultural and natural resources communities. We hope to adapt past alumni and experiences to shape the current era of agricultural outreach in the Penn State community in hopes of creating a more passionate and successful agricultural future.

The American Association of Drilling Engineers is a professional society with the purpose of gaining energy industry exposure for its members. This is pursued with technical electives, technical discussions, tours of oil and natural gas rigs and facilities, and our annual trip to the AADE conference. Technical electives allow for an industry professional to teach a weekend course to students about a currently used engineering technique. Our technical discussions allow for students to view the newest technology of the oil industry be presented and discussed by current engineers. Our rig tours allow for students to tour and interview workers within working facilities of the energy industry. Our conference allows for the most dedicated members to talk with hundreds of companies directly.

column3: American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineers
column6: The purpose of the Pre-professional Branch of ASABE is to promote directly and indirectly the interests of the students of Agricultural and Biological Engineering, particularly as these interests relate to their professional advancements and to the parent society of ASABE.
aeepennstate.org

column3: Association of Water Students at Penn State
column6: The Penn State Association of Water Students (PAWS) is intended for students from across different plans of study and departments who are interested and/or involved in water issues and research activities. We want to create a space where students can collaborate and share ideas, network, socialize, engage with the community in relation to water issues and find information on water events and research here at Penn State and the broader water community. This will be done by hosting professional development talks, volunteer services opportunities, social events, and skills workshops.

The Beekeepers Club exists as a space for beekeeping-enthusiasts and for those simply interested in learning about/sharing the beekeeping hobby. We promote the importance of honeybees through various activities. Members may be granted opportunities to visit beekeeping locations, to hear talks from experts in the field, and to help the club start/maintain our own colonies in order to further our appreciation and knowledge of honeybees and beekeeping.

Block and Bridle, known as the premier livestock and horse club on campus at Penn State, is one of the most active clubs on campus, not just on Ag Hill but also at the university level. Block and Bridle currently has 75 active members, these members have livestock and horses as a common interest and participate in a variety of activities which range from social and educational events to community service. Transfer and freshmen students are greeted in the fall at the club's Welcome Back picnic where old members reunite and new members begin to form lasting friendships. General club meetings are held every first and third Thursday of the month, with the board of directors meetings being held on alternative weeks. New students have ample opportunities to become involved with the club and are encouraged to participate as they are required to assist with at least four events to become an initiated member.
The diverse background of club members allows the interests in all species of livestock to be well represented at club events. Block and Bridle's equine enthusiasts participate in several horse related events throughout the year. Students become involved with horses on campus by participating in weanling and mare handling/grooming and also by assisting with the Penn State Quarter Horse spring sale. Students with a meat interest help with ham processing for the fall and spring meat sales. Those with cattle experience assist with the State Bull Test Sale where approximately 100 bulls are clipped every spring. Sheep fans help with the Keystone International Livestock exposition. Also, members with a judging passion have the opportunity to run several livestock and horse judging contests. Members volunteer at the Keystone International Livestock Exposition and The Penn State Spring Judging Workout. Members with a goat interest help with the club's newest annual event, an American Boer Goat Association sanctioned show each fall. While most club members have a specific species of interest, all members are encouraged and welcome to participate in every event.
We Are…Penn State! Club members have a lot of school spirit and regularly attend Penn State footballs games together and cheer in the infamous student section. Students share their Penn State pride by helping to host the annual Prospective Student Open House. High school Students have the opportunity to visit campus for two days and experience life as a College of Agricultural Sciences student first hand. In addition to showing school spirit, club members also enjoy educating campus about the College of Agricultural Sciences. 
Blood for Bats is now in its thirteenth year as a club activity. Blood is harvested from cattle at the PSU Meats Lab and delivered to the Philadelphia Zoo as the primary food source for their vampire bat colonies. The zoo appreciates the club's efforts as we have consistently delivered blood with low microbial counts.
Each year, Block and Bridle hits the road to proudly represent Penn State at the National Block and Bridle Convention. Members benefit from networking with other Block and Bridle members from across the country. This year 15 members of the club traveled to Lincoln, Nebraska for convention. In February, Fifteen Block and Bridle students joined forces with Dairy Science Club members at the University of Rhode Island for the North East Student Affiliate (NESA). Contestants judged livestock classes consisting of horses, dairy cows, beef heifers, market hogs, breeding ewes, and oysters. Members also participated in quiz bowl competitions and oral presentations. Penn State was well represented with an overall count of 7 teams; we made our school proud as well as our devoted advisors by being named the 1st place Overall University at the competition. Penn State had the 1st place team overall, 1st and 2nd place teams in quiz bowl, 1st and 3rd place speeches, and 2nd place team in judging.
Block and Bridle is proud of their contributions to the Penn State community. We wrapped up the academic year by hosting and contributing to our Beef Up the Blood Supply spring blood drive. It is the largest Penn State blood drive held on campus and provides donors with a nutritious hamburger following their donation. We have had a pretty good turn out in the past few years.
Along with the many service activities, club members, initiates, and advisors enjoy each other's company throughout the semester at many social events. Members could be found playing bowling at Northland Bowl downtown in the fall. In the winter, our club was seen watching the very popular movie Encanto and singing along. Many club members showcased their athletic talent by participating in intramural (IM) football, and dodge-ball at Penn State.
  Little International, or Little I, is one of the most anticipated events of the year and Block and Bridle would not be complete without this long-standing tradition. This year, the Little International celebrated its 104th year as a long standing tradition with Block and Bridle at the Pennsylvania State University. Fifty students participated this year, while more than one hundred alumni came back for the show. The morning started with the opening ceremony followed by the introduction of the judges who were each show managers or assistant show managers of previous shows. The event concluded with a round robin, where the overall showmen for each species competed against each other for Overall Champion Showman. The Stockmen's club, the Block and Bridle alumni group, partnered with Block & Bridle to make this year's event a success, providing both breakfast and lunch. Additionally, alumni were given the opportunity to participate in a livestock judging contest. Participants perfected their fitting and showmanship skills and were able to display their hard work to a full Snider Agricultural Arena.
Club members are excited to debut a new prestigious club sponsored by Block and Bridle: The Penn State Saddle & Sirloin Club. This club was created to raise additional funds every year for the club's endowment account, which will benefit the club in years to come. In order to gain membership to the club a beautiful saddle, donated by Roger Allgeier of Brighton Feeds & Saddlery in Brighton, Colorado, must be "bought." The saddle remains in the room of traditions at Penn State and plaques are placed on a latigo strap recognizing the newest owner and member of the club. This spring was our inaugural sale and the saddle sold for $5000. A very generous alumnus, Bill MacCauley, matched the sale price to bring the final total to $10,000 for the endowment account! The latigo strap will gain a plaque honoring Dr. Harold Harpster, a very influential faculty member at Penn State, and Vivian Baumer, a previous adviser to the club who passed away this spring.
As you can tell, Block and Bridle members stay busy year round with club activities. Club advisors Dr. Daniel Kniffen, Dr. Ed Mills, Mr. Chris Grant, and Mr. Ben Williamson are proud of our hard work and accomplishments and continue to offer their time and support. We maintain a tradition as one of the dominant clubs on Ag Hill and strive to continue that tradition of excellence as members before, during, and after each club event.

Stimulates the interests of the University in various accounting fields and presents the students with experienced viewpoints from the business world.                       
GroupMe Link: https://groupme.com/join_group/69833202/Ul4k1rPq
https://groupme.com/join_group/69833202/Ul4k1rPq

Helps students learn what it means to be an actuary, develop professionally, pass actuarial exams, and secure jobs and internships through a variety of annual events, including an actuarial career fair, technical trainings, mock interviews, company info sessions, and funding for exam resources.
Join the weekly email here: http://eepurl.com/gUH5xb
Join the GroupMe here: https://groupme.com/join_group/28806968/DL93oAL3

The AD/PR Club aims to promote a better understanding of the function and values of advertising and public relations, and stimulate and encourage advertising/PR professionalism. Throughout the semester, we host industry professionals that connect with our students and provide insight to various career paths. Our goal is to educate and guide students in The College of Communications. 
  Interested in becoming a member? Email Alayna Kopacka at azk694@psu.edu!

Alpha Kappa Psi is the oldest and largest business fraternity in the country. As a brother, you are joining a network of more than 260,000 individuals worldwide. AKPsi is proud to be the home of alumni that have held positions that range from Fortune 500 CEOs to non-profit organizations. The possibilities for you and your career goals are endless; the first step to your success is here! 

The Gamma Epsilon Chapter was founded at Penn State in 1951. Rooted in tradition, this chapter has been able to develop thousands of principled business leaders. Alpha Kappa Psi is proud to provide brothers with the highest professional development on campus, preparing each individual for their time beyond Penn State. Most importantly, this fraternity has a very unique community of brotherhood, leading to strong friendships that last a lifetime.

column3: American Marketing Association at Penn State
column6:
Interested in marketing or related industries? PSAMA is ranked #1 nationally and offers our members 5 divisions that focus on the areas of digital advertising, analytics, sports, retail, and sales! Within your division you will work on real life marketing projects for our corporate sponsors while also learning about industry trends, professional development, and teamwork. We also accept all years and majors! 
PSAMA looks to provide members with tangible marketing experiences and turn business students into business leaders.
Our mission is to provide our student members with real-world business experience; not just limited to the fundamentals of marketing, but also exploring all professional and rudimentary skills of business. Through personal and professional development, networking and leadership, we offer our members the vital prerequisites needed for any undergraduate to make a comfortable transition to the workforce.
Not only is PSAMA one of the most prominent student organizations in the Smeal College of Business at Penn State, but we are also a top ranking collegiate chapter of the American Marketing Association.  We provide our members access to some of the most sought-after networking opportunities, skill-building workshops, lecture series, case competitions, and professional development seminars available to undergraduates.
By joining one of PSAMA's 5 divisions, you will gain valuable hands-on experience working with companies who have real-life marketing challenges, whether in the realm of sports, retail, sales, digital marketing and advertising, or marketing analytics.
All Penn State undergraduate students are welcome to join Penn State AMA, regardless of academic major or year. The only prerequisites is that all members must pay their dues to the American Marketing Association to be a collegiate member as well as pay Penn State chapter operations dues.

The Business in Cosmetics Club provides students interested in the cosmetics industry with resources to learn about the field and cultivate relationships with alumni. Our goal is to improve students' knowledge of career responsibilities industry wide.

column3:
C
Consulting Organization at Penn State
column6: The Penn State Consulting Organization inspires, educates, and enables the next generation of business leaders and problem solvers by giving our members the opportunity to explore consulting as an industry and career path, acquire expertise related to collaborative, consultative problem-solving and gain experience working with clients and solving real-world challenges.

The purpose of the Corporate Innovation & Entrepreneurship Society (CIES) is to foster a creative, innovative culture within Penn State’s community. Our aim is to strengthen the academic and professional network of students interested in Corporate Innovation & Entrepreneurship.

Delta Sigma Pi is a professional fraternity organized to foster the study of business in universities; to encourage scholarship, social activity and the association of students for their mutual advancement by research and practice; to promote closer affiliation between the commercial world and students of commerce, and to further a higher standard of commercial ethics and culture and the civic and commercial welfare of the community.

The Penn State Boxing Club promotes the physical well being of the Penn State community and provides instruction for recreational and competitive skills in boxing.  No prior experience is required; we have trained side by side with first-timers, skilled fighters, and national collegiate champions.

WE ARE...Penn State's Club Badminton Team! We welcome students of all levels and have practice times several time a week in which the courts are reserved for club members only. Dues are collected each semester to help the club provide feather shuttles for everyone. Within the club, there is also a competitive team to play in tournaments against other schools. Tryouts are held in the beginning of fall semester, and an unofficial tryouts in the spring. 
You can also get connected with us! Search for our Facebook group "Penn State Club Badminton" and request to join. We also have a GroupMe and Instagram @psubadminton.

Club Bass Fishing provides its members with the opportunity to further their knowledge and enjoyment of the sport of fishing. The club also provides a platform for its members to compete in the highest levels of the sport. The club hosts meetings on a bi weekly basis. Along with instruction and competition, PSBF is active in the local fishing community, with community service events and seminars throughout the country.

Dude on rock?
The Climbing Club composes of both recreational and competitive climbers that would like to elevate their general climbing knowledge, technique, strength, and mobility through a supportive and engaging environment. We utilize the Intramural Building's Climbing Suite with occasional trips to the local gym, Climb Nittany. 
Rock on, Dude!

The purpose of Penn State Crew is to instruct members of all level of ability in the sport of rowing and to instill life skills in its members that will enable them to continue to enjoy the sport of rowing beyond their years at the Pennsylvania State University.

The Creative Writing Club shall provide a community for Penn State students to mature in their writing and shall host events, collaborative efforts, and retreats to inspire creative endeavors. Through this association, student writers will improve upon their craft and bring further artistic value to Penn State.

Delta Kappa Alpha is a national organization with chapters on 25 campuses across the country. DKA strives to connect like-minded students with a passion for entertainment and provide them with opportunities to grow personally and professionally.

To provide daily online publications that will be an informal, fun source of advice, humor, news, commentary, etc. to Penn Staters; to provide students with professional experience in the world of online periodicals; to work with the national Her Campus staff to uphold the Her Campus purpose in a Penn State setting.

Kalliope, Penn State’s undergraduate literary magazine, is sponsored by the Penn State English Department.
  The purpose of Kalliope is to further the ideals of free and open literary expression by establishing a writing community.  It also provides a literary outlet through the publication of student work, public readings, and lectures.
  Kalliope includes works of fiction, nonfiction, poetry, and visual art. The selection process begins late in the fall semester and ends early in the spring semester. This period is followed by the production process, in which the staff designs and assembles the magazine. The resulting publication is printed and distributed before the end of the academic year.
If you're new and want to get involved make sure to follow us on Instagram where we post regularly and join our Slack!
(https://join.slack.com/t/kalliope2023-24/shared_invite/zt-20vh8du0x-KGemnz74Ztp5pc0AmrG36A)

La Vie is Penn State's official yearbook, and is also its oldest club! We have been preserving Penn State's memories since 1889 with our annual publication, and continue to do so every year. La Vie is nationally recognized as one of the country's best college yearbooks, and we regularly receive prestigious awards for our efforts. We provide opportunities to explore various different fields, such as photography, writing, advertising, marketing and more! Experience is not necessary. Come join our staff to be a part of preserving Penn State's history!

ARHS is Penn State's on-campus student government that strives to improve the quality of life for all students at University Park. We work to better the on-campus community through:
Collaborating with RAs and Housing & Food Services to enhance residence hall living
Providing opportunities for student engagement and leadership growth
Advocating for students' needs and interests within on-campus housing
Funding events that benefit on-campus students
ARHS encourages involvement from all PSU students interested in improving the campus experience at University Park. We are always looking for new members who want to make a positive difference in campus life for their fellow students.

The Blue & White Society is the student membership of the Penn State Alumni Association. As the student alumni association, the Blue & White Society helps students establish a connection with the university, get involved across campus by providing members with community service, athletic events, and campus-wide activities, and offers students professional development and networking opportunities with alumni. With plenty of leadership opportunities available and plenty of ways to get involved, the Blue & White Society is University Park's most active student organization.
    To learn more, check out our website at http://www.bluewhitesociety.com/.
    Our Mission: To enhance student life at Penn State through diversified experience, with an emphasis on service to the community, civil leadership, tradition, and outreach while establishing the foundation of a lifelong commitment to the University as members of the Penn State Alumni Association.

column3: College of Education Graduate Student Council
column6: The College of Education Graduate Student Council (CoEGSC) was created for and by graduate students to facilitate relationships between students, faculty, administration and staff across departments and programs. CoEGSC serves as a resource for graduate students and focuses on advocating for and enriching the graduate student experience through various organized events, both formal and informal in nature.

The College of Education Student Council seeks to represent the undergraduate student body of the College of Education and promote meaningful student interactions with 1) the College’s administration, 2) the College’s Alumni Society Board and alumni at-large, 3) the College’s Office of Development and Alumni Relations, 4) the College’s Advising Center, 5) the College’s faculty members, 6) other students and student organizations in the College and University, and 7) the larger community of Penn State and its surrounding areas.

column3: College of Health and Human Development Undergraduate Student Council

column6: The Council of Commonwealth Student Governments (CCSG) advocates for the 19 Penn State Commonwealth Campuses by providing a forum for communication, growth, unity and legislative opportunities for Penn State students.

DNA Day is a National annual event on April 25th organized by the National Human Genome Research Institute to commemorate the discovery of the double helix and the completion of the Human Genome Project. DNA Day at PSU is one of many growing chapters across the nation and the second chapter to be established in Pennsylvania! As a science outreach program, our collective DNA Day Network mission is to break down the barriers to science and bridge the gap between research institutions and the public by promoting young adult's interest in science. To accomplish this goal, DNA Day at PSU has partnered with local Pennsylvania high schools with an emphasis on underserved communities that have limited opportunities for science outreach and exposure. Our Penn State chapter pairs scientists with local high school teachers to present interactive module lessons and hands-on workshops to teach students about DNA, the latest advances in Genetics and Genomics research and technology, and exciting career paths in the field. This program also gives high school students the unique opportunity to interact with early-career scientists and break down misconceptions about who scientists are and how we carry out our own original research, thereby demystifying scientists as a whole and expanding career options many high school students have not previously considered.

column3: Earth and Mineral Sciences Student Council
column6: The college of EMS Student Council provides a vital link between students, administration, and community in an attempt to enrich the intellectual and social atmosphere of the College of Earth and Mineral Sciences. Our meetings are held on alternating Wednesday evenings at 6pm with our THON Organization with some combined Student Council/THON meetings. Throughout the semester we host many events to help enrich the atmosphere of the college. We host professional development events such as faculty-student dinners, breakfast with the deans, and events with the Graduates of EMS (GEMS). We also host many social events such as a homecoming celebration in the fall, the college's semi-formal night (Gala) in January, an end of the year picnic in May, as well as many other smaller events throughout the year. All students, including those outside of the College of EMS, are welcome to join!

Global Brigades is the largest We coordinate the activities of the four Global Brigades clubs on campus, in addition to working at local volunteering initiatives. Though the focus of the club is international volunteering we put a lot of emphasis on volunteering in our community. International volunteering is primarily run by the other Global Brigades clubs on campus such as Global Water Brigades and Global Medical Brigades who travel to Central America, Europe, and Africa to work with communities.

The mission of the Graduate and Professional Student Association (GPSA), in striving to enrich the experience of graduate and professional students, shall be to provide: a unified and informed voice representing graduate and professional students to the University’s administration, Board of Trustees, academic units, and other external organizations that make decisions on behalf of students; a forum to address the ideas and concerns of graduate and professional students; support of scholarly activities and professional development; leadership, social, and service opportunities to the graduate and professional student body; and, events and activities to promote a sense of community among graduate and professional students and their families.

We are a space for people of all abilities to form both friendships and alliances on issues that affect persons with disabilities. We aim to spread awareness about disability rights issues and to advocate for a more accessible campus and world.

The African Students Association (ASA) was founded at the Pennsylvania State University on February 3, 1969. ASA is an organization geared towards increasing student awareness about the African continent. As a collective, our mission is to unite the sons and daughters of the motherland and all those concerned with her welfare. We further this mission by creating an impact on campus with annual events, awareness programs, attending other cultural and social events, and uplifting the name of the Motherland in all we do.
  Our Aims are:
To foster a fraternal relationship and better understanding among fellow Africans.
To project the African image in the American society through social and cultural activities.
To promote friendship between us and the American people and the rest of the world.
To engender the spirit of Pan-Africanism.
To give moral support to the Liberation Movements in non-independent African states.

column3: Asian Pacific Islander Desi American Caucus
column6: The mission of the Asian Pacific Islander Desi American Caucus is to advocate for and promote diversity by giving a collective and unified voice to the APIDA community at the Pennsylvania State University. Through a unified and collaborative effort, we are to serve as the voice of many, ensuring diversity remains a prevalent subject for not only our community, but our institution as a whole.

The Asian Undergraduate Students Association aims to give back to the Asian community at the Pennsylvania state university by creating opportunities to achieve a higher sense of cultural and social awareness. We will serve as a voice for and to support the cultural and social interests of students with Asian pacific heritage. We will also transcend social boarder and foster relationships with other groups on campus through community interactions.
  Join our Discord! https://discord.gg/6vMc2aY3Zh

column6: To provide a flawless transition that supports the academic, professional, and social development of our fellow change of campus business students.

We are deeply committed to supporting projects with the motive to provide free education to deserving students with poor economic backgrounds, skills training, and empowerment for women.

column3: Association for Women in Sports Media
column6:
About AWSM
WE ARE...The Association for Women in Sports Media student chapter at Penn State. AWSM helps advance women in the sports media industry, provides networking and support.
Our Mission
1. Serve as a positive advocate for women in sports media by offering support, mentoring and networking services as well as national visibility.
2. Serve as a watchdog, promoting a fair portrayal of female professionals in sports media, encouraging diversity, positive workplace environments, and equal access to opportunities.
3. Mentor and assist college women interested in pursuing careers in sports media through internships and scholarships, student chapters and networking events

Welcome to the Balkan Student Association (BSA)!
Our organization is a group of passionate students from various Balkan countries who share a common interest in promoting and celebrating our cultural heritage. Our primary goal is to create a community where Balkan students can socialize and support each other.
Furthermore, we believe that by sharing our traditions, customs, and language, as well as organizing various events and activities throughout the year, such as cultural festivals, food tastings, language exchanges, and educational (history) talks, we can promote a greater understanding and appreciation of our diverse cultures to others. 
We welcome students of all backgrounds interested in learning more about Balkan culture, experiencing it, and becoming part of our vibrant community.

We have 10 departments including 5 dancing departments: Urban, Girls K-pop, Boys K-pop, Popping, ACG dance; and 5 backstage departments: Secretary, Styling, Event Planning, Media, Fund Raising. We welcome all of you who interested in us, and you can definitely find a suitable position in our dance crew to fulfill your college life and proudly say:
"I'm ACE. We are ACEs." 
We are not perfect, because we are short of you.

Mission Our Purpose: To have an open group and Company that will help to expose dancers to a variety of different styles and techniques along with having a focus on creating, shaping, and presenting choreography.The Group: We will hold open technique classes for any and all that want to either come and learn a new technique, sharpen their technique, or just want to dance for fun! The classes will be run studio style and are free and open to all students. Group members will have the chance to perform pieces if the piece is choreographed by another group and/or exec board members.The Company: The Company is for more serious dancers that have experience and are willing to commit. The Company will travel to major cities to see shows, participate in dance conferences, and take master classes. The Company will also have the chance to perform pieces choreographed by choreographers from other cities and universities. There is an audition required to become a part of The Company.AMBITIONS will also be available to perform for events, choreograph for other groups, and will accept choreography from other students.*What makes us different from all of the other dance groups on campus is that we do not limit ourselves to one style. The dance styles that we will hold technique classes for and also perform will include but is not limited to ballet, pointe, modern, jazz, lyrical, contemporary, hip-hop, tap, and Mojah along with improv and self-expression.AMBITIONS was founded in order to create a diverse forum for all students, regardless of race, major or ability, to be able to choreograph and further their dance technique freely and easily.AMBITIONS is the only group on campus who is about furthering students dance skills.

Hi everyone!! welcome to Bounce !
We are a BIG family which welcomes everyone as long as you have a passion for dancing.
(The best thing is you don't need to have experience for it.)
We were established in 2015 and we are the FIRST recognized Asian dance organization. 
We provide a variety of dance styles and many performance opportunities ( including THON weekend experiences).
We have covered and created over 200 pieces including Hip Hop, Jazz, Urban, Popping, K-pop, Contemporary, and Chinese Modern, etc. 
We also have our own YouTube channel which provides dancers with more opportunities to show their talents. We also hold open workshops for beginners.
Please join us if you are interested! :)

column3: Competitive Ballroom and Latin Dance Club at Penn State

We are proud to perform in events all over campus all year long, including Homecoming FTG Talent Show & Parade, Sports Halftime Shows, THON Showcase, and even THON Weekend!
For more pictures, videos, and information check us out on Instagram @pennstatedancealliance or on our Youtube channel, Penn State Dance Alliance!

Dark Storm Step Team is a club that will unite all students from different cultural backgrounds and to allow them to express their different cultural differences through step. Dark Storm performs at different events held on and off campus in the Penn State and State College community.

Infusion is an organization that organizes, plans, and hosts an intercollegiate dance competition. We invite 9 teams from across the country to compete for cash prizes and points to the national championships. The Infusion board firmly believes in the values the founders passed down to them, pledging to move forward with the same sincerity, hospitality, and charity.
Infusion also hosts Penn State’s Best Dance Crew with several of the finest Penn State dance teams that come to showcase their talent and love for dance!

We are in the third year towards building a Level 4 self-driving car by June 2025! This is all part of the AutoDrive II Challenge sponsored by GM and SAE. Check our website (avt.psu.edu) for more info and how to get involved!
The purpose of Pennsylvania State University's Advanced Vehicle Team is to provide students in the communications, business, and engineering fields the opportunity to gain hands-on, professional experience through engaging in advanced vehicle technology competitions.

The purpose of the American Concrete Institute Student Chapter at Penn State, hereafter referred to as ACI @ PSU, is to expose our members to the field of concrete engineering, including the studies of structural engineering and material science in coordination with the American Concrete Institute. Our goal is to aid in the professional and intellectual advancement for our members through interactions with students, faculty, professionals, and civic leaders, as well as through projects that will promote logical thinking.

column3: American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics
column6:
Our chapter’s mission is to instill a passion for aerospace engineering that leads our members to pursue impactful and gratifying careers in the aerospace profession. We also seek to promote technical excellence and a collaborative community between our members and the Aerospace faculty at Penn State.
Our chapter participates in many events, such as field trips, design challenges, guest speakers, and involvement fairs.  Our chapter tries to pick events that are both rewarding and inspiring for our members.  We also try and pick events that help underclassmen determine their choice of major.  We hope to be a place where undecided students can learn whether they want to be an aerospace engineer.
Our chapter also promotes the national organization.  Each year, we participate in the AIAA Region 1 Student Research Conference.
Finally, our chapter tries to participate in science-related events in the State College community.  We do this to try and increase the interest in STEM fields among students in our community.

Alpha Delta Phi is one of the oldest Fraternities and was originally founded in 1832 as a literary society. The Nittany Chapter officially joined the Penn State IFC in 2013 and includes brothers from a diverse range of majors and backgrounds.

Alpha Epsilon Pi (AEPi) is the world’s Jewish college fraternity, operating chapters on more than 190 college campuses in seven countries. Founded in 1913, AEPi has more than 90,000 living alumni. Alpha Epsilon Pi is a Jewish fraternity and brotherhood in Alpha Epsilon Pi is open to all who are willing to espouse its values and mission. The fraternity’s mission – developing the future leaders of the Jewish communities – is demonstrated every day through acts of brotherhood, Tzedakah, social awareness and support for Jewish communities and Israel.

Alpha Kappa Lambda (ΑΚΛ) is an American collegiate social fraternity for men founded at the University of California, Berkeley, in 1914. Today, it operates 36 active chapters and colonies and over 25,000 initiated members.
Alpha Kappa Lambda was founded on April 22, 1914 by a group of young men attending the University of California, Berkeley. Its birth, however, dates back to 1906 when a group of friends discussed the “need of Christian men for a place to live and study that was within their (financial) means.”
After assisting in the cleanup of the Great 1906 San Francisco Earthquake, four students re-addressed their desire to organize a house club during a YMCA conference in Pacific Grove, California. It was decided to form “Los Amigos” in 1907, which was a house club named from the Spanish translation of “The Friends.” Shortly after, seven more men joined Los Amigos. Reverend Gail Cleland, one of the original eleven members of Los Amigos, recalled, “When we organized Los Amigos as a house club, house clubs and fraternities were dime a dozen. They came, they lived for a few months or a few years, then they went out of existence again. But Los Amigos did not go out of existence.”
He continues, “And seven years later, in response to the suggestion of Benjamin Ide Wheeler, president of the University of California, we organized our house club as a national fraternity of one chapter.”
The founders of Los Amigos were a diverse group, but they shared a common desire for studious living in a college environment and continued integrity after their formal education concluded.

The objectives of this chapter shall be to stimulate the ambitions of it members; to prepare them for the greatest usefulness in the causes of humanity, freedom, and dignity of the individual; to encourage the highest and noblest form of manhood; and, to aid downtrodden humanity in its efforts to achieve higher social, economic, and intellectual status.
Alpha Phi Delta was founded at Penn State in 1929. Originally founded as an Italian Fraternity, Alpha Phi Delta now looks to its Italian Heritage as it progresses into the future.

We are a Fraternity founded upon the values of character. Our Values, once secret but made public in 2005, are what make us unique. Our Values call us to better ourselves through our actions and words. These are the values that we espouse:
SILENCE
He has the strength to embrace silence and the will to build an interior life founded upon an honest desire to truly listen to others. Trust in silence transcends the gulf that is created when men feel the need to compete in action or rhetoric. He is introspective and self-reliant.
CHARITY
He is charitable in the broadest sense of the word. A man who strives for a life of charity and service is more patient, kinder, and more forgiving of the flaws of others. A charitable man sacrifices of himself to help others and seeks no recognition in return. He is humble, reverent, and generous.
PURITY
He consistently strives for purity of mind, body, and soul. The man who is pure of thought, word, and deed does not shrink from adversity or lofty goals. There is no self-pity, rationalizations, or apologies. He is moral and a gentleman in the finest sense of the word.
HONOR
He lives a life of personal integrity, thereby accruing honor. An honorable man lives up to promises made to others and to himself. A man of honor is not vain, and is willing to endure scorn or ostracism rather than conform to the pressures of peers, superiors, or the fashion of the day. He is ethical, honest, and trustworthy.
PATRIOTISM
He loves his country, remaining consistently engaged in its affairs. He seeks to know his country and to pass that knowledge on to others. He is devoted to the principles of personal freedom, justice, and civic responsibility embedded in the U.S. Constitution that have made our country. He is loyal, proud, and humble.
Thus our Purpose is to Better the Man through the creation and perpetuation of brotherhood founded upon the values of character: Silence, Charity, Purity, Honor, and Patriotism.

Alpha Rho Chi is the professional co-ed fraternity for architecture and its allied arts. Brothers of Alpha Rho Chi are academically devoted to 11 different majors across various schools at Penn State. Aside from education, Alpha Rho Chi promotes brotherhood through professional, social, and philanthropic events.

Founded nationally in 1897 and Established on the Penn State campus in 1898, Alpha Zeta is the original agricultural interest fraternity on campus and in the nation.  Our house, located next to Rec Hall and across from Waring Commons at 360 N Burrowes St was completed in 1915, making it the second oldest fraternity house on campus.  Our founding members had a significant influence on shaping the Farmer's High School of Pennsylvania into what we now know as The Pennsylvania State University. This is evident around the campus in the historic plaques and by the names of the buildings.  
Alpha Zeta is a member of the Interfraternity Council and participates in all IFC programs, events, and standards.  Alpha Zeta has continually achieved noteworthy rankings in both IFC and university-facilitated Standards of Excellence metrics.  
We are always looking for men and women to share our interest in agriculture and related fields, if you think you may be interested, please stop by the house or contact us!
  Austin Kolb
President, The Morrill Chapter of Alpha Zeta

The Penn State Fitness and Bodybuilding Club is designed to provide students with the opportunity to learn about bodybuilding and receive instruction in regards to proper safety, diet, and fitness. We aim to promote fitness in every aspect. This club helps connect those passionate about bodybuilding and fitness to help share training, nutrition, and lifestyle tips. Through discipline, determination, and dedication, members will have an opportunity to succeed in both group and personal levels. Nonetheless, this club will function as a cooperative proto-public in that all members are equally responsible and accountable for each others' development. A bodybuilder, above all, is someone who stays disciplined.  Respect and discipline are vital building blocks of physical and mental well-being.

column3: Changing Health, Attitudes, and Actions To Recreate Girls at Penn State
column6: The purpose of the CHAARG of Penn State Chapter is to serve college aged students in pursuing their health and wellness goals through creating a community of peers and enhancing our members' knowledge and experience of health and wellness. CHAARG will provide opportunities for students to expand self-awareness by engaging in activities related to nutrition and fitness as well as promote programming that will explore various forms of physical activity. The programming that includes physical activity will only take place off campus.

Chess Club is dedicated to allowing undergraduate and graduate students a space to enjoy the game of chess with their peers. There are opportunities in the club to learn more about chess and participate in intercollegiate competitions. We accept players of all skill levels and strive to welcome to new players wishing to learn. We meet Tuesday and Thursday at 7pm at the Hub Aquarium during the school semester.

Join the club by joining our discord:
https://discord.gg/wP2M7ThDM8
  No restrictions on membership!
  Our Vision is to maintain an enriching, student-run program that is able to provide opportunities in the world of esports through competition, organization, and learning; to field teams that can compete at the highest levels of play; to encourage individual excellence in performance and character; to aid in social preparation of young people for the diverse world they are about to enter; to create an awareness of public service and the importance of participation in community outreach and charity, and to provide members of Penn State Esports opportunities to address every area of relevant interest to the best of the organization’s ability.
Our board members have been involved and invested in this club for years. We have been working very hard over the summer and during this semester to make the club as fun and competitive as possible for all esports athletes. We have some exciting things planned for this year and years to come, including more support for our twitch streamers, our intercollegiate LAN tournament in the spring, and building a dedicated game space on campus in the future.

The goal of this organization shall be to provide a sense of community and a safe harbor for all students seeking fun, friends, and competition. We serve the purpose of the people and serve to provide a place for all peoples alike to become one group of harmonious joy. As well as to promote the general welfare and promote community values of Penn State and State College. Here we plan to provide the ENTIRETY of Penn State a place to play either competitive or causal Cornhole.

The Penn State CrossFit club seeks to enhance the lives of students by following the training and methodology of CrossFit.  The CrossFit training program seeks to create an environment where the values of discipline, self enhancement, team unity, and accountability are encouraged and reinforced. In preparing ourselves to succeed in life, this is a great opportunity for leadership, learning, and service. This challenging, time efficient, and extremely effective physical training program has advanced the concept of fitness and has become a powerful alternative to traditional fitness routines.

Welcome to Disc Golf Club!
