The purpose of this Chapter is to serve the interests of the graduate students of the Architectural Engineering department at the Penn State University and act as a conduit between the students and the decision makers within the department. This organization functions to enhance the quality of the Architectural Engineering graduate student experience and education as well as aims to create a better sense of community within the department.

We are a group of rhetoricians promoting interdisciplinary scholarly conversations. We are now officially recognized by the Rhetoric Society of America (RSA) and were founded by Dr. Rosa Eberly in 2005.
  We aim to provide resources and assistance with professional development and teaching, organize professional and co-curricular events for graduate students, provide networking opportunities with other graduate students (past and present), faculty and staff in the University, and individuals at other academic institutions.
  Since 2010, we host our signature event, Camp Rhetoric, in the Spring, inviting rhetoricians from different institutions to a day of scholarly collaboration featuring a pair of invited speakers.

This group is intended to build community and provide graduate students within the biobehavioral health program a space where they can collaborate and share ideas, network, socialize, and find peer support for graduate school.
This will be done by hosting professional development talks, social events, and skills workshops; as well as organizing weekly writing, reading, and accountability groups.

We are the graduate student movement of Cru at Penn State University. We love the academy, find the person and works of Jesus of Nazareth to be satisfying and true, and look to Him as the beautiful hope of the world. We exist to help every grad student at Penn State embrace and deeply experience the gospel in their life, relationships, and calling as a scholar.  We have a weekly large group gathering, multiple Bible studies throughout the week, and various social activities.  Please see our website (http://pennstatechristiangrads.org) for more information and to sign up for our weekly emails.

column3: Colombian Graduate Students Community at Penn State
column6: This is an organization created for and by Colombian graduate students, professors, investigators, and their relatives, with the purpose of consolidating our academic community and raising awareness of the Colombian diaspora present at Penn State and its area of influence.

column3:
C
Comparative and International Education Student Association
column6:
The purpose of the Comparative and International Education Student Association is to
promote the development of students as scholars and future professionals in the field of
Comparative and International Education. The intention of the association is to provide a
forum for out-of-classroom education and research opportunities, networking, and
professional development relating to all matters of international and comparative
education

The goal of EGSA is to provide a sense of community to the graduate students who study entomology at Penn State: University Park. Students can be from any department, though many students are in Entomology and Ecology. EGSA's officers attend departmental committees and advocate for graduate students, and then return to meetings every other week to discuss the issues as a graduate student body. All feedback is then given back to the committees. EGSA hosts weekly social events including Craft Night, movie nights, ice cream socials, and trips to amusement parks. EGSA also helps to fund student travel to conferences as needed. Funds are collected through fundraisers by selling member-created crafts at conferences, outreach events, and sales.

The Graduate and Professional Outdoor Club is an inclusive community of graduate and professional students with a shared interest in engaging in outdoor activities. GPOC strives to lower any barrier to participation in outdoor activities by making technical and safety skills available, facilitating the use of gear and equipment, and connecting members with on and off-campus outdoor resources.

There is nothing more heartwarming than a home away from home. IGSA as an organization renders that feasible by serving as a platform for all graduate and postdoctoral fellows and potential new Indian Graduate students. We welcome those interested in the culture of our country and we strive to keep alive the rich heritage of India through and through . In the recent past we have conducted events such as Jashn, Diwali, Pongal, Ganesh Chaturthi and more!.

column3: American College of Health Care Administrators
column6: The Purpose of the American College of Health Care Administrators is to provide professional development and guidance to its members in order to help them prepare for the challenges in long-term care administration.

AMSA is a student-governed, national organization committed to representing the concerns of physicians-in-training. AMSA members are medical students, premedical students, interns, residents and practicing physicians. 
How is AMSA different from other organizations? When you join AMSA, you become part of a vital force of future physicians who believe that patients and health professionals are partners in the management of health care and that access to high-quality health care is a right and not a privilege. At AMSA, activism is a way of life. Student idealism is transformed into meaningful public service, innovation and institutional change.

The Biobehavioral Health Society was created to facilitate a positive learning environment in the undergraduate program and to foster communication between faculty and students. Our organization holds regular meetings that focus on recognizing outstanding achievements and developing educational and career opportunities for students as well.

This organization shall serve the following purposes:A. To inform members on career options within the biomedical sciences.B. To provide further insight into current research practicesC. To provide members with sources of information concerning admission to professional schoolsD. And, above all, to provide members with the opportunity to interact with professionals, alumni, and other students with similar interests and goals.

column3: College of Health and Human Development Ambassadors
column6:
As College of Health and Human Development Ambassadors, we promote the interests of the college at events involving prospective students, current students, and alumni. Students have the opportunity to participate in events that include, but are not limited to, Majors and Minors Night, College of HHD Tours, Accepted Student Programs, and events as requested per the Dean and/or other members of the College’s Administration. Our goal is to represent the College of Health and Human Development at the highest standard, while encouraging a sense of community between our Ambassadors, faculty, alumni, and most importantly, our prospective students to enhance the overall mission of the College. 
We are looking for students who are passionate about studying, not only at Penn State, but in the College of Health and Human Development. Application and interview process are required.

column3: Diversity and Inclusion Student Association in Health and Human Development
column6:
The purpose of the Diversity and Inclusion Student Association is to:
Assist the College of Health and Human Development’s (HHD) Office for Diversity and Inclusion with innovative ideas and programming that will support students from underrepresented groups. 
Raise awareness and engage in discussions surrounding topics related to diversity, identity, equity, and inclusion that impact students’ experience and their future careers working in a health and human development field. 
Collaborate to create and facilitate activities that will engage students and enhance their academic, personal and professional development. 
Attend and help with the facilitation of the Office for Diversity and Inclusion’s meetings, discussion forums and, other activities for all students 
Assist with events that promote the recruitment of underrepresented groups  
Assist with the promotion of the Office for Diversity and Inclusion through face to face interaction, flyer distribution, social media, and campus events 
Help administration identify collaboration opportunities with other diverse groups and offices on campus

The purpose and mission of the Penn State Emergency Medical Services Association is to promote camaraderie among students with an interest in EMS; to promote EMS awareness and education; and to support the university and surrounding community in its efforts to deliver quality emergency medical services.
A club where undergraduate students who are interested in participating in research can learn about how to conduct research that is related to equine health, nutrition, performance and behavior.

column3: Genetic Counseling Club at Penn State

column6:
Visit Our Website to Learn More! www.aedpsu.edu
AED is a nationally recognized honors society open to all pre-health students that takes pride in creating a community where students can feel comfortable with one another. No matter what job in the medical field you want to get into, you will find your place in AED. AED is honored to offer elite programs that will help aspiring health care students find their passion.
Our expansive shadowing program provides members with unique opportunities to observe a day in the life of any medical profession. Our volunteer program supplies members with many opportunities to serve the community and explore your interests. AED members are active in cutting edge research on campus and impacting social change through the diversity in medicine taskforce. Through the peer mentoring program we answer all questions about taking the right classes, or getting the right pre-health experiences. We also feature medical expert speakers in our meetings and professional networking.
If we want to be doctors, physician assistants, nurses, or something else in heath care, we pre-health students have one thing in common: a true passion to helping others through medicine and a dedication to reach those goals. Through AED, we aim to develop our passions and achieve excellence toward our goals.

column3: Alpha Epsilon Honor Society Omicron Chapter
column6:
"Alpha Epsilon is the honor society for outstanding agricultural, biological and food engineers. The objectives of the honor society are to promote the high ideals of the engineering profession, to give recognition to those agricultural, biological and food engineers who manifest worthy qualities of character, scholarship and professional attainment, and to encourage and support such improvements in the agricultural, biological and food engineering profession that make it an instrument of greater service to mankind.
Memberships in Alpha Epsilon consist of three classes: honorary, active and alumni. Honorary members are selected on the basis of successful achievement in biological and agricultural engineering. Active members are chosen only from students registered in the upper portion of their engineering class, and who exhibit outstanding qualities of character, leadership, and personality."
The Alpha Epsilon Omicron Chapter is the chapter representing the Agricultural and Biological Engineering Department at Penn State. The goals of the chapter include professional development, community service, and relationship development amongst department members.

Founded in 1919, Beta Alpha Psi is a national honor organization for financial information students and professionals. The primary objective for the organization is to encourage and give recognition to scholastic and professional excellence in the business information field. This includes promoting the study and practice of accounting, finance, and information systems; providing opportunities for self-development, service, and association among members and practicing professionals, and encouraging a sense of ethical, social, and public responsibility.

The purpose of the Biological Honor Society shall be to function as an honor and professional society for students of the biological sciences. Its activities shall be designed to stimulate interest, scholarly attainment, and investigation in the biological sciences, and to promote the dissemination of information and new interpretations among students of the life sciences.

Chi Epsilon honors Junior and Senior year students seeking a degree in Civil Engineering who embody the four principles of the profession: "Scholarship, Character, Practicality, and Sociability." Since 1925, The Pennsylvania State University Chapter of Chi Epsilon has been committed to upholding the status of the civil engineering profession.

column3: College of Health and Human Development Honor Society

column6:
The mission of the Society is to function as an honor society for students and professionals of forensic science. The activities of the Society shall be designed to stimulate academic achievement, promote community understanding, and advance the fields of forensic science.
Membership:
Undergraduate Requirements: Shall be enrolled in or recently graduated from a Forensic Science degree program; Completed 47 credits or 3 semesters; And have a minimum grade point average of 3.3 on a 4.0 scale and rank in the top 35% of their class
Graduate Requirements: Shall be enrolled in or recently graduated from a graduate program in Forensic Science; Have completed 12 semester hours of graduate work or one full term equivalency for one academic term used by the institution; And have a minimum grade point average of 3.5 on a 4.0 scale

column3: Classics and Ancient Mediterranean Studies Club
column6:
The purpose of this club is to learn more about the classical and ancient Mediterranean world, whether it be ancient literature, languages, material culture, or history, and to meet other students and people with similar interests.  
If you have any suggestions for us or feedback, please fill out this google form! https://forms.gle/t5PikZK4gaz22HyK8

The Comparative Literature Club meets regularly to discuss wide-ranging topics from non-Western literature to book-to-film adaptations. Open to all, regardless of major,  come and discover your next read or share your favorites!

Our mission is to connect like-minded creatives through our passion for design and pursuit of professional development/networking! We hold monthly meetings that range from professional development and critiques, to Friendsgiving and ice-cream socials!
...
Check out our involvement fair video below and follow us on instagram for more updates and general information (@pennstategraphicdesign)!

The history round table club is a place for all Penn State student that are interested in learning more about or discussing our favorite events and periods in history. Every topic is open to discussion as well as a democratic system for members to vote on activities such as watching movies and historical excursions. Guest lecturers will also be invited to talk about certain time periods or events the group is interested in.

column3: Human Development Family Studies Undergraduate Student Organization
column6: The HDFS USO is an organization open to all HDFS majors and minors. We support a variety of annual events during Fall and Spring semesters, including Meet the Faculty and Resume Workshops. Along with these annual events, we also offer a rotation of professional development and community service events on campus. These have included volunteering for Penn State’s LifeLink, informational sessions on applying to graduate school, talks by potential internship and employment sites, and alumni networking events.

Interested in learning a second language? Already proficient in a second language, but would like to improve your proficiency? Language Growth Club is a community of language learners who support each other as they traverse through their journey to meet their goals. We stand for the collaboration and the appreciation of language learning as it relates to its use and associated culture. You do not have to be enrolled in a language program to enjoy the art of language learning with us! This club facilitates discussions, shares resources, and fosters a community of dedicated individuals who are committed to achieving their language learning goals.

The Liberal Arts Ambassadors serve as representatives for the College of the Liberal Arts in a variety of capacities. We support the Liberal Arts Office of Undergraduate Studies though participation in recruitment related and other student focused events throughout the year. In addition to working with the Office of Undergraduate Studies, we provide student representatives for on campus events hosted by the College’s Office of Alumni Relations and Development. Ambassadors also provide tours for alumni returning to campus and both accepted and prospective students. Essentially, the Liberal Arts Ambassadors represent the College to prospective students, their families, alumni, and other members of the College’s community.
  Our past events include hosting the annual Careers for the Liberal Arts event which helps to network and connect students with alumni and representatives from various employers and professions, giving tours to distinguished alumni and students, serving on panels for Accepted Students Programs, making weekly calls to advise prospective and accepted students, and so much more! We are a credited, professional org at PSU and we offer an incredible selection of academic, career, and social opportunities. 
I encourage you to follow our social medias for event updates and recruitment information. Once your application is deemed to be eligible, you will be further contacted for a short 15-30 minute interview in order to better understand your values and associate your name with your face. Our social media links are below, so be sure to stay up to date about opportunities!
  Feel free to reach out with any questions or for clarification about anything mentioned above by either direct messaging us on OrgCentral, or emailing our 2023-2024 president Allison at psu.la.ambassadors@gmail.com. We can't wait to meet you and have you become a part of the fastest-growing student organization for the Liberal Arts!

The purpose of the Lift the Mask Club is to reduce the stigma of mental health illnesses. It also aims to increase awareness and to seek solutions to the many problems related to mental health in our country. We have biweekly meetings and provide opportunities for club members to openly discuss issues, stories, and other aspects related to mental health.  We will provide resources (hotlines, websites, organizations) to the members of our club that relate to that topic of the meeting. We also plan to have events across campus such as yoga, dog petting, and other events that will reduce stress and promote positive mental health.  The club is sponsored by the Quell Foundation, who was created by PSU alumnus, Kevin Lynch. The Quell Foundation provides scholarships for students affected by a mental health illness and aims for these students to advocate and spread more awareness about mental health in their collegiate communities.  We will encourage our club members to advocate and apply for scholarships for the Quell Foundation as well. Feel free to join our GroupMe: https://groupme.com/join_group/88633968/cWy0RceL

ODS exists to provide veterans and military members attending school with the opportunity to network with other military members, help with the transition process, student leadership positions, community volunteering, professional networking as well as providing the opportunity to socialize with other veteran and military students.
Veterans helping veterans transition from the military to college. We help with the GI Bill, scholarships, class selection and anything a veteran may need when first starting college.

column3: American Choral Directors Association Student Chapter
column6: The purpose of the American Choral Directors Association Student Chapter shall be to support and educate choral musicians at University Park campus and the State College area; to acquaint students with the privileges and responsibilities of the music education profession, specifically of choral education and voice teaching; to provide opportunities for members to become acquainted with leaders in the choral music profession through participation in chapter, state, division, and national conferences; to encourage music education students' involvement with the American Choral Directors Association; to supplement information covered in the Music Education/BA/Performance curriculums for students.

We meet every Friday in Willard 371 from 7 pm to 9 pm! If you love art or want to meet and socialize with fellow artists, join us and bring your own supplies! We welcome all mediums and any skill level: everything from beginners to well-learned artists.

The Art of Nursing is a choir composed of students with the intent of going into the healthcare field who hope to bring joy and healing to the elderly and sick through song. We are learning that in order to be extraordinary healthcare professionals someday, we need to do more than successfully complete the rigorous curriculum that is set before us as we earn our degrees. The “Art of Nursing” organization is seeking to be a venue through which we can foster relationships and connections with the very patients/residents that we actually care for in the State College community. In addition, participating in the arts allows the members to increase empathy and therapeutic communication skills, which are very important in healthcare. 
Not only does this organization help those we perform for by promoting stress relief and healing, it also has a positive impact on the members by giving them a space to relieve stress and grow as caring individuals. 
Our current plan of action is to pair with nursing homes in the State College area, who will welcome us to perform for their residents. We hope to make this an interactive choir in which members are matched with one to three residents to sing and connect with during our visits. Many residents in nursing homes suffer from depression and anxiety, yet listening and making music is proven to help relieve some of the associated symptoms. As a group, we hope to uplift the residents and show them that they are important, cared for and loved. If interested, please join us in this mission!

ACMC welcomes and recruits musicians who can play traditional Asian instruments or western instruments and officers in doing Publicity, Treasurer, and Performance Management
*Audition required for instrument players
Please contact the primary contact email with your instrument area

Founded in 2008, Blue in the FACE is a co-ed a cappella group at Penn State that enjoys singing and performing while also making a couple of friends along the way! With the help of our supportive alumni network, we arrange and perform a wide range of contemporary and classic songs at gigs and our end-of-semester concerts. For over a decade, Blue in the FACE has welcomed students and turned them into one big singing family.

The purpose of the Pennsylvania State University Cello Club is to promote the playing of cello, combine in an ensemble form to create music, and to explore and recognize the playing of other cellists, orchestras, and philosophies involving technique, interpretation, and style.

The purpose of the Chamber Music Society is to provide an outlet to serve the classical music needs of the Penn State community and to further appreciation of chamber music by providing education and performance opportunities for interested instrumentalists.
To support the efforts and the mission of THON by bringing students together to raise funds and promote awareness of the Four Diamonds Fund.

Atlas Benefiting THON is an open, innovative, charitable organization at The Pennsylvania State University acting as, and according to, the rules governing a special interest organization of the Penn State IFC/Panhellenic Dance Marathon. Atlas aspires to serve THON and the larger community by providing superior emotional support to all Four Diamonds families, raising awareness of pediatric cancer, funding pediatric cancer research, and enhancing the lives of its members.

During THON 2023, Axis raised a total of $46,131.75, bringing the combined total for Axis since its founding in 2011 to $534,985.16! We work hard to maintain our position as a top 10 special interest fundraising organization. Axis was allotted 5 dancers for THON 2023! Since 2012, we have had hard working and dedicated members represent us on the THON floor - one of the highest honors in the THON community. In the past we have had first year members, underclassmen, and seniors selected to represent Axis for the 46. As long as you are passionate about THON and committed to our organization, you have the chance to dance! 
As a special interest organization, we are very family focused. We are so lucky to have been paired with the Calvanelli family. Throughout the year we get to interact with our THON child, Ayrton, his brother Declan, and his parents, Nicole and Joe. Since we are a smaller organization we have a strong relationship with our family, each of our members typically has the opportunity to meet our family in person. This year we are looking into creative ways to have our members connect with the Calvanelli's! 
Axis is a family. We place an emphasis on getting to know our members and planning events that help us to grow together as an organization. There are chances both in the beginning of the year and throughout the year to get to know each of our members and chairs. We value non-THON related activities and social events that allow our members to develop stronger bonds with each other. On top of this, Axis offers many opportunities for leadership development. There are various leadership positions and committees that members are given the opportunity to join. Members gain valuable experiences through these opportunities that they can apply to real-world situations. 
Get on our email list by completing the following form: Join Axis Benefiting THON

AYUDA is a Special Interest Organization (SIO), meaning we were founded for the sole purpose of participating in THON. Through THON’s Adopt-A-Family program, we are paired with the Ayden Gora family. In our 10+ years together, our relationship with them has grown, and our members anchor their efforts in providing support for the Goras and countless families just like them. All year leading up to THON Weekend, we host and attend various fundraisers to benefit THON, providing support for Four Diamonds and building community along the way. Many of our members are involved in other aspects of THON, often serving as Captains or Committee Members, but we all find our home on Monday nights with Ayuda. We live by our motto, “Small Org, Big Family,” and we strive to provide a welcoming environment and an opportunity to fulfill a mission greater than any one of us—ending childhood cancer. You can visit our website or our Instagram to get to know us better. New members are always welcome, and we hope to see you soon!

The mission of DASH is to bring students together while raising money and spreading awareness for the Penn State IFC/Panhellenic marathon (THON). DASH seeks to come together as a family to offer love, comfort and support to children and families affected by pediatric cancer all while in pursuit of a cure.

The mission of Eclipse is to raise money primarily for patients of pediatric cancer, with an important secondary interest in the treatment of victims of malaria and community service. In addition, we are very interested in establishing an organization that promotes teamwork, social impact, and developing the leaders of tomorrow through community and global activism.
--
Eclipse was founded in 2016, and its short tenure at Penn State, has become the largest THON Org on campus.  In Eclipse, we care about building family and creating long lasting relationships.
--
Please check out our Instagram @EclipsePSU or our website eclipsepsu.org for more information about joining Eclipse!

ENCORE is an open philanthropic organization at Penn State University to give students associated with the Penn State Symphonic Band, The Penn State Symphonic Wind Ensemble, and other students an opportunity to participate in Penn State IFC/Panhellenic Dance Marathon (THON) to raise money and awareness for THON, the Four Diamonds Fund, and pediatric cancer research. ENCORE will provide fundraising opportunities for members and provide opportunities to participate with the annual dance marathon.

Hello everyone! We are Everyday Benefitting THON!! Our name "Everyday" comes from the idea that everyday our club is fighting cancer. We do this through fundraising and supporting our THON family: the Cecil's. We have various fundraising events throughout the semester such as bake sales, merchandise fundraisers, donor drive, and holiday themed sales. In addition to fundraising money for pediatric cancer, we also are a community. All our members are close and people we consider to be good friends. We would love for you to be apart of this community and get to know us. We all have on thing in common: We do it for the kids. Everyday we fight and everyday we hope to get one step close to a cure.
If you would like to join our Group Me click this link here: https://groupme.com/join_group/52744693/Nk1jVaHz

The purpose of the College Democrats shall be to promote, both on campus and off, the Democratic Party of the United States of America, its ideals, and its philosophies. Moreover, the College Democrats shall encourage all University students to support the Democratic candidates and elected officials at the Federal, State, and Local level. We are looking to implement progressive change both in elected offices in the United States and here at Penn State.

College Independents meets Tuesday evenings, 6PM-7PM in 014 Huck Life Sciences Building. Come to a General Body Meeting to discuss current events in government and politics with a wide variety of viewpoints!
Our membership body has Republicans, Democrats, independent/unaffiliated voters, and more. We promote the respectful discussion and exchange of ideas, and we bring together students studying a wide variety of fields, including political science, economics, engineering, and business.
Our organization is low commitment, so come and go as you please!
  Click here to join our Announcements GroupMe!

The purpose of Penn State College Republicans is to assist in the election of Republican candidates to local, state, and national office, promote conservative ideals and principles at the Pennsylvania State University, engage in community service. We meet weekly to discuss current events, hear from speakers, and discuss opportunities to serve in the Penn State community, both for our party and our university.
  VISIT OUR WEBSITE: pennstategop.org

The Gender Equity Coalition will advocate for just policies and culture shifts and educate students to create a more equitable Penn State. The Gender Equity Coalition will focus on critical issues facing women and non-binary individuals, especially sexual violence, reproductive justice, and the intersectionality of marginalized identities. 
We envision a future in which all individuals, regardless of gender identity, enjoy equal rights, equitable resources, and exist without the threat of violence, harassment, or discrimination.
Follow us on Instagram @Hopeherehopenow and Facebook @Hope Here Hope Now

column3: League of Women Voters at PSU
column6:
The League of Women Voters at Penn State is an affiliate of the national League of Women Voters organizatkon with the mission of increasing voter accessibility, knowledge, and turnout on our campus. LWV PSU is open to ALL! We are an inclusive, non-partisan organization that accepts and welcomes all.
The League of Women Voters at Penn State aims to register voters, educate voters, and get out the vote. Through our three committees, students can help increase civic engagement on campus.

The purpose of the Lion Caucus shall be: To promote the interests of the Pennsylvania State University, its official positions and the interests of its students, to elected officials on the local, state, and federal levels of government. To educate government officials on the positive influences the Pennsylvania State University has on students and residents of the Commonwealth. To inform the student body of federal, state and local policies and proposals impacting the University and to promote advocacy. To provide students with meaningful leadership experiences, meeting and interacting with government and elected officials.

column3: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
column6:
Our mission is to achieve equity, political rights, and social inclusion by advancing policies and practices that expand human and civil rights, eliminate discrimination, and accelerate the well-being, education, and economic security of Black people and all persons of color. 
We envision an inclusive community rooted in liberation where all persons can exercise their civil and human rights without discrimination.
With more than 2 million members and 112 years of experience, we work to make sure Black voices are heard, demands are met, and Black excellence is amplified.

Our goals are to build a political network, organize political advocacy, foster brotherhood, and create leaders for America's future, championing causes including workers’ rights, national independence, care for the environment, and family values.
A place for students to enjoy Christian Fellowship, enjoy Bible study, and share their spiritual journey. All are welcome!

Hi! Welcome to Alliance Christian Fellowship.
We are a student organization that is designed to help you grow in your own personal walk with Christ, while doing life with other Christ-followers who share similar aspirations, dreams, and struggles. At the heart of ACF, you'll find a group of students dedicated to knowing and serving the Lord.
During the semester, we meet:
Sundays in Alumni Hall, HUB-Robeson Center. Join us at 10am for mingling and fellowship, followed by worship and a message at 10:30. 
Wednesdays at 7pm in Memorial Lounge (107), Pasquerilla Spiritual Center for our Midweek gathering. We go through a weekly rotation of events including family meals & worship and prayer. All are welcome (and invite a friend)!
With a smaller life group, you can study the Word with a close group of friends! You'll definitely want to have a close-knit group of friends that will encourage you and that you can just be real with. There are several of these groups. Shoot us a message if you want to get plugged in!

Gatherings: We are dedicated to being a community of people centered around Jesus. All our Bibletalks center on the Bible. We have group Bibletalks and also offer individual Bible Studies that dig into what it truly means to have a relationship with God. Typically our Bibletalks last about 45 minutes, with 15-20 minutes spent playing a game and laughing and 25-30 minutes dedicated to a guided discussions with questions about a passage or topic from the Bible and questions that the Bible itself asks of us.
Friday: We love being around each other and have Friday events as well, which are primarily designed to be a blast. With Friday activities like Giant Volleyball, Family Feud, PowerPoint Night and Paint Night, we have loads of fun.
For All People: All events are open to anyone, whether you consider yourself an expert on the Bible or you know nothing at all. The discussions are designed to appeal and engage people who call themselves "not that religious," as well as those who call themselves "very religious". This club is meant to help learn who Jesus really was and hear about the incredible life he lived.
Locations:
Tuesday Bibletalk @ 7pm at East, outside Findley Commons
Thursday Bibletalks @ 6:30pm at Pollock, outside Pollock Commons
(Gatherings will be moved inside for rain and when it gets colder)
Friday Evening Fun locations vary

Asian American Christian Fellowship is the Epic Movement at Penn State. Epic Movement is a Cru ministry, focused on reaching Asian American students and faculty through building Christ-centered movements that are culturally meaningful and significant.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zzdd5xuI1WM&t=3s
Promotes the spiritual and social life of young people at the University by providing opportunities for worship, fellowship, training, and evangelism.

Bridges International is a caring community of Christ-followers welcoming all international students and scholars as well as interested American students and we are committed to:- Serving others- Promoting social connections- Engaging in spiritual conversations- Helping internationals and Americans grow to become leaders who can love, encourage, and serve others.

Burning Hearts is a student ministry and family at Penn State University. We are commited to helping students of all background experience the radical love and life-changing power of God found through Jesus Christ. We're passionate about empowering students to become world changers and culture transformers who take Jesus's love and power and share it in all their spheres of influence

The purpose of the Penn State CMI is to provide in depth study of Apostolic faith while setting up programs & services to encourage and maintain spiritual awareness. We are endeavoring to explore and experience the power and ministry of Jesus Christ, as was experienced by the early church.

The mission of the Catholic Campus Ministries at Penn State is to give witness to a Catholic presence in university life and to promote and sustain the well being of the whole Catholic person. Grounded in the tradition of the Church, Catholic Campus Ministries provides for an environment and fellowship that challenge members to encounter the Living Christ and be transformed by His Spirit. To aid in this mission, Catholic Campus Ministries provides for community members the obilgatory liturgies essential to the faith and in the process also addresses the liturgical needs of many in the international student community. In addition, Catholic Campus Ministries offers retreats, service opportunities, book and Bible studies, lectures and other activities within a tradition of diverse ethnic, cultural and language backgrounds that benefit the campus community and the universal Catholic Church.

Cedar Heights Registered Student Organization is a RSO that fosters a multi-ethnic community where people who don't know Jesus can come to learn about him and understand the good news Jesus brings. It is also a place where Christians can learn, mature, and become closer to Jesus.

Ally House provides an open, safe, and inclusive living environment for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and ally students, as well as others beyond the sexuality and gender binary. Ally House fosters a community dedicated to the education and understanding of sexuality and gender issues.

This organization allows arts and architecture students to come together and bond through monthly meetings and activities. It also provides the chance for students to show case their work and inform others of activities occurring in the college.

column3: Earth and Mineral Sciences Living Learning Community
column6: Welcome to Irvin Hall, the Living Learning Community for students within the College of Earth and Mineral Sciences! As the LLC of the College of EMS, Irvin Hall seeks to promote academic involvement within the college by providing residents and non-residents with ample opportunities to network with faculty and staff within the college, connect and meet like-minded students, and participate in various events hosted throughout the academic year!
Earth House is a Living Learning Community (LLC) in North Halls for the College of Agricultural Sciences majors; however, we do have members of diverse academic backgrounds.

Penn State Engineering House (E-House) hopes to provide students with a constructive and positive live-in community that supports projects and activities relevant to their majors within the College of Engineering. E-house is conveniently located in McKee Hall, a sector of the West Halls residence area sited next to Recreation Hall and the Lion Shrine. E-House is considered a co-ed special living option, available only to those full-time students accepted into the College of Engineering at University Park. E-House provides students with the opportunity to take on leadership roles through various executive positions and committees within the house. In addition, E-house supports numerous social events, such as sporting events and picnics, to promote a sense of community and friendship among its members. In order to continually improve the living environment, members of E-House have the opportunity to attend house meetings where they may offer opinions and suggestions. Overall, E-House’s commitment to its members offers a comfortable living environment where engineers may share their common interests through their studies and their social involvement.

column3: Information Sciences and Technology Special Living Option (Living and Learning Community)
column6: The Information Sciences and Technology Special Living Option strives to create a unique living environment that fosters student interaction, both social and academic. We aim to enhance the awareness of Information and Technology by bringing residents of common interests together and advocating a greater appreciation for the future of technology.

The purpose of Alliance of Heroic Hearts is to educate, encourage, and inspire children everywhere! Known for cosplaying for a cause, our organization's volunteer members dress up as Superheroes, Princesses, or any characters kids will recognize in order to visit children's hospitals, partake community festivals such as LionBash and Fall Fest, Library Reading events at Schlow Library, School visits, Fundraise for Penn State's Relay for Life, THON and so much more.

Alpha Phi Omega is a co-ed service fraternity which is built on the pillars of leadership, friendship, and service. We are involved in community service projects both locally and nationally, some examples include working with local boy scout groups, animal shelters, outdoor service events at the arboretum and shaver’s creek, and smaller projects around the local community.
            We are of course involved in THON! We love our THON family, and often go on family visits were we celebrate birthdays and special occasions, or just go to hangout! We raise money throughout the year through different fundraisers and events, and we have dancers for THON.
            Alpha Phi Omega is also a place to find your family! We host many fellowship events throughout the year. All new members receive a big that introduces them to fellow brothers and gets them acquainted with Alpha Phi Omega traditions. All members are also part of one of three families that have friendly competitions each semester in the family Olympics! The friends you make in APO are friends you’ll have for life!

Join our GroupMe to remain up to date with upcoming Best Buddies events and information!
  Join with this link!

The Bethune Society is a service-based student organization focusing on providing our services to help build bridges across racial, religious, and social divides in the PSU and State College communities. Our organization is named after educator and civil rights activist Mary McLeod Bethune whose life and service stood for a more equal tomorrow. We use Albright-Bethune United Methodist Church (located at 206 S. Burrowes) as a base for our operations. Our main focus is service projects and providing our services.

The Black Male Leadership Symposium aspires to produce unity and stability among black males, while making an effort to retain and recruit as many of these men it can reach. Our plan is to develop the leadership qualities of the young black males involved.

The mission of the Organization shall be to: Cultivate representatives who act as global leaders, as well as advocate service organizations and engage socially beneficial projects to raise public awareness of societal problems. Execute and promote socially beneficial projects to raise awareness of societal problems. Promote collaboration among students, faculties, staffs, school organizations, community organizations and companies. Enhance social responsibilities and cultural diversity among all ethnicity and genders.
The purpose of Penn State Cancer Outreach is to help students find resources in State College that can help them get involved with different cancer charities in the community.

Centre Helps is a local nonprofit that has been serving the Centre County community for nearly 50 years through a 24/7 hotline providing resources and referrals, emotional support, and crisis intervention to those in need. The PSU Centre Helps Club will serve as a bridge between service opportunities for the community offered through Centre Helps and the Penn State campus community. We aim to create a positive on-campus culture, allowing students to help their peers in need of support.
At our club meetings we will announce upcoming volunteer opportunities through our club to benefit the greater centre county community as well as special activities and events geared towards stress relief and improving mental wellness.

Challah for Hope is an advocacy organization that raises money for the State College Food Bank. We bake challah, a type of braided bread, every other week and collect donations for sold loaves. Based on Jewish traditions, but inclusive and open to all religions, nationalities, etc. to help "repair the world".

If interested in joining, please fill out our interest form, join our GroupMe, and check out all the club links at: https://linktr.ee/psucirclek
  Circle K International is a collegiate service organization with a worldwide membership that promotes fellowship, leadership, and service. Although each Circle K club is sponsored by a Kiwanis club, college and university students govern the organization on all levels. A board of officers on the district level, and an International Board of Trustees comprise the leadership teams.Circle K International is an organization for college and university students who are responsible citizens and leaders with a lifelong commitment to community service. Current membership is 12,288 college students on 507 campuses in 15 nations in North and South America, the Caribbean, Southeast Asia, and West Africa.

column3: alpha Kappa Delta Phi International Sorority, Inc.
column6: alpha Kappa Delta Phi Sorority promotes Sisterhood, Scholarship, Leadership, Service and Asian Awareness. We are the largest Asian-interest sorority, with chapters at universities across the United States and Canada. The Nu-torious Nu Chapter was established in the fall of 1994, being one of the first chapters on the East Coast.
The Object of the Fraternity shall be to encourage a spirit of fraternity and love among its members; to stand at all times for character, dignity, scholarship, and college loyalty.
Delta Phi Epsilon is an international social sorority whose mission is to create a sisterhood experience rich in tradition, innovation and opportunities for growth.

Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Incorporated is an organization of college educated women committed to the constructive development of its members and to public service with a primary focus on the Black community.

A premier women's organization dedicated to fostering sisterhood and a love that is ever steadfast.  We are committed to lifelong learning and giving graciously. We strive for excellence in all of our pursuits including scholarship, service, leadership, and community relationships as global citizens.  Delta Zeta is a lifelong experience from collegiate to alumna.

Animation Club at Penn State is a community of creatives and friends interested in animated media. Originally founded to host our annual international Happy Valley Animation Fest, we are dedicated for artists and appreciators to network, collab, learn, and screen animated work. 
We carry weekly evening meetings on Thursday at 8pm in Visual Arts Building 207, providing industry-related guest speakers, workshops, and technical resources. On Fridays/Saturdays, we frequent game night tournaments and movies screenings. 
  Feel free to email us or DM on Insta for any questions or to be added to the listerv!  :)

Since September 2001, the PSAO has been bringing anime, manga and Japanese pop culture to the University Park campus. Working to provide both weekly screenings and a social environment for Penn State’s anime/manga fan base, the PSAO is continually broadening its horizons.
The PSAO meetings serve multiple functions, on Tuesdays we meet at 8:00 in the Willard building for free anime screenings, on Wednesdays we have game night at 8pm in the Pollock Rec Room were we play multiple types of games, finally Fridays are manga night at 8pm. For more details about our events check out the PSAO discord! 
https://discord.com/invite/aq3Y9SV
Our organization is made up of a very diverse group of students; the club executives and members bring together interests, majors, and personalities of all types to create an engaging and fun club environment.

Book Club is a casual social organization for both undergraduate and graduate to engage in discussion over shared reading experiences. If you're looking for an informal, low-key-but-fun environment in which to discuss stories, other media, and life in general, this is the group for you. Through weekly in-person meetings, book-based social events, and engaging discussions, we help forge connections between those students who might otherwise have stayed inside reading. All are welcome, and books are chosen by voting on member suggestions.
Please email Secretary Olivia Mandola at ovm5126@psu.edu or President Mikaila Gallagher at mbg5672@psu.edu for more information, or to be added to the club GroupMe. We'd love to have you!

The Penn State Car Club is an organization for all things that move on wheels!  We are interested in cars, trucks, motorcycles, and anything in between!  We are more of a social-oriented club that hosts many different types of vehicle-oriented events like car meets, socials, track days, dyno days, drag days, and many more!  We meet once or twice a week to come together and talk about our passion while surrounded by the vehicles that we drive.
The biggest Chinese popular music club in State College

Clay cOven consists of MFA, BFA, and non-majors taking a class. The mission of this club is to unite ceramic witches, in order to learn from peers and other artists. We hope to achieve this through working together, sharing supportive critical feedback, and fundraising for programs and equipment that will better us, both as individual artists and as a community.
PLEASE NOTE: you must be enrolled in a ceramics class to participate in the club and have access to facilities. Thank you!

FIRST MEETING OF THE SEMESTER: Thursday, August 24th 2023
6:30pm HUB room 131

The Penn State Coffee Club is a student-focused coffee interest group on the University Park Campus aimed at promoting the connoisseurship, tradition, and science behind brewing and enjoying coffee. Through the club, students will learn the rich global history behind coffee cultivation and roasting. Coffee Club will foster and promote coffee connoisseurship and flavor appreciation by learning different brew methods, professional tasting techniques, and through experimental opportunities domestic and abroad.

The Culinary Medicine Club strives to educate students on how certain foods or diets might help to prevent, lower risk, and/or manage symptoms of various diseases through an interactive learning environment. Then as a group we will cook a meal, dessert, or snack that someone suffering from or trying to prevent the disease would eat. The goal is to learn and educate, cook and eat. 
Nutrition is one of the least talked about aspects of helping to treat and prevent a lot of diseases since medicine and pharmaceuticals are usually chosen as the first option by physicians. Many pateints are never introduced to the idea of making diet changes for prevention and management of a disease and often suffer harmful side effects of drugs or are unresponsive to the treatment. Through this club we hope to show future healthcare workers the importance and value of good nutrition to make a bigger impact on patients.

Disney Club at Penn State (DCAPS) is a student-run organization. Through weekly meetings, we participate in activities and discussions that foster our individual passions for all things Disney! We provide members the opportunity to find others with like interest and create an environment that fosters a strong community. We collaborate with Disney professionals to help members connect with individuals within the industry to build their network at Penn State and beyond.

The Blue & White Society is the student membership of the Penn State Alumni Association. As the student alumni association, the Blue & White Society helps students establish a connection with the university, get involved across campus by providing members with community service, athletic events, and campus-wide activities, and offers students professional development and networking opportunities with alumni. With plenty of leadership opportunities available and plenty of ways to get involved, the Blue & White Society is University Park's most active student organization.
    To learn more, check out our website at http://www.bluewhitesociety.com/.
    Our Mission: To enhance student life at Penn State through diversified experience, with an emphasis on service to the community, civil leadership, tradition, and outreach while establishing the foundation of a lifelong commitment to the University as members of the Penn State Alumni Association.
Please visit our website for more information about our garden and how you can join us or participate in our events!

Greeks CARE provides sexual assault prevention training each semester to members of the Greek community at Penn State. They promote healthy sex and sexuality, teach consent, how to support survivors, bystander intervention, and the mental health effects of trauma.
For questions about our organization, please email GreeksCarePresident@psu.edu.

Penn State Homecoming is one of the largest student-run homecoming organizations in the country, which aims to celebrate tradition and instill pride in all members of the Penn State family through active engagement of students, alumni, faculty and staff across the community. Our organization is comprised of many student volunteers who donate their time to creating a multitude of events that make the Homecoming celebration a yearlong event. 

Students work with their peers, alumni, corporate sponsors, and various other community members to help make Homecoming Week and our other annual events occur. Homecoming maintains lasting relationships with those in and outside of Penn State University to ensure a successful celebration each year.

THON is a student-run philanthropy committed to enhancing the lives of children and families impacted by childhood cancer. Our mission is to provide emotional and financial support, spread awareness, and ensuring funding for critical research, all in pursuit of a cure.

column3: It's On Us at Penn State
column6:
The purpose of It's On Us Peer Educators is to provide educational programming on topics including gender violence, sexual assault, and relationship violence on behalf of the Gender Equity Center (GenEq). Members are committed to the prevention of sexual and gender-based violence in all forms,
It's On Us is more than a rallying cry; it is a promise and a commitment from Penn State community members to the victim-survivors in our community that we accept the charge that it is on US to eliminate sexual violence at Penn State. We want ALL survivors to feel seen, heard, and supported by Penn State. Our goal is to be a community for victim-survivors who have experienced interpersonal violence and to especially be a support system for underrepresented students here at Penn State.

To promote the Pennsylvania State University, as well as, its interests and goals, among future, current and past students and friends of the university. To instill within students the idea that their involvement with the university can and should be a lifelong commitment. To aid, assist and promote the Penn State Alumni Association and the Office of University Development.

The purpose of the Lion Caucus shall be: To promote the interests of the Pennsylvania State University, its official positions and the interests of its students, to elected officials on the local, state, and federal levels of government. To educate government officials on the positive influences the Pennsylvania State University has on students and residents of the Commonwealth. To inform the student body of federal, state and local policies and proposals impacting the University and to promote advocacy. To provide students with meaningful leadership experiences, meeting and interacting with government and elected officials.

column3: Academic Team at UNC Chapel Hill

column6: Mission Statement: "We are a professional community of Tar Heels who study computing; we are dedicated to exploring our field, defining our interests, engaging with each other, discovering our strengths, and improving our skills." If you are interested in joining, please visit this link: https://bit.ly/ACM-Sign-Up. Also, make sure to contact us with any questions!

Alpha Alpha Alpha, or Tri-Alpha, is a National Honor Society founded in 2018 for high-achieving first-generation college students. Tri-Alpha promotes academic excellence and provides opportunities for leadership experience and personal growth amongst First-Generation college students.
 ...
Here at UNC Chapel Hill, the Alpha Rho chapter of Tri-Alpha continues to grow as we move into our third year on UNC’s campus. Our goal is to provide a welcoming environment and established community for first-generation Tar Heels, as well as resources for college success, networking opportunities, and the recognition of your academic success at Carolina. First-generation students face unique challenges in higher education, and we aim to celebrate the victories–both big and small–of our community.
 ...
Students eligible for membership meet the following criteria:
* Come from a family where neither parent, step-parents, nor any legal guardians earned a bachelor’s degree, and
* For undergraduate students: Be a current bachelor’s degree candidate at UNC-Chapel Hill who has completed at least three full-time terms of study (minimum 36 credit hours), at least one of which must have been at UNC-Chapel Hill (for transfer students), and who has an overall GPA of at least 3.2 in all coursework.
* For graduate students: Be a graduate student who has completed the equivalent of at least one term of study (9 or more graduate credits) and has a program GPA of at least 3.5 (or an average of “high pass”).
 ...
To learn more about the national body, visit https://www.1stgenhonors.org/.
  If you have questions about our university’s chapter, please reach out to our chapter officers at TriAlphaUNC@gmail.com.

column3: Alpha Chi Sigma Professional Chemistry Fraternity
column6:
Dear Prospective Brother,
  Welcome to Alpha Chi Sigma! UNC's chapter of Alpha Chi Sigma (AXS) was founded on May 6, 1912, and for 103 years the chapter has been dedicated to giving back to the community while using its vast chemistry knowledge as an advantage. In AXS, we pride ourselves on our service projects, such as hosting the Chemistry Merit Badge workshop for the Boy Scouts of America and entertaining the children in the Pediatric Playroom event at UNC Hospitals. In the past, we have partnered with the American Chemical Society in giving science demonstrations at the North Carolina State Fair, performed for the campus community during the NC Science Festival, volunteered at local Science Olympiad tournaments, and sponsored events at UNC's subset of DNA Day.
  While we are very service oriented, we always find time to have social lives as well. The people you meet in this fraternity are some of the best people you will meet during your time at UNC. Livelong friendships are made in AXS and you will not believe the impact it will have on your life. AXS changed my life for the better and I have no doubt it will yours as well.
AXS is open to all Chemistry, Biology, Neuroscience, Pre-med, Pre-pharmacy, as well as any other STEM major. For more information and to stay up to date with rush events and dates, follow us on Instagram: @axsigmarho

column3: Alpha Epsilon Delta Pre-Health Honor Society
column6:
Alpha Epsilon Delta (AED) is a national pre-professional pre-health honor society, with chapters at universities across the country. The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is home to the NC Beta Chapter, founded in 1936. Our goal is to provide our members with valuable resources and experiences that will help guide them on their way to professional careers in health care, while also forming valuable friendships within the organization.
AED has three pillars of membership, including Academics, Service, and Social. Each of these areas has an important role in a member’s experience in our organization. Hear from members about their favorite parts of AED here. 
Our academic resources include regular lectures from health professionals, test prep courses, study groups, peer mentoring, and more. We have also been able to guarantee the opportunity to shadow a clinical health professional at least once during a member’s time in AED. Each Fall, our organization co-hosts a Medical School Deans Panel, made up of deans from major North Carolina Medical Schools (UNC, Duke, ECU, Wake Forest, etc.). These resources allow our members to network with professionals, explore different careers within health care, and to gain experience in fields in which they are most interested.
AED is also dedicated to service, and provides a large number of opportunities for students to volunteer on campus and in the local community. We have partnered with a wide variety of organizations in Chapel Hill for small and large service projects, including UNC Health Care, Orange County Habitat for Humanity, Ronald McDonald House, TABLE, MedWorld, Hope Gardens, and more. AED also hosts two on-campus philanthropy events each semester. Last year, our members put on “AED for the Kids,” a talent show for performance groups on campus to raise money for NC Children’s Hospital, and “Shaved by the Bell,” an event raising money for St. Baldrick’s Foundation, a nonprofit organization dedicated to childhood cancer research. While giving back to our community, our members work together, get to know each other, and foster connections that strengthen our brotherhood.
AED also hosts a number of social events throughout the semester for our members to spend time together outside the classroom, and to get to know each other better. Each year, members are invited to cocktails, mixers with other pre-professional organizations, a retreat, and a Spring formal. Smaller events include dinners, YoPo nights, game nights, and more! Our Big/Little mentoring program also partners new members with older members, allowing for fast friendships and guidance through the challenges of being a college student.
AED has a lot to offer, and we invite you to explore our website and participate in Fall or Spring Recruitment if you are interested in becoming a member. Please feel free to contact us with any questions about our organization - we look forward to hearing from you!

Ad Club is a professional development club for students that are interested in advertising and marketing. We offer three main professional development opportunities through our annual networking trip, guest speakers, and workshops.
https://youtu.be/ZHSo5hA1gzE

The purpose of the American Association of Neurological Surgeons, UNC Medical Student Chapter, is to:
1. Provide a means of exposure to neurosurgery and related fields to medical students at the UNC School of Medicine through organized lectures and presentations by professionals in said fields.
2. Organize physician shadowing opportunities within the UNC Neurosurgery Department.
3. Provide opportunities for medical students to present topics or original research related to neurosurgery and neuroscience during meetings.
4. Organize educational community outreach events related to neuroscience and neurosurgery aimed towards elementary, middle and high school students.
5. Disseminate information regarding potential research opportunities (i.e. projects for medical students, poster presentation opportunities, and relevant conferences) to members.
 Due to the nature and limited space of our events, we are unable to accomodate students outside of the School of Medicine.

column3: American Mock World Health Organization UNC-Chapel Hill Chapter
column6:
AMWHO is an authentic simulation of the World Health Assembly, the sole decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO). Students assume the roles of a variety of actors and engage in debates and discussion on global health challenges.
At conferences, undergraduate and graduate students will assume the roles of WHO ambassadors, non-governmental organization members, media correspondents, or industry representatives. In regional blocs, delegates debate, write, and ultimately vote on a resolution that aims to address the global public health challenge and theme of the conference. If the resolution passes, it will go to plenary, where all of the regional blocs come together to debate and vote again on each region’s resolutions. Final resolutions that pass will be sent to the World Health Assembly in Geneva, Switzerland.

Beyond debate, AMWHO at UNC is an amazing opportunity to hear from experts in global public health! Throughout the conference, students will have access to renowned professors from the Gillings School of Global Public Health and public health professions from the Triangle from a wide variety disciplines. Students will hear from and talk to these guest speakers at the banquet, opening and closing ceremonies, and a lunch and learn event.
UNC Campus Affairs events will take place several times per semester. These events are a great opportunity to learn about and discuss key public health issues. Examples of events include guest lectures, speaker panels, and disaster response simulations. Find out when upcoming events are by subscribing to AMWHO's Outlook Groups and checking our Facebook page.
Website: www.uncamwho.org
AMWHO Outlook Groups: https://forms.gle/cjxS4GhxGmVSpZbo6

The American Student Dental Association is a student organization at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill which has been founded for the purpose of protecting and advancing the rights, interests, and welfare of students pursuing careers in dentistry.  Our objectives are to represent students with a unified voice and provide information, education, advocacy, and services. The association introduces lifelong involvement in organized dentistry, and promotes change for the betterment of the profession.

column3: Albums and Record Society at UNC-CH
Back Page Creative Writing Club at UNC-CH
column6: The mission of Back Page Creative Writing Club is to build community through creative writing and literary arts, allowing students to express themselves through the written word and benefit from sharing creative ideas in a collaborative space with an emphasis on equal opportunity. Through this club, we intend to help undergraduate students expand on any creative impulses or ideas that otherwise would not have been started or shared. Follow us on Instagram or join our GroupMe for more information and updates: https://groupme.com/join_group/68270863/T8IzPgLo

Through the means of high-energy, traditional dance, we strive to promote and educate the UNC community and the Triangle area on Punjabi culture.
Through our dance we also aim to outdo ourselves and represent UNC as a nationally competitive dance team through dance competitions in the fall and spring. 
Annually, we also hold a fundraising performance event with guest appearances from many other UNC performing groups in order to raise money for charities helping impoverished children in India.
