Indian Classical Music Club that incorporates both Hindustani and Carnatic Music. We serve students who are interested in and perform the art. It will provide a space for students to come together, jam, learn from one another, and perform.

Blank Canvas is UNC's largest student-run dance company, and the only all levels, all styles dance group on campus. Our dancers, choreographers, and officers are all students. We are dedicated to giving performers of all backgrounds an outlet for participation in and the choreography of original works. Dancers are able to perform twice per year (once at the end of each semester) and may also attend the various social events we offer throughout the year. Dancers who are looking for more performance opportunities can join our Performance Team to dance at sports games, community and campus events. We also offer technique classes to the public!

Cadence is an a cappella group at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. We are a community service-oriented group, and love to perform at events on campus and in neighboring communities.
Cadence was founded by Lachi Music in 2003, then a junior at UNC. The group established its presence on UNC's campus after hard work and commitment to making music. It currently consists of 15-18  young, diverse, femme-presenting people who love to sing.

Established in 2016, Carolina Animators Anonymous (AniAno for short) offers a place for students to learn the animation filmmaking process in the absence of animation classes at UNC. We have made award-winning animated short films for Campus Movie Fest and continue to create animations with the diverse talents of our club members.
  Watch our Introduction video here!
Join our Discord server for club event updates: https://discord.gg/uVuUVZhm8G
  FAQ:
I don’t know much about animation/I’m not a very good artist. Can I still join? 
Artists and animators of all skill levels are welcome! By collaborating with other artists in the club, you will learn lots of tips on how to improve! You can also contribute without needing to draw, such as through writing or production.
  What should I expect when I first join AniAno?
First, introduce yourself and share what you love about animation! Then, decide which roles in animation you want to contribute to. There are various roles such as storyboarding, character design, and animating. If you're not sure which roles suit you best, it's a good idea to try a little bit of everything and see what you enjoy doing most!
  What software does AniAno use?
Although club members tend to rely on the Adobe Creative Cloud suite provided for free by UNC (specifically Adobe Animate and Photoshop), you can use any digital art software you're comfortable with! There is also nothing wrong with good ol' paper and pencil!
  I am thinking of having a career in animation. Can AniAno help with that?
Yes! Aside from doing club projects, AniAno also explores the animation industry and offers resources for networking and portfolio building. You do not need to go to an art school to get into the animation industry. It's all about making lots of cool stuff and getting in touch with other animators!
    If you have any questions, please send us an email!
Organization Email: carolina.aniano@gmail.com
  Discord Server: https://discord.gg/uVuUVZhm8G
  Organization Webpage:https://carolinaanimatorsanonymous.my.canva.site

Members of the Carolina Girls are committed to excellence in sharing our passion for dance and in the classroom.  In reference to the university’s emphasis on light and liberty, we strive to shine our light in the community and break barriers in the community.  The Carolina Girls serve and represent the UNC-CH community with pride.  Through dance, the Carolina Girls will inspire self-confidence, and promote discipline, integrity, professionalism, and leadership.

Join our GroupMe! https://groupme.com/join_group/95781774/lI1HF1Oo
***Please make sure to request membership on Heel Life so that we can add you to the GroupMe!!!***

Carolina Jams Club is a UNC-Chapel Hill Student Organization with the purpose of bringing Carolina musicians together. We meet up to practice and make music for service projects, concerts for benefits, lessons for people wanting to learn to play an instrument, and much more. Our goal is to spread the love for music and allow anyone to learn, play, and grow as a musician.

Our Mission:
Share, respect, and support all cultural identities.
  Share:
We hold Culture Shop and Festival Assembly for our members to share their cultural identities and knowledge in culture. Culture Shop offers an online platform to showcase cultures with pictures or videos or other materials on our organization's website. Members who have a culture or multiple cultures listed online will have the chance to show their cultures at Festival Assembly, which is held once per year. We will invite all UNC students to come to our Festival Assembly. 
  Respect:
We hold workshops for lectures and discussions. We will invite professors, graduate students, researchers, and other scholars in academia to educate us about culture. We will also invite other cultural organizations to talk about connections or differences among cultures together. Respecting each other’s cultural identities is our priority.
  Support:
We hold Culture Support Community and Culture Support Service to support both international students and endangered cultures. We will have an online community chat group for students to connect, and we will hold regular meetings for students to share their stories and support each other. As for Culture Support Service, we will offer a channel to encourage people worldwide to look for and collect endangered cultures. We will work together to discover how to commit to preserving global cultural identities and bring endangered cultures back.

column3: Allies for Minorities and Women in Science and Engineering
column6:
AM_WISE is a group for graduate students with the goal to bring scientists together to connect, generate ideas, share advice, and learn about the problems caused by the disparities in STEM, as well as the inspirational work of minority scientists.
Our Mission is to (1) Communicate – create an atmosphere where graduate students and post-docs can connect, generate ideas, and share advice with fellow scientists; (2) Educate – learn about the problems caused by the disparity of success in STEM, especially chemistry and physics and astronomy, as well as the inspirational work done by minority scientists throughout history; (3) Articulate – discuss ways to solve these problems and encourage departments to be more welcoming of all scientists. 
We provide support for graduate students and post docs in the chemistry and physics and astronomy departments to create a more welcoming community for all members of STEM departments at UNC. We do this by inviting speakers from diverse backgrounds to speak to the community twice a year. We run a graduate peer-mentoring program (Graduate Achievement through Mentorship) to provide first-year graduate students the support they need. 
We meet every other month to discuss new and ongoing policy projects, initiatives and events within the departments. If you are interested in learning more, check out our website, or use your UNC email account to join our listserv!

Join us for our weekly Italian meetings. We'll practice our language skills, study material, and enjoy Italian food! Members of all Italian sections are welcome. Benvenuti anche ai nostri amici dall'estero! We are holding meetings Mondays @5pm in Room 2424 of the Student Union. We hope to see you there!

The UNC Chapel Hill Arab Student Organization was founded in 2019 in order to foster a cohesive Arab network on campus and in the surrounding community. Our organization has three primary objectives we strive to achieve:
Firstly, UNC ASO aims to build and maintain an Arab community that is inclusive of all within the pan-arab world. We want to build a space that does not generalize the Arab experience, but rather celebrates the different practices within our heritage that adds to the richness of the Arab identity.
Secondly, we aim to create connections with local and international leaders, organizations, and alumni to strengthen our community outside campus limits.
Thirdly, ASO aims to connect our members with outside career paths, promoting academic and employment opportunities to help ensure their success after graduation and beyond. Any Arab student at UNC Chapel Hill is eligible to join and be a member of ASO! If you have any questions or concerns please email asochapelhill@gmail.com. Find out about upcoming meeting on our instagram @uncaso

Ascend is an organization that focuses on enhancing the presence and influence of current and future Pan-Asian professional leaders and serves as a collective voice for Pan-Asian professional communities. The best way to stay updated on our events it to follow us on Instagram and join our groupme (link in insta bio)

The Asian American Law Students Association (AALSA) is a social, academic, and career-oriented network for past and present students at Carolina Law. AALSA strives to serve its members by hosting social and academic events, pro bono or volunteer programs, and mentorship opportunities.

AASA is a student organization on campus that emphasizes the promotion of cultural and social awareness on campus and to the community through service projects, cultural events, working with other organizations, and sponsoring social events.
Check us out on Instagram (@uncaasa) and Facebook for the quickest access to information on new events!

column3: Black Graduate and Professional Student Association
column6: BGPSA strives to unite future leaders in the African American community at UNC-Chapel Hill through education, social interaction and service. Our organization is open and welcoming to all graduate and professional students who share the same intent.

The Black Student Law Association is a forum for sharing and solving problems unique to Black students in the law school community.  BLSA sponsors academic and career workshops, cultural awareness activities and community service projects throughout the year.

The Carolina Beekeeping Club is an opportunity for students to get involved with all the aspects of apiculture: including learning about the life cycle and complex social structure of honeybees; managing hives; using the products of the hive, including wax and honey; planting pollinator friendly crops; marketing the products; and disseminating information on the importance of pollinators, especially honeybees, to the public at large.
  Follow us on Instagram @unc_beekeeping ! Our GroupMe link is in the Instagram bio.

column3: Citizens Climate Lobby of UNC Chapel Hill
column6:
Citizens Climate Lobby is a non-profit, non-partisan grassroots advocacy organization focused on national policies to address climate change. We conduct community outreach, leverage media opportunities, and lobby Congress to build political will around 4 main policy areas: carbon fee and dividend, building electrification, clean energy permitting reform, and healthy forests. 
We meet biweekly from 6:30-7:30pm in Dey Hall 307 (9/12, 9/26, 10/10, 10/24, 11/7, 11/14, 11/28). 
Please request membership to be added to our email list and get involved!

Get involved with CompostMates at Carolina! Many individuals face barriers to composting. CompostMates breaks down those barriers through a free, twice monthly collection service for those without the time, space, transportation, and/or funds to donate food scraps or maintain their own compost. 
For prospective members: Members are the ones who receive our food scrap collection service. Stay updated by following us on Instagram!
For prospective volunteers: You can fill out the form in the linktree to sign up to volunteer as a driver! Drivers ride around and collect food scraps from our Mates. 

Those interested in getting involved who do not have a vehicle can be on our sustainability committee. The sustainability committee works with our sustainability chair to host events and create social media content that emphasizes advocacy, activism, and education surrounding environmental sustainability.

A group of welcoming and motivated individuals who are passionate about food justice, sustainability and gardening. We work to combat the campus food desert by improving access to fresh fruits and vegetables to students and the campus community

The purpose of the Environmental Law Project is to expose law students to the issues, opportunities available, and people involved in Environmental Law. ELP gives students practical experience in Environmental Law through our Pro Bono projects and Environmental Law Symposium. For students working summer internships in the environmental field we provide grants, funded by our recycling program. In addition, we send out updates via email, organize social events, and hold speaker series on environmental issues.

column3: Food Recovery Network at Chapel Hill
column6: The Food Recovery Network at UNC-Chapel Hill is dedicated to fighting food waste and hunger in the Triangle Area. Our members recover left over food from local eateries and donate it shelters in the surrounding area.

Acts2Fellowship (A2F) is a Christian student group at UNC Chapel Hill. We do life together, study the Bible together, and figure out how God and Christianity fits into it all, especially through the craziness of college life! A2F is a safe and fun place to make friends, talk about life, and grow in a relationship with God.

The Bahá'í Faith upholds the unity of God, recognizes the unity of His Prophets, and inculcates the principle of the oneness and wholeness of the entire human race. It proclaims the necessity and the inevitability of the unification of mankind, asserts that it is gradually approaching, and claims that nothing short of the transmuting spirit of God, working through His chosen Mouthpiece in this day, can ultimately succeed in bringing it about. It, moreover, enjoins upon its followers the primary duty of an unfettered search after truth, condemns all manner of prejudice and superstition, declares the purpose of religion to be the promotion of amity and concord, proclaims its essential harmony with science, and recognizes it as the foremost agency for the pacification and the orderly progress of human society. It unequivocally maintains the principle of equal rights, opportunities and privileges for men and women, insists on compulsory education, eliminates extremes of poverty and wealth, abolishes the institution of priesthood, prohibits slavery, asceticism, mendicancy and monasticism, prescribes monogamy, discourages divorce, emphasizes the necessity of strict obedience to one's government, exalts any work performed in the spirit of service to the level of worship, urges either the creation or the selection of an auxiliary international language, and delineates the outlines of those institutions that must establish and perpetuate the general peace of mankind.

Our mission is making disciples on campus who impact the world. We welcome all students to share our vision of being a light for Christ in the university community.
  A follower of Jesus regularly encounters God, connects with followers in community, grows together, and makes an impact on the world around them. Regardless of where you are on this path, we want to walk with you to help you follow Jesus more closely.
Encounter - a weekly encounter with God through worship, prayer and Biblical teaching.
Connect Groups - small groups that serve together, play together, study God's Word together, eat together... generally live life together.
Grow Groups - groups of 2-4 that meet on their own time to read the Bible, pray, share struggles and triumphs, and sharpen one another in Christ.
Make an Impact - find an existing need where you are and let God use you to help meet it.
Our ultimate goal is to see lives transformed by the love of Jesus. Join us.
  Watch this video to learn more : click here
Watch this video to see what we did over Spring Break this year: click here
The primary purpose of the Chabad Student Group is to provide living Judaism to the students at the University of North Carolina within the framework of traditional Judaism.

UNC-CHUUF is dedicated to serving the spiritual needs of the Unitarian Universalists and other liberal religious and non-religious students by offering religious community programming, worship, and peer support which reflect UU principles and purposes, and which celebrate diversity.
CHUUF meets Thursdays from 5:00 pm to 6:00 pm in the Student Union (Room #3515). We provide food and fellowship for all of those who wish to join us.
Our sponsoring congregation is the Community Church of Chapel Hill Unitarian Universalist. You can look at their website and find more information about Campus Fellowship here: https://www.c3huu.org/unc-campus-fellowship.html

Chi Alpha is a ministry that exists to reach college students, build them up in their faith and send them out to serve and make a difference in a world in great need. Our vision for Chi Alpha is to learn together to be Devoted Disciples of Jesus who build Deep Friendships with those around us and act as Deliberate Servants of our campus, community, and world.

The Vision
The Christian Legal Society of the University of North Carolina School of Law is a Christ-centered student group with a focus on fellowship, mentorship, and pro bono service. Our members include law students and professionals who are committed to glorifying God through spiritual formation, compassionate outreach, and the integration of faith and legal practice. All are welcome to join us!
Fellowship
Our society strives to support Christian students in their walk of faith through law school. As new students come to Chapel Hill each year, CLS works to get them connected with roommates, housing, churches, and community organizations. CLS enjoys a long tradition of hosting Christian leaders in the legal community who regularly address the group on important issues at the nexus of faith and law. Our list of distinguished speakers includes law school deans, members of congress, and North Carolina Supreme Court justices. In the middle of the busy life of law school, CLS provides a faith-based opportunity for law students to fellowship. In addition to our weekly lunch meetings where we gather for discussion, scripture reading, and prayer, our members often meet for group dinners, outdoor events, and worship services.
Mentorship
CLS provides a network for attorneys of faith to connect to the Christian legal community. New members benefit from mentorship with upperclassmen in law school and professionals in the field. Upperclassmen help new students navigate their way through the first years of school, providing guidance, insights, and friendship early on in the law school journey. CLS has a proud tradition of cultivating leaders in the law school and legal community. Our members are active in various student organizations such as the school journals, moot court, student bar association, and pro bono. Local professionals also partner with CLS to provide career advice and connections to young attorneys as they begin their post-graduate career. More information about our mentorship program can be found on the Mentorship page.
Pro Bono Service
UNC School of Law has a long and proud tradition of Pro Bono service in the North Carolina community. Our members are highly active in the Pro Bono and public interest projects, acting out their faith in service to others. CLS seeks to partner with organizations that have a faith or a family-oriented mission in their legal practice. Our Pro Bono coordinator is responsible for connecting our members with the right projects.

column3: Christian Medical And Dental Association - Medical
column6: Our organization seeks to provide a place for UNC medical and dental students to grow in their faith, to explore God's word together, and to learn more about applying their faith and beliefs to their lives as health professionals.

We desire to build an organization that allows and helps men become a better part of their communities and empower them to make lifelong friends and develop, both personally and professionally, through the ACACIA fraternity.

A social panhellenic sorority that fosters friendship, leadership, learning and service to the university and surrounding community; our recruitment is open to all female students at UNC-CH interested in joining the Greek community.  To learn more about our national organization, check out alphachiomega.org!

Our sorority is a home away from home for our membership - an organization of philanthropy, sisterhood, and social activities to enrich collegiate lives. Alpha Delta Pi sorority was founded at Wesleyan College in Macon, Georgia and was the first national collegiate society for women. The Beta Upsilon chapter of Alpha Delta Pi was founded at UNC in 1939.  Our large chapter of well rounded women is very involved on campus at UNC and ADPi is proud to have one of the highest GPAs in all of Panhellenic.  Our national philanthropy is the Ronald McDonald House and we have exciting campus and community wide events throughout the year to benefit our friends at the Ronald McDonald House, including Make Your Own Mac & Cheese Night and our Ron-a-Thon 5K run!

Alpha Epsilon Pi is a brotherhood of Jewish students at UNC who support each other and better the community. We participate in many social and service-based activities throughout the semester.
Learn more at aepiunc.org.

column3: Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc. Theta Pi Chapter
column6:
Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated was founded on January 15, 1908, at Howard University. It is the first black Greek-lettered sorority, and it is an organization devoted to fellowship among college women, high scholastic and ethical standards, and service to all mankind. 
  The Theta Pi chapter was chartered at UNC-CH on April 20, 1974, by fourteen phenomenal women. Members of our organization are represented in a number of on-campus student organizations including the McNair Scholars Program, Robertson Scholars, Morehead-Cain Scholars, Admission Ambassadors, The Daily Tar Heel, the Black Student Movement, and the Campus Y.
  The theme of our 2022-2026 International Programs is Soaring to Greater Heights of Service and Sisterhood. The “Foundation Initiative” is Strengthen Our Sisterhood with five initiatives serving as “Program Initiatives”. Those initiatives are Empower Our Families, Build Our Economic Wealth, Enhance Our Environment, Advocate for Social Justice, and Uplift Our Local Community. 
  Moreover, the women of Theta Pi strive to uphold high ethical and moral standards on the campus of UNC to allow Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc. to remain a premier organization for young women.

www.unc-akdphi.com
VISION STATEMENT
alpha Kappa Delta Phi Inc. will be the most respected, premier network of innovative female leaders within the community by:
Encouraging the growth of our members through cultural diversity and the expression of individuality;
Empowering our members to become pioneers for philanthropic, cultural, and scholastic programs worldwide;
Developing strategic collaborations and partnerships; and
Supporting initiatives promoting the sustainability of our organization and its mission.

column3: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity Inc Mu Zeta Chapter
column6: The Mu Zeta Chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc. was founded on April 15, 1976 on the campus of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Through manly deeds, scholarship, and love for all mankind, we inspire to uplift and help our campus and local community.

Alpha Pi Omega Sorority Inc., is the country’s first and oldest Native American Greek letter organization!
Founded at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill on September 1st, 1994. 
Alpha Pi Omega Sorority Inc., is a united sisterhood of Indigenous women who are committed to each other, our communities, tribes, families, academic excellence and self-empowerment! 
"My Sister As Myself"

Chartered in 1879, the Alpha Delta Chapter has retained active status for 134 years and graduated over 2,000 brothers.  We take great pride in our reputation as a well-rounded organization that focuses on brotherhood, scholarship, leadership development, professional growth and various social activities.
  THE CREED OF ALPHA TAU OMEGA
To bind men together in a brotherhood based upon eternal and immutable principles, with a bond as strong as right itself and as lasting as humanity; to know no North, no South, no East, no West, but to know man as man, to teach that true men the world over should stand together and contend for supremacy of good over evil; to teach, not politics, but morals; to foster, not partisanship, but the recognition of true merit wherever found; to have no narrower limits within which to work together for the elevation of man than the outlines of the world: these were the thoughts and hopes uppermost in the minds of the founders of the Alpha Tau Omega Fraternity.

column3: Association for Women in Mathematics at UNC-Chapel Hill
column6:
We are the graduate student chapter of the national Association for Women in Mathematics. Our programming includes lunches and other events promoting female mathematics faculty and seminar speakers, speaker events, and social events in conjunction with the undergraduate chapter of AWM.
Please note that this is the graduate chapter of AWM. If you are looking for the undergraduate chapter, please click here.

IGNITE at UNC-Chapel Hill is a college chapter of IGNITE National. IGNITE builds political ambition in young women in their own communities. We provide civic education, exposure to womxn in political leadership, hands-on-training and work opportunities, and a peer network of women who support and nurture each other's aspirations to become the next generation of civic and political leaders. We are nonpartisan.

column3: Medical Student Pride Alliance, UNC School of Medicine
column6: Welcome to the Heel Life page for the Medical Student Pride Alliance (MSPA) at the UNC School of Medicine!  Through our involvement with students, faculty, and administrators in the School of Medicine and other UNC Health Schools, we seek to better educate our classmates and ourselves about serving LGBTQ+ populations. We have numerous projects in the works, thanks to our hard-working members and allies throughout the allied health services of UNC. Throughout each medical school year, we strive to share several talks with medical students and faculty, including how to be an LGBT ally, living as an LGBT physician, the endocrinology of transitioning, how to counsel patients on safe sex practices, and more. We also continue to be deeply involved in the ongoing evolution of the UNC SOM curriculum in order to work with faculty and address LGBT health education in both the pre-clinical and clinical years.

column3: Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
column6:
oSTEM empowers LGBTQ+ students in STEM to succeed personally, academically, and professionally. We hold social events to connect queer STEM students with one another, and we partner with graduate students in STEM Pride to provide one-on-one mentorship opportunities.
  Join our listserv to stay updated on events by joining our organization on this page or by emailing ostem.unc@gmail.com
Instagram: @ostem.unc
GroupMe: https://tinyurl.com/ostemgroupme

OutLaw (formerly Lambda Law Students Association) seeks to educate the Carolina Law community about the legal, political, and social issues facing the gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, and questioning community.
We feel honored to continue the work of decades of queer and trans Carolina Law students under this new banner. We’re so grateful to have all of you alongside us as we continue to make space for queer organizing, solidarity, and joy at Carolina and in the broader legal profession!
OutLaw is open to any and all members of the larger Carolina community who are interested in LGBT legal, political, and social issues. We particularly encourage supportive allies to attend meetings and monthly events.

Pride@KFBS serves as the Undergraduate Business Program’s LGBTQ+ organization. We seek to increase LGBTQ+ visibility at UNC Kenan-Flagler and establish a sense of community for LGBTQ+ students and allies interested in business. Additionally, we connect students to LGBTQ-friendly employers and  provide extensive professional development opportunities specific to the needs of LGBTQ+ students in business. Our organization welcomes allies to show support and partake in educational events, which provides them the tools to become a better ally.

The Queer Library & Information Collective (QLIC) is an LGBTQ+ student organization that strives to create an inclusive space for all students to excel academically and socially. Based at the UNC School of Information and Library Science, we host social events and contribute to student outreach and advocacy efforts. We value and support queer and intersectional feminist interests within our school, community, and the information and library science fields. We recognize the intersectionality of oppression and strive to work across those intersections to create a more welcoming and just environment. QLIC is open to everyone. To receive our monthly newsletter, sign-up at tinyurl.com/QLICSIGNUP.

The Sexuality and Gender Alliance (SAGA) works to foster a strong LGBTQ+ community at UNC. SAGA is an events and social justice based organization that hosts many programs and activities throughout the year. Examples include Queer Prom, monthly Movie Nights, and much more! In addition, we hold collaborations with other student groups on campus to celebrate the intersectional nature of LGBTQ+ life.
Above all else, SAGA strives to promote the welfare of all LGBTQ+ folks on campus. Everyone is welcome to our events, and we look forward to meeting you!

Drag is a gender-bending art form in which a person dresses in clothing and makeup meant to portray and exaggerate a specific gender identity, usually one that’s different from their day-to-day gender expression. While drag is a performing art, it is also a form of self-expression and a celebration of
LGBTQ+ pride. Today, drag has become a creative outlet for queer identifying people to achieve gender expression, self-empowerment, artistic exploration, community building, and fighting discrimination.
The art of drag incorporates acting, dancing, fashion, comedy, and make-up skills. Drag performances established the queer culture in society with a huge motive of fighting against all the odds to set the normality and equality of queer orientations in the society. Drag displays that gender identities are equal, fluid, and devoid of labels--a message that urgently needs to be heard in today’s world.

Mission Statement: "We are a professional community of Tar Heels who study computing; we are dedicated to exploring our field, defining our interests, engaging with each other, discovering our strengths, and improving our skills." If you are interested in joining, please visit this link: https://bit.ly/ACM-Sign-Up. Also, make sure to contact us with any questions!

column3: Advocates for Inclusion in Medicine and Science

column6:
The Alliance/Allied Health Ambassadors serve the entire Allied Health Sciences department and provide programs and activities that are relevant and beneficial to all departments, often incorporating information about how the different disciplines interact in post-graduate professional settings. 
Through the Allied Health Ambassadors, current Allied Health students will have advocates between themselves and the faculty to provide more opportunities for professional growth through department-wide programs. Future interested applicants will be able to learn more about the Allied Health Sciences programs at UNC from current students and faculty through events organized by the ambassadors.
The Allied Health Ambassadors strive to provide opportunities for current and prospective students to gain knowledge and skills, not found in their regular curriculum, about the Allied Health Sciences that they can carry with them into their professional careers. It is our hope that the information we provide will be mutually beneficial to both the students and the patients they will serve throughout their careers.

column3: Allies for Minorities and Women in Science and Engineering
column6:
AM_WISE is a group for graduate students with the goal to bring scientists together to connect, generate ideas, share advice, and learn about the problems caused by the disparities in STEM, as well as the inspirational work of minority scientists.
Our Mission is to (1) Communicate – create an atmosphere where graduate students and post-docs can connect, generate ideas, and share advice with fellow scientists; (2) Educate – learn about the problems caused by the disparity of success in STEM, especially chemistry and physics and astronomy, as well as the inspirational work done by minority scientists throughout history; (3) Articulate – discuss ways to solve these problems and encourage departments to be more welcoming of all scientists. 
We provide support for graduate students and post docs in the chemistry and physics and astronomy departments to create a more welcoming community for all members of STEM departments at UNC. We do this by inviting speakers from diverse backgrounds to speak to the community twice a year. We run a graduate peer-mentoring program (Graduate Achievement through Mentorship) to provide first-year graduate students the support they need. 
We meet every other month to discuss new and ongoing policy projects, initiatives and events within the departments. If you are interested in learning more, check out our website, or use your UNC email account to join our listserv!

The purpose of the American Association of Neurological Surgeons, UNC Medical Student Chapter, is to:
1. Provide a means of exposure to neurosurgery and related fields to medical students at the UNC School of Medicine through organized lectures and presentations by professionals in said fields.
2. Organize physician shadowing opportunities within the UNC Neurosurgery Department.
3. Provide opportunities for medical students to present topics or original research related to neurosurgery and neuroscience during meetings.
4. Organize educational community outreach events related to neuroscience and neurosurgery aimed towards elementary, middle and high school students.
5. Disseminate information regarding potential research opportunities (i.e. projects for medical students, poster presentation opportunities, and relevant conferences) to members.
 Due to the nature and limited space of our events, we are unable to accomodate students outside of the School of Medicine.

column3: American Constitution Society - UNC Law Chapter
column6:
Nationally, ACS is an organization of legal professionals that is dedicated to advancing and defending democracy, justice, equality, and liberty; to securing a government that serves the public interest; and to guarding against the abuse of law and the concentration of power.
On campus at Carolina Law, ACS is a lefty group that focuses on educating and advocating for progressive law and policy. We program events that emphasize access to the courts, the importance of a progressive judiciary, and the protection of individual rights and the dignity of every person.

Our organization provides education on issues of geriatric health and wellness to medical students, as well as opportunities for community outreach through patient visits and education. For more information, please visit our official website at http://www.med.unc.edu/ags

UNC School of Medicine AMWA endeavors to empower women to lead improving health for all within a model that reflects the unique perspective of women, as well as advance women in medicine & improve women's expertise, mentoring, and alliances.
*SCHOOL OF MEDICINE STUDENTS ONLY, not open to undergraduates*

Actively Moving Forward (AMF) at UNC-CH provides a grief support community for undergraduate and graduate students at any point in their bereavement journey. Members can participate in a variety of peer-led discussion, social, or service-based events. AMF is a safe, non-judgmental space; everyone is welcome to join! 
  Actively Moving Forward at UNC-CH is a chapter of the national HealGrief Actively Moving Forward organization.
  GroupMe: https://groupme.com/join_group/88585181/X79UdK1o
To learn more: https://healgrief.org/actively-moving-forward/.
To download the app: https://healgrief.org/amf-app/

Our mission is to make every student feel cared about and welcome on campus. As students, we face stress, anxiety, drama, and negativity from time to time. The Acts of Random Kindness (ARK) Club strives to make school a little more pleasant by conducting uplifting campaigns, activities, and projects—because it's the little things in life that make a difference. Our main goals are to spread kindness, courage, and compassion through Random Acts of Kindness.

Through the hosting of guest speakers who specialize in lung disease and air quality, AIR Club members will gain awareness about topics including asthma, lung cancer, cystic fibrosis, smoking cessation, and the impacts of poor air quality on chronic lung conditions. In addition, the audience will be able to take part in a movement seeking to spread awareness of the importance of these diseases not just on campus, but also into the surrounding community by visiting schools and hosting fundraisers. This organization works closely with faculty in the UNC School of Medicine and seeks to improve the general airway health of the campus.

column3: Association for Carolina Emergency Response and Injury Prevention
column6:
ACERIP is both a Student Organization recognized by UNC-Chapel Hill and an accredited BEI teaching institution for the State Office of EMS. Each semester, ACERIP sponsors an EMT-Basic class and CPR classes for UNC students, faculty and staff.
ACERIP is a student-run organization whose purpose is to make the UNC-CH campus and Chapel Hill communities a safer place to live, work, learn, and play.

While providing healthcare to the Eastern NC community of Bloomer Hill, our organization seeks to expose medical students to healthcare in rural communities and under-served parts of the state.
For more info, see our website: www.med.unc.edu/ncsrhc

Brain Dump hopes to help students start journaling, especially for those who have been having a hard time to start journaling or just interested in starting. We are looking forward to guide students with journaling prompts that are targeted towards navigating one’s inner thoughts and feelings, along with helpful tips and strategies to do so. We also plan to share some of the individual entries during meetings and be a safe place for everybody to share their journey of facing their vulnerability and authenticity through journaling!
Groupme: https://groupme.com/join_group/88454225/s2dreo2Y

Carolina Barbell is a home for lifters of all experience levels. Whether you've never touched a barbell or are a seasoned Powerlifting or Bodybuilding competitor, Carolina Barbell can help you reach your goals or just provide a fun place to be with like-minded individuals.
  We offer events such as: 
-lifting workshops
-nutrition seminars
-guest speakers
-competition prep
-mock meets
-social events
-and so much more

column3: Carolina Bebes—Birth & Breastfeeding Evidence-Based Education and Support
column6: The purpose of Carolina BEBES is to provide an opportunity for interested students to learn more about normal birth and breastfeeding and to advocate for supportive birth/breastfeeding practices on campus, locally, nationally and globally. Through participation, students will have the opportunity to be involved in evidence-based advocacy, training and community education opportunities. The organization will also serve as a mechanism for students to get involved in supporting the efforts of the Carolina Breastfeeding Institute.

column3:
C
Carolina Obstetrics and Gynecology Interest Group

column6: The Affirmative Action Coalition is focused on making sure we are committed to maintaining diversity at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill despite the outcome of the Supreme Court. We are primarily focused on providing education and developing a petition to the College of Arts and Sciences to make sure that there are diverse initiatives being implemented and utilized.

column3: American Constitution Society - UNC Law Chapter
column6:
Nationally, ACS is an organization of legal professionals that is dedicated to advancing and defending democracy, justice, equality, and liberty; to securing a government that serves the public interest; and to guarding against the abuse of law and the concentration of power.
On campus at Carolina Law, ACS is a lefty group that focuses on educating and advocating for progressive law and policy. We program events that emphasize access to the courts, the importance of a progressive judiciary, and the protection of individual rights and the dignity of every person.

Carolina Review is a student-run publication of conservative thought on academics and campus, state, and national events.
Mission Statement:
Carolina Review is a journal of conservative thought and opinion published at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, founded by a group of graduate and undergraduate students in 1993. Carolina Review has been the most visible and consistent voice of conservatism on campus, providing students with an alternative to the left-wing orthodoxy promoted by other student publications, professors, and student groups. During its ten-year existence, the Review has enabled UNC students to hear both sides of issues, while combining reporting with opinion, humor, and feature articles.
Carolina Review is staffed solely by UNC students who write and publish on a monthly basis. Our purpose is to show students that a political philosophy of conservatism, free thought, and individual liberty is an intelligent way of looking at the world–contrary to what they may hear in the classrooms and on campus. In general, writers and contributors to the Review share a belief in the following:
We believe the University should be a forum for rational and informed debate–instead of the current climate in which ideological dogma, political correctness, fashion, and mob mentality suppress academic freedom.
We believe any attempt to establish utopia is bound to meet with failure and, more often than not, disaster.
We believe free enterprise and economic growth, especially at the local level, provide the basis for a sound society.
We believe the University is an important battleground in the “war of ideas” and the outcomes of political battles of the future are, to a great degree, being determined on campuses today.
We believe a code of honor, integrity and rationality are the fundamental characteristics of individual success. There is no excuse for lack of individual initiative.
We emphatically oppose totalitarianism and its apologists.

The Federalist Society was founded on the principles that the state exists to preserve freedom, that the separation of governmental powers is central to our Constitution, and that it is emphatically the province and duty of the judiciary to say what the law is, not what it should be.

Humanities for the Public Good is a multi-year, $1.5-million initiative intended to recognize and catalyze publicly engaged scholarly activity among humanists and humanistic social scientists at UNC-Chapel Hill. Initiated by Terry Rhodes, now Dean of the College of Arts & Sciences, with support from the Institute for the Arts & Humanities and funding from the Mellon Foundation, the initiative offers grants and programmatic opportunities primarily aimed at graduate students and faculty in partnership with cultural institutions within and beyond the academy. The emphases of the initiative are on integrating: public engagement in graduate education, through grants, teaching, and workshops; public and digital humanities efforts, an effort which will be spearheaded by a new Digital Integration Coordinator at the Digital Innovation Lab; and valorizing and promoting civic engagement in faculty teaching and research in the humanities through grants and associated workshops. This work relies upon and complements the long-standing work of UNC-Chapel Hill’s array of programs, centers, institutes, and initiatives which have served as bridges between the university and its many internal and external publics.

Established in 2017, The Institute of Politics (IOP) at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill aims to engage and inspire students, particularly undergraduates, to pursue careers in politics and public service. With nonpartisanship as its cornerstone principle, the Institute strives to promote greater understanding and cooperation between the academic world and the world of politics and public affairs.

Our group is founded for the purposes of 1) connecting students and faculty interested in international law, 2) communicating possible career and networking opportunities, and 3) encouraging greater awareness of (and participation in) international law and policy issues. We aim to achieve these goals by providing social outings where students, LLM and international students especially, and faculty can explore international law in a friendly setting.

Quick Facts:
Community nickname(s): C-Mike
Region of campus: Middle
Time to walk to the Pit: 5 minutes
Style of buildings: Four-bedroom suites
Community office location: Carmichael, first floor lobby


About the Community:
Located at the heart of UNC’s campus, Carmichael’s proximity to Kenan Memorial Stadium, Dorrance Field, the Student Rec Center, and the Pit provides an easy commute to both classes and sports games. Its suite-style layout fosters community building and camaraderie amongst residents, creating a tight-knit community perfect for anyone looking to get connected within the Carolina Community.


Carmichael is home to the BLUE Residential Learning Program (RLP), which encourages student innovation and creativity by allowing exclusive access to BeAM Maker workshops, career planning resources, and applied science co-curricular programs. It also hosts the Transfer United RLP, which facilitates a seamless transition to Carolina for transfer students by providing key resources and support for success in academics, wellness, and community engagement.


About the Residence Hall Association:
RHA stands for the Residence Hall Association and we represent the concerns of over 9,000 residents before the Administration of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provide diverse social, educational, and philanthropic programs within the residence halls, manage community enhancements, facilitate recognition of residence hall leaders, and foster a sense of community and belonging for all students at Carolina. Look out for RHA’s annual “Catching Waves” event held at Carmichael at the end of the Spring semester!

Quick Facts:
Region of campus: Northern
Time to walk to the Pit: 5 minutes
Style of building: Hall-style
Community office location: Cobb, first floor
  About the Community:
Cobb’s beautifully renovated rooms, ample amenities, and five-minute walk to class make it a top choice for many students. Its location next to the basketball and tennis courts is especially appealing, and other campus staples such as Davis Library, Lenoir Dining Hall, the Student Union, and the Student Recreation Center are only a short walk away. Once inside, Cobb boasts a piano room, study spaces, and technologically-equipped seminar rooms perfect for movie nights and community programs.
  About the Residence Hall Association:
RHA stands for the Residence Hall Association and we represent the concerns of over 9,000 residents before the Administration of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provide diverse social, educational, and philanthropic programs within the residence halls, manage community enhancements, facilitate recognition of residence hall leaders, and foster a sense of community and belonging for all students at Carolina. Look out for RHA’s annual “Cobbwarts” event held at the end of the Spring semester!

Quick Facts:
Community nickname: CoCo
Region of campus: Northern
Time to walk to the Pit: 2 minutes
Style of buildings: Hall-style
Community office location: Connor Hall, first floor
  About the Community:
Located just across from the Pit, Connor Community provides residents with easy access to classes, dining options, and study spaces in the center of campus. The community is composed of the Alexander, Connor, Joyner, and Winston Residence Halls, each with their own unique features and atmosphere that allow students to customize their residential experience. The quad directly in front of Connor Residence Hall provides ample opportunities for social connection, frequently hosting volleyball and spikeball tournaments, cookouts, and students lounging in the sun. 
  Joyner Residence Hall, located within Connor Community, is home to the Pride Place Residential Learning Program (RLP), which focuses on wellness, empowerment, and academic success for students of all gender identities, gender expressions, and sexual orientations. Through intersectional learning experiences and a unique partnership with the UNC LGBTQ Center, this RLP provides a support system for LGBTQ+ residents while allowing them to explore various identities and cultural competencies through weekly discussions.
  About the Residence Hall Association:
RHA stands for the Residence Hall Association and we represent the concerns of over 9,000 residents before the Administration of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provide diverse social, educational, and philanthropic programs within the residence halls, manage community enhancements, facilitate recognition of residence hall leaders, and foster a sense of community and belonging for all students at Carolina. Look out for RHA’s annual “Connorstock” event held at the end of the Spring semester!

Quick Facts:
Region of campus: South Campus
Time to walk to the Pit: 15 minutes
Style of buildings: Four-bedroom suites
Community office location: Craige, first floor lobby
  About the Community:
Located near South Campus hotspots such as the Dean Smith Center, Student and Academic Services Buildings (SASB), Chase Dining Hall, and the Rams Head Rec Center, Craige Residence Hall is a great place for first years to live as they begin their journey at Carolina. Whether you prefer to study in the Green Room or play games like pool, ping-pong, and foosball, there is always a place for you to find your home among Craige’s 600+ residents. Easy access to bus routes also ensures that students can get to-and-from classes quickly and can stay connected to North Campus social events.
  Craige is also home to the Carolina Gaming Arena, a state-of-the-art esports facility allowing everyone from casual gamers to competitive players to form teams and play over 100 different games on large monitors and gaming PCs. 
  About the Residence Hall Association:
RHA stands for the Residence Hall Association and we represent the concerns of over 9,000 residents before the Administration of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provide diverse social, educational, and philanthropic programs within the residence halls, manage community enhancements, facilitate recognition of residence hall leaders, and foster a sense of community and belonging for all students at Carolina. Look out for RHA’s annual “Bikini Bottom Bash” or “Craige Carnival” event held at the end of the Spring semester!

Quick Facts:
Community nickname(s): Ehaus
Region of campus: Southern
Time to walk to the Pit: 13 minutes
Style of buildings: Four-bedroom suites
Community office location: Ehringhaus, first floor lobby
  About the Community:
Ehringhaus boasts over 600 residents, making it an ideal spot for first-years looking to make friends as they acclimate to Carolina. Its location across the street from Hinton James and north of Koury creates a unique social environment, well-suited for spontaneous games of sand volleyball on the lawn or long talks while relaxing using the community’s hammocking poles. 
  Ehaus’ close proximity to key campus landmarks such as Boshamer Baseball Stadium, Rams Head Rec Center, Chase Dining Hall, and the Student and Academic Services Buildings (SASB) ensures students can take advantage of the academic resources and social opportunities UNC has to offer.
  About the Residence Hall Association:
RHA stands for the Residence Hall Association and we represent the concerns of over 9,000 residents before the Administration of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provide diverse social, educational, and philanthropic programs within the residence halls, manage community enhancements, facilitate recognition of residence hall leaders, and foster a sense of community and belonging for all students at Carolina. Look out for RHA’s annual “Ehaus Beach Blast” event held at the end of the Spring semester!

Quick Facts:
Community nickname(s): HoJo
Region of campus: Southern
Time to walk to the Pit: 17 minutes
Style of buildings: Four-bedroom suites
Community office location: Hinton James, first floor lobby
  About the Community:
Hinton James, or HoJo, is a social hub on campus and home to over 900 first-year students. Residents can join in on volleyball or pick-up basketball games outside, host study groups in lounges, or chat with friends on one of HoJo’s many balconies. HoJo’s close proximity to the Dean Smith Center provides an added bonus for sports fans, making it easy to go to-and-from basketball games with friends.
  Hinton James is home to the First Generation Residential Learning Program (First Gen RLP), which serves self-identified first-generation students during their first year at Carolina through co-curricular activities, learning spaces, and connections intended to enhance their UNC experience.
  About the Residence Hall Association:
RHA stands for the Residence Hall Association and we represent the concerns of over 9,000 residents before the Administration of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provide diverse social, educational, and philanthropic programs within the residence halls, manage community enhancements, facilitate recognition of residence hall leaders, and foster a sense of community and belonging for all students at Carolina. Look out for RHA’s annual “Hojopalooza” event held at the end of the Spring semester!

Quick Facts:
Region of campus: Northern
Time to walk to the Pit: 7 minutes
Style of buildings: Hall-style
Community office location: Kenan, first floor
  About the Community:
Known for its spacious parlors, large porches, and rocking chairs, Kenan Neighborhood is perfect for those looking to join a close-knit community. It’s location across the street from the Coker Arboretum and a few minutes from East Franklin allows residents to get to classes and social outings within a short time, and the large quad out front ensures there is always a place for students to study and hang out on a sunny day.
  About the Residence Hall Association:
RHA stands for the Residence Hall Association and we represent the concerns of over 9,000 residents before the Administration of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provide diverse social, educational, and philanthropic programs within the residence halls, manage community enhancements, facilitate recognition of residence hall leaders, and foster a sense of community and belonging for all students at Carolina. Look out for RHA’s annual “Kenan Kounty Fair” event held at the end of the Spring semester!

Quick Facts:
Region of campus: Southern
Time to walk to the Pit: 15 minutes
Style of rooms: Two-bedroom suites
Community office location: Craige North, first floor
  About the Community:
Located only a few minutes away from the Dean Dome, Kenan Memorial Stadium, and Chase Dining Hall, the Mannings Neighborhood is perfect for residents looking for easy access to sports games and social events at UNC while still enjoying the increased privacy of two-bedroom, suite-style living. The Mannings Neighborhood is composed of Koury, Horton, Craige North, and Hardin, and the community’s place next to the larger first-year residence halls allows students to join in on basketball and volleyball games or have a picnic with friends on the lawn. Bus stops placed just outside the halls provide a quick way to get to-and-from classes, Franklin Street, and the greater Chapel Hill area.
  About the Residence Hall Association:
RHA stands for the Residence Hall Association and we represent the concerns of over 9,000 residents before the Administration of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provide diverse social, educational, and philanthropic programs within the residence halls, manage community enhancements, facilitate recognition of residence hall leaders, and foster a sense of community and belonging for all students at Carolina. Look out for RHA’s annual “Manning Madness” event held at the end of the Spring semester!

column3:
B
Bioethics Journal at UNC-Chapel Hill

column6:
Carolina Film Association is committed to enabling students develop their cinematic craft. The organization accomplishes its mission by offering resources, guidance, and organization to student filmmakers to realize their vision in a cinematic language over televisual or episodic forms.
We use a fluid structure to develop and produce several projects at once while pushing students to elevate their art. The different guilds collaborate on different projects, playing on each member's different strengths and interests to produce great films. 
Formed from a simple idea, CFA has grown to over 200 undergraduates from a number of academic disciplines. Similarly organized like many production companies, CFA is built upon an Officer Board, a Board of Executive Producers, and multiple Department Guilds (Screenwriting, Editing, Acting, etc.).
Ideas, pitches, and scripts of any nature are welcomed by all, from its members or any UNC student. After a thorough feasibility assessment, greenlighted productions are assigned a producer and/or director. These individuals then build a production crew consisting of actors, editors, cinematographers, and set crew. Across the next couple of weeks, these members work hard to develop a quality piece of work suitable for a multitude of audiences.
  Sign up for our listserv here: https://carolinafilmassociation.weebly.com/email--listserv.html and check out our website while you're at it!

column3: Carolina Otaku Uprising - UNC Anime Club
column6:
**CHECK OUT OUR WAY MORE ACTIVELY UPDATED WEBSITE**
http://coup.web.unc.edu
And join us on Discord (it's where we're most active): http://discord.gg/XBkHBZT
And join us on Twitter
And And Our New Instagram:
And 
COUp seeks to expose and educate all students of UNC to Japanese animation, and is open to any and all interested in being exposed to this piece of Japanese culture--or if you just like giant robots.
Also, about the roster; a large chunk of our members use their gmail addresses primarily, and this roster system only lets us use the UNC email ones, so a number of them haven't opted into the roster.
If you'd like email notifications for our announcements, fill out this form: https://forms.gle/Z1My4V7a4FgpPoUEA

The vision of Carolina Scientific is to produce a professional publication with the purpose of informing students of the latest news in scientific research at UNC-Chapel Hill. We publish one magazine per semester, with about 25-30 articles highlighting ongoing research at UNC-Chapel Hill. This research ranges in discipline, from Biology and Chemistry to Environmental Science and Anthropology. Readers of our magazine have the opportunity to explore their scientific interests and potential projects and labs that they could get involved in. We hope to improve scientific literary for all and inspire innovation and creativity for future STEM leaders! 
We recruit staff writers, designers, and copy editors during the first two to three weeks of each semester to work on that semester's publication. We have interest meetings and workshops for each team. Staff writers will learn how to interview professors and write articles for a science writing magazine. They will also be given information about how to become involved with undergraduate research. Designers learn how to layout and organize a magazine using InDesign. Copy editors get to hone in on their editing skills by editing the articles from the Staff Writers. Our Executive Board oversees content editing, finances, and team leadership. 
If you are interested in joining one of these teams, contact us at carolina.scientific@gmail.com

Cellar Door is the oldest undergraduate literary journal at Carolina. Published annually in print, the magazine has continually showcased the best poetry, prose, and art of the undergraduate student body since 1973-74.
  Cellar Door publishes in print and online, seeking to showcase the best poetry, prose, and visual art on both platforms. The print editions, published each spring, are judged, receive prizes, and are available for free across campus. Online, you’ll find additional content, reviews, and interviews with writers and artists, as well as the same caliber of original, vibrantly creative work that the print edition is known for.
  We accept rolling online submissions at the beginning of the spring semester and print submissions at the beginning of the fall semester. We also hold interest meetings at the beginning of each semester for students who'd like to join our staff.
  For more information, please visit unccellardoor.com.

Thank you for joining The Daily Tar Heel’s Heel Life page! Our newsroom is hiring for the Fall 2021 semester, and you can find the full application online at: https://www.dailytarheel.com/page/dth-fall-2021-application. The current deadline is Aug. 27. Please email editor@dailytarheel.com with any questions or concerns about the hiring process.

We are one of the largest undergraduate majors in the College of Arts and Sciences, with over 2,490 undergraduate majors and 593 undergraduate minors in Fall 2022. Over 200 undergraduate students are involved in research with faculty. We are committed to ensuring our undergraduate majors have transformative academic experiences at Carolina. 99% of our students engage in a research-intensive psychology course, 55% have enrolled in a First-Year Seminar course to make the best transition possible to college life, 43% engage in a service-learning course to extend their learning beyond the classroom and make an impact on the local community, and 25% participate in a study abroad experience to enrich their knowledge and understanding. We want our students to have an academic experience that challenges them to connect their classroom learning with their citizenship in a global economy.

column3: Future Leaders of User Experience at UNC-Chapel Hill
column6:
Welcome to FLUX, the User Experience organization at UNC-Chapel Hill!
FLUX is a vibrant, multidisciplinary community united by our shared enthusiasm for user experience. Our mission is to foster a dynamic campus community where ideas flourish, skills grow, and aspiring UX professionals can embark on a journey of continuous professional development.
Follow us on Instagram for more updates! 

               -->  FLUX_UNC   <--

Lightwood Entertainment aims to provide video-oriented creatives of color on UNC’s campus with the space, resources, support, and cross-collaboration necessary for them to realize their creative visions. With a collective of creatives including writers, directors, producers, marketers, editors and more, we amplify the stories of the unheard through fresh, original content for us, by us.
Our application cycles are on a semester basis. Check out our website and social media for alerts of when our recruitment is open.

A Moment of Magic is the original 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that allows college-age students to provide emotional support to medically vulnerable children, inspiring them to be brave, strong, and fearless. 
  Our most popular services include in-person character visits where our volunteers dress up as favorite fairytale and superhero characters. We provide services such as individual visits, bedside visits, group visits, story readings, etc. You'll find us at hospitals and clinics, at social service institutions, at large public events focused on awareness and advocacy, and even in families homes. 
  We are always looking for new members to join our team. If you are passionate about serving children, please fill out our interest form for the Fall 2023 semester. If you have any questions or want to learn more, don't hesitate to email us.

To assemble college students in a national service fraternity in the fellowship of principles derived from the scout oath and law of the Boy Scouts of America; to develop leadership, to promote friendship and to provide service to humanity; and to further the freedom that is our national, educational and intellectual heritage.  All Brothers are selected through a rush process based upon service and social requirements.  Rush takes place at the beginning of both fall and spring semesters.
In the Rho chapter of Alpha Phi Omega, we try to provide a wide variety of service opportunities. We work with Carolina Tiger Rescue, Adopt a Highway, the Human Rights Center, UNC Hospitals, Arc of Orange County, A Helping Hand, Battle ParkCharles’ House, and TABLE, to name a few. On campus, we also work with Dance Marathon, Habitat for Humanity, Relay for Life and run the UNC Lost and Found. We have monthly drives, which are for national relief efforts or to benefit an organization we work with. In addition to drives, we give monetary grants out every semester to organizations chosen by our fraternity. Every semester the service committee tries to extend the impact of APO on campus and in the community. Whether you enjoy working with animals, tutoring young people, helping the elderly, or helping in general, the Rho chapter makes connections with organizations to make any service possible.

column3: American Red Cross Club of UNC-CH
column6:
*UPDATED 9/25/2023
New members welcome!
Register for Volunteer Connection! Following the below tutorial video, make sure to use this direct link: (Link Coming Soon)

The American Red Cross Club at UNC is the perfect club to join for anyone interested in health, community outreach, and service activities. General Interest Meetings are held at the beginning of the fall semester and are a great way to learn more about the American Red Cross Club and its role at UNC and within the community. However, you can join at any time throughout the school year!
Please reach out to us on social media (Instagram: @unc_arcc & Facebook @UNCRedCrossClub) or email (uncamericanredcrossclub@gmail.com) to learn more about what the Red Cross Club does each semester.
Quick guide to the UNC-CH American Red Cross Club:
We’re a part of the Central North Carolina Chapter of the American Red Cross
Dues: $10 for the whole year (Venmo our Treasurer, @Amir-Shaheeen). Please inform an exec if this isn't feasible!
We have four committees:
Biomedical
Health and Safety
Disaster Services
Fundraising
Meetings are biweekly
Registration with Volunteer Connection is mandatory for all volunteers!
We organize blood drives, participate in SPLASH, Safetoberfest, and organize other events on campus and throughout the community!
